componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Boston Properties' Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Ms. Arista Joyner, Investor Relations Manager for Boston Properties. Please, go ahead.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties' Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night, as well as furnished on Form 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconciled all
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties' Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night, as well as furnished on Form 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements. If you did not receive a copy, these documents are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.bostonproperties.com. 
An audio webcast of this call will be available for 12 months in the Investor Relations section of our website. At this time, we would like to inform you that certain statements made during this conference call which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although Boston Properties believes the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, it can give no assurance that its expectations will be attained. Factors and risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by forward-looking statements were detailed in Wednesday's press release and, from time to time, in the company's filings with the SEC. The company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. Having said that, I'd like to welcome Owen Thomas, Chief Executive Officer; Doug Linde, President; and Mike LaBelle, Chief Financial Officer. During the question-and-answer portion of our call, Ray Ritchey, Senior our Executive Vice President and our regional management team will be available to address any questions. I would now like to turn the call over to Owen Thomas for his formal remarks.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arista, and good morning, everyone. Our focus today, in addition to the quarter and market conditions will be a review of 2015 and our outlook for 2016. On current results, we produced another solid quarter with FFO per share $0.01 above consen
componenttext:
Thank you, Arista, and good morning, everyone. Our focus today, in addition to the quarter and market conditions will be a review of 2015 and our outlook for 2016. On current results, we produced another solid quarter with FFO per share $0.01 above consensus and $0.01 above our guidance after adjusting for The Seasons transaction. Based on recent leasing accomplishments, as well as a significant lease termination we just completed for $45 million, we have also increased the midpoint of our full year 2016 FFO per share guidance by $0.26. We leased 1.4 million square feet in the fourth quarter and 5.2 million square feet for all of 2015 and our portfolio occupancy is now 91.4%. 
So moving to the operating environment. The U.S. economy continues to grow albeit at modest level with full year 2016 GDP growth expected to be 2% to 2.5%. There was a modest slowdown in the fourth quarter of 2015 as GDP rose only 0.7%. The jobs picture remains healthy with 292,000 jobs created in December, 2.7 million jobs created in all of 2015, 2.5% wage growth for last year and 5% unemployment, albeit with lower workforce participation rates. Economic growth continues to be uneven with energy-related industrial sectors in recessions. Our markets that are driven by technology and life sciences are continuing to exhibit tightening leasing conditions. Office markets nationally are also firming. The data indicates that absorption was 17 million square feet for the fourth quarter and 46 million square feet for all of 2015. Vacancy ended the year at 13.8%, down 20 basis points for the fourth quarter and 50 basis points for the year and asking rent rose 4.7% with Boston and San Francisco experiencing the highest increases. Construction levels actually dropped in the fourth quarter to 2% of existing stock but are up 9% from a year ago. Financial markets have become very volatile in 2016 driven largely by concerns that weaker economic growth outside the U.S. and falling oil prices will have a negative impact on the U.S. economy. Most economic data indicates a continued slowdown in the Chinese economy, the domestic equity market in China is down over 20% year-to-date and fears of additional currency devaluation are pervasive. China has funded an estimated $600 billion of currency reserves over the last 6 months, supporting the remedy to its current trading level. Local regulators appeared to be taking additional steps to stem capital flows out of China. Oil prices have also dropped nearly 50% from highest last year to approximately $33 a barrel. This has caused disruption in the industrial component of the U.S. economy and widening credit spreads for high-yield particularly related to the energy sector. We are also monitoring with interest investment activity from oil based fund as several Middle Eastern funds have reportedly been redeeming more liquid offshore investment than 2015. And lastly, despite the Federal Reserve raising short-term rates 25 basis points in December, the 10 year U.S. Treasury has dropped below 1.9%, given all the global economic uncertainty mentioned. 
So what is all of these mean for real estate, investment activity and valuation? Our instincts that are investment activity from some of oil base sovereign wealth fund should slow due to decreasing inflows and capital needs at home and that flows from China will recede due to increasing capital control. However, there continue to be numerous large-scale office deals completed in gateway markets at attractive pricing. Recent examples included selling 787 7th Avenue to CalPERS and 1285 6th Avenue to RXR and Blackstone selling 4 assets in Westwood to Douglas Summit as well as 500 Street and 222 Berkeley in Boston to Oxford and JPMorgan. All these deals were large and completed with North American led investors at cap rates in the mid-4% range or lower. Our REIT is capital values for high-quality assets are holding up, notwithstanding in some cases, fewer bidders and a somewhat geographic rotation of investor appetite. Further as a tailwind, long-term interest rates are low and dropping while cap rates spreads to treasuries are above long-term average have been rising. Investment yields and cash flow stability from high-quality real estate assets will continue to be an attractive investment alternative to fixed income. Our capital strategy remains largely unchanged in that we are investing more in new developments versus acquisitions which will be funded partially by additional dispositions. On acquisitions, we continue to actively review new investments but do not anticipate significant investments and stabilize buildings given continued robust pricing. We are however, seeing a pick up in value add and development opportunities in our core markets. 
Moving to disposition. In the fourth quarter, we completed the sale of Innovation Place in San Jose for $207 million, including a gain of $79 million and a land parcel sale in Maryland for $13 million. Our total dispositions for 2015 were $584 million on an hour share basis which led to a special dividend of $1.25 per share, which brings our total special dividend paid since 2005 to over $21 per share. For 2016, we expect to continue to sell non-core assets and assets where we are able to achieve extraordinary pricing, but likely at levels below 2015. Our balance sheet is strong. We have already raised the cash to fund our significant capital need and we see upside in many of our core assets through roll ups and redevelopment. We recently sold 7 Kendall Center to MIT for $105 million based on a pre-agreed option associated with MIT's tenancy in the building. We also placed under contract for sale our Reston Eastgate site to a corporate user who will retain us to build a corporate facility for their use, further enhancing the Reston area. Though difficult to estimate precisely at this time, we would expect to $200 million to $250 million of total assets sales in 2016. 
Moving to development. Our activities remain robust. In the fourth quarter, we placed in service from our development pipeline, 535 Mission Street and 690 Folsom Street in San Francisco, the Point in the Waltham and Annapolis Junction in Annapolis, Maryland. In the aggregate, these projects cost $254 million and with the exception of Annapolis Junction, which is currently not lease, we're delivered 98% occupied and an unleverage cash yield of 7.8% which is above our target. Also in the fourth quarter, we added to our active development pipeline, the Hub on Causeway at North Station, which is the podium phase of our North Station development in Boston, where we have signed anchor deals for 60% of the 200,000 square-foot retail component and are negotiating 85,000 square feet of additional retail and office leases. North Station is a very significant mixed use development being built adjacent to 1 of Boston's busiest transit stations and the TD Garden. This project is a 50% partnership with Delaware North and will provide us with significant long-term profit opportunity. At year-end, our development pipeline consisted of 11 projects representing 4.6 million square feet and $2.6 billion in project costs. Our budgeted NOI yield for these projects is in excess of 7%. The commercial component of the pipeline is 58% pre-leased. We have all the cash, $1.5 billion, required to complete the development of the portfolio, which should add materially to our company's growth over the next 4 years. 
Looking ahead into 2016 on development. We have numerous entitled projects and new starts will be highly dependent on pre-leasing activity. More specifically, we secured 940,000 square feet in additional entitlements from the city of Cambridge for Kendall Center and are in discussion with several tenants for pre-leasing a 360,000 square-foot office building. For Springfield Metro Center in Northern Virginia, we are pursuing a 600,000 square-foot requirement from the TSA. Again, predicated on substantial pre-leasing, other potential projects for this year are 20 City Point in Walton, Mass. and Blockside office in Reston. All of these projects aggregate 1.5 million square feet. 
Lastly, we continue to devote time and resources to refurbishing our existing high-quality asset base. As Citibank vacates 399 Park Avenue in late 2017, we'll be completing upgrades to the facade entrance, roof decks and outdoor spaces. A redevelopment of the office and retail space in the low rise 601 Lexington Avenue was also planned. We are also updating lobbies and common space at 1330 Connecticut Avenue and Metropolitan Square in Washington, D.C. to accommodate existing tenant renewals and attract new tenants. 
So in summary, we are very enthusiastic about our prospects for success and ability to create shareholder value in 2016 and beyond. We have a very clear plan to improve and lease our existing assets as well as add new buildings through development to our portfolio. All of which we expect to result in attractive FFO growth over the coming years. We have selected non-core assets for sale to ensure continued portfolio refreshment. We have significant entitled and unentitled land holdings that we will continue to push through the design and permitting process and add selectively to our development pipeline in future years. Our balance sheet is strong with net debt-to-EBITDA below 6x and with much of our upcoming debt maturities having now been either refinanced or hedged. This strong capital position will also allow us to pursue and act on investment opportunities that may present themselves in the coming quarter due to increasingly turbulent financial market conditions. Now, over to Doug for a further review of our markets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. So it seems like everyday we seem to jump on this roller coaster of global volatility in the financial markets. But I do want to step back and just sort of take a little bit of a prospective here. So about 8 months a
componenttext:
Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. So it seems like everyday we seem to jump on this roller coaster of global volatility in the financial markets. But I do want to step back and just sort of take a little bit of a prospective here. So about 8 months ago when we were in the conference, I think almost every meeting we had was dominated by questions focused on signs of weakness in the tech markets, the lack of public IPOs, questionable valuations of unicorns, whether there was a looming shadow vacancy in our tech -- biotech markets due to potential slowing from venture capital sources and that all of this was sort of going to be precipitating the market correction. I think honestly that these are the same questions that we were asked in November and they're the same questions that are on everyone's mind today. They continue to be top of mind. So just take that perspective as I give my comments. You're going to recall that the way we've been characterizing the Bay Area real estate market is really 1 of, as I would refer to, healthy where the activity is really pretty similar to what it was in 2013, which was a really good year, but clearly off the spike that we saw in 2014. And I think the pace of activity that we're getting today is pretty similar to the same activity that we've been seeing in the back half of 2015 and it's pretty constant. And I just sort of want to supply some facts to back that up. So in the Northern Peninsula in the Valley, in the last quarter or so, Apple has expanded by another 1 million square feet. Google has leased over 500,000 square feet and they've entered into additional building purchase agreements. Palo Alto Networks has expanded by 300,000 square feet. Facebook has taken on 200,000 Square feet. As Owen said, we were the beneficiary of Broadcom's desire to expand and they purchased our 574,000 square feet at Innovation Center and have filed permit for the next phase of development, which is up to 537,000 square feet. And then, on top of all that, there've been another 12 fields in the Valley for over 1.3 million square feet with block of space over 50,000 square feet. And we, in January, signed 88,000 square feet of renewals and expansions in our single-story Mountainview asset that's R&D property over $48 triple net rent. If you go to the city. Leasing activity in the city finished off 2015, clearly off of the 2014 level high when Salesforce and Twitter and Dropbox all combined for over 1.4 million square feet, just those 3 tenants. But again, it was the exact same level we were in 2013. Tech demand continues to average around 50% of the volume in the city and there has been a pretty consistent volume of deals. Now recently, there's been continued attention to sublet space. Well, the Dropbox sublet, which was planned at China basin, it was all absorbed by Stripe and Lift. There was some Twitter availability that was described in the mid-market area and it's all under lease negotiation. In fact, there's over 850,000 square feet of tech leasing that's expected to get done in the first quarter and it's almost entirely expansion led by Air B&B, which has taken an additional 150,000 square feet from the former Dolby building. The largest block of sublet space that was in our portfolio was a 5-4 block in EC3 coming back from the Morgan Lewis mortgage that occurred a few years ago. We leased 4 of those 5 floors. Now there is some speculative construction in the city, 181 Fremont and 350 Bush and The Exchange are all under construction and they're adding about 1.4 million square feet of space. In Park Tower, at Trend Bay is supposedly going to be -- sorry, another 750,000 square feet. But again, the overall vacancy rate in the city of San Francisco is under 6% and people continue to talk about the prop issues there but the point is that after the FAR deposit in October, the bank was at about 1.75 million square feet but the first admission project, if 598 Brand Street get approved, the bank will be empty. No additional supply availability. At Embarcadero Center, we completed another 220,000 square feet of office leasing during a quarter. 4 floors totaled 162,000 square feet and new tenants moving into Embarcadero made up 145,000 square feet of that. During the third quarter, you may recall and I'm going to refer to this a few times, we described our "revenue bridge" to get into the end of 2017 and I think one of the sell side analyst on our last call sort of asked, well, so how much of that's in the bag back? Well in Embarcadero Center, the larger deals that we completed last quarter, about 95,000 square feet, are going to add about 2.4 million square feet to that 2017 revenue versus '15. The new floor deals that we did this quarter, 145,000 square feet are going to add 4.4 million square feet. We have another 4 more floors close to being completed, another 89,000 square feet. Those floors a going to add 5.1 million square feet for a total of 12 million square feet of fundamental growth from Embarcadero Center. So $12 million of incremental growth from Embarcadero Center. The mark-to-market on these transactions is between 40% and 70% on a gross basis. And none of those transactions are in our same-store statistics for the quarter. In fact, there's only about 28,000 square feet of CBD deals in the San Francisco region in that same store data in our supplemental. Traditional fiery of demand continues to be very strong at Embarcadero Center and across the city. At 535 Mission, we're at 99% leased. So this is the last time you're going to be hearing about that project for quite some time. We've completed 51,000 square feet of leases. Average growth gross rent of about $80 a square foot. The building should be fully contributing by the third quarter of '16, cash returned 7.8%, 150 basis points greater than our pro forma. I have hope to announce that we had signed leases for additional 5 floors at Salesforce Tower, 108,000 square feet, bringing that to 821,000 square feet of leasing of that 1.4 million square foot building or 59%. While, 2 of the leases are back or 2 of those floors but the remainder is yet to come in and we expect to see it hopefully by this Friday. So we're going to have 108,000 square feet of leasing done. We're adding venture capital and management consulting clients as industries are being represented in the building. We still have active single and multi floor discussions going on with asset managers and hedge funds and more VCs, law firms, consulting firms, real estate brokerage firms and other non-tech service firms that encompass another 300,000 plus square foot of space. Activity continues to be really strong at Salesforce Tower. And most of these requirements are lease expiration driven occupancy. Tenants are recognizing the value and excitement about the Salesforce Tower and wanting to be there. So again, in summary, activity across the California portfolio, our Bay Area portfolio continues to be very strong. 
Let's jump over to Manhattan Midtown. Again, not much has changed on our activity and expectations for the Midtown market. Our tone has been pretty consistent for the last 24 months, somewhat subdued. When we made the strategic decision to get in front of our many pending lease expirations due to the large block future availability to supply in the market. And our view that providing early release in the form of taking back some space in small increments will be the best interest of both us and our customers. Well, during this quarter, we completed another 11 deals, 120,000 square feet. 8 of them had starting rents above $90,000 a square foot and 6 were above $100,000 a square foot. Compared to the last quarter, where we did 12 deals, 90,000 were over, square feet -- in 10 deals over $90 a square foot and 7 deals over $100 a Square Foot. Now, it's clear that during periods of high stock and credit market volatility, many things due in fact distract the high end users. And while some of the active tenants are probably elongating their decision-making process, they continue to look for space and sublet space in Midtown is at an 8 year low. In 2014, there were 570,000 square feet of leases done with starting rents between $90 and $99 a square foot. In 2015, there was more than 1.2 million. For deals over $100 a square foot, there was over 1 million square feet in 2015. The reason I talked about this is because the bulk of our availability and rollover in our portfolio in the next few years occurred in spaces with that command rents in excess of $90 or $100 a square foot. Now transaction size continues to be small, with the preponderance of the activity under 20,000 square feet for nonrenewal, which is the reason we have, again strategically, decide to cut off the remaining floors that we have at 250 West 55th Street and we have leases out for all of our remaining prebuilt suites and we have signed half of our deals on the 2 of the 3 available floors that we have. We have signed leases now for 242,000 square feet with incremental gross revenues of $18 million that will be exhibiting in 2017, another component of our bridge. We signed a termination agreement last night with a tenant that leaves 85,000 square feet in a combination of 1 high-rise floor, the second floor and a portion of the ground-level space at 250 West 55th Street. While working with the tenant on the transaction that will allow them to minimize their future obligations while recognizing both the cost and the time associated with finding a replacement tenant, the parties agree to a onetime payment and a transfer of the responsibility of retenanting the building to Boston Properties. That space was never built out and we never provided TI. 
Switching over to 399. As Owen said, we've unveiled our plan for the upgrade, including the addition of outdoor terraces in our "Oasis in the Sky", as we position the building to relapse 640,000 Square feet of 2017 explorations. Those are late '17 explanations. We are in lease negotiations now on 200,000 square feet of that space and we completed our first full floor deal in the mid-rise where we have pricing the space with starting rent around $115 a square foot. There are a number of medium-sized financial institutions with 2018 and '19 explorations that really value to be more affordable, low-rise large block space, we have those 165,000 --  100,000 floors and 55,000 square foot floors but with connectivity to our slightly more expensive space in the mid-rise. 
Going down to Washington, D.C. 2/3 of our activity this quarter in the Washington area was in Northern Virginia where we completed 128,000 square feet of leases with the GSA, renewal at our VA95 project and also some GA -- GSA contract dependent expansions that are Kingstowne projects. Then we also did 10 small transactions in Reston Town Center. In January, we completed a 60,000 square-foot renewal at the Town Center with starting rents of over $54 a square foot. And again, if you compare that to the total, were rents are on average of $33 to $35 a square foot, a premium from Reston continues to show. Reston is 97% leased. Our signature residential project is under construction and we are in lease negotiations for 80% of the 25,000 square feet of retail that's associated with that project. And for our leasing team followed its typical pattern given the lack of blocks of space and the continued demand in Reston, we should have a lead tenant for the 275,000 square foot signature office development sometime in 2016. In the CBD of D.C., we completed our second office lease at 601 Ave. and we have pretty good activity o the remaining 47,000 Square feet. Our largest availability is going to be at Metropolitan Square where we have 120,000 square foot tenant expiring at the end of first quarter. We are in active discussions on more than 110,000 square feet of that upcoming availability. Our view is that the overall market conditions in D.C. really haven't changed much. On the margin, it's probably a little bit more GSA related leasing that's anticipated for 2016, but it's probably going to have some economic limits that will push it a little bit further out of the CBD in the East end. The district continues to be very competitive. 
The majority of our Boston activity during the quarter was in suburban Waltham, Lexington. The Waltham Metro West Market, a "suburban market" continues to get stronger driven by organic expansion. This quarter, we did 16 leases in our suburban portfolio for 413,000 square feet and we have another 200,000 under active negotiation. Rents have increased 25% over the last 18 months. Delivery of the Waltham development is on target, August for 10 City Point  October for 1265 Main. Both projects come into service 100% leased. In January, the city of Boston learned that General Electric had chosen to move its corporate headquarters to the city. It's expected to bring about 800 jobs, but that's really not what the issue is. What it really speaks to is the overall economic ecosystem of the area. This region continues to be a magnet for both the life science industry, established technology companies, as well as start app tech and maker organizations. This has led to continual improvement in business growth in the greater Boston area. The East Cambridge office and land market is probably the largest beneficiary of growth and if that has the best economic of any market that we're in. With 6.5 million square feet of office space and just under 8 million of lab, base, direct vacancy is under 4%. Office rents continue to achieve new peaks with the most recent transaction to being completed on the office space of over $65 triple net with annual increases. Head improvement allowances have been reduced and are not below $60 per square foot. As Owen mentioned, we finished out the year with an up-zoning of our Kendall Square development that's going to allow for the eventual development of 540,000 square feet of commercial office and 400,000 square feet of residential, including 80,000 up for sale. We're having substantive conversations right now with a number of existing tenants that are searching for growth and looking for that office space. The other news for our Cambridge portfolio is the recent decision of Microsoft to relocate a group that it has at 255 Main Street to the suburbs over the next 24 months. This is likely going to mean that we will have an opportunity to leased 125,000 square feet of space that will not going to be expiring until 2021. With the site, RFP expected to be issued in May and the zoning applications still in process, we would expect more Cambridge tenants with near-term space need to be likely exploring suburban Waltham in Lexington and the Boston CBD because there's simply no place to go in the city of Cambridge right now. The Boston CBD continues to be a good market as supply has been absorbed over the last 2 years, though there is some speculative development the seaport of a modest size building. Again, GE has not landed on where its new home is going to be and it could take existing inventory or go to a new development. At 120 St. James, where we have 170,000 square feet of availability, there are now a number of tenants reviewing our options at the building and they range from 32,000 square feet of single floor up to the entire 170,000 square-foot block. 
At 200 Clarendon, we're in lease negotiations with tenants that will fill 100 floors in the high rise, and leave us with 90,000 square feet on floors 45, 46 and 47. High end demand in Boston is typically been for users under 30,000 square feet and we expect to lease the spaces in smaller increments. We have completed our multi-tenant transaction at 100 Federal Street were Putnam has signed a leased for 250,000 square feet, Wellington has executed a long-term renewal and relocation on 156,000 square feet its current using and BofA has been able to realize some space and rent savings by reducing its footprint by 137,000 square feet. All of the available space at 107 Federal Street has now been spoken for. Again, as you think about our bridge to 2017, these transactions at 100 Federal Street contribute approximately $6 million of incremental revenue. So last fall, we outlined $80 million of incremental revenue from our existing portfolio that we hope to have in place by the end of '17. Given all the transactions I've described, we now have commitments for approximately $36 million of that $80 million. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I'm going to start out with a few comments of what we're seeing on the debt markets. As you know, we deceased our $640 million mortgage loan on 200 Clarendon Street in December. That resulted in a $0.13 per share charge
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I'm going to start out with a few comments of what we're seeing on the debt markets. As you know, we deceased our $640 million mortgage loan on 200 Clarendon Street in December. That resulted in a $0.13 per share charge for our fourth quarter earnings. To replenish our cash, we closed on $1 billion 10 year bond deal at an all in yield of 3.77%. The excess funds will be used to repay our $211 million mortgage on Fountain Square, that is open for prepayment at par in April, as well as fund our future development costs. We've reduced the cash interest rate by 200 basis points with this bond deal versus the expiring loan and the annual cash interest savings will be $11.5 million, even though we borrowed an additional $150 million of proceeds. On a GAAP basis, the interest rate reduction is 75 basis points as both of the refinance loans were above market at acquisition, so they have a noncash fair value interest component that is amortized into and reduced its GAAP interest expense. Clearly, the market volatility that Owen described is having an impact on the credit market. It's driving credit spreads wider  particularly as you move out the risk spectrum. The bond market continue to operate efficiently though at high-quality issuers like ourselves have access on spreads that are 20 to 30 basis points wider than 155 basis point spread that we issued in early January. Though there are frequently days when the global volatility does necessitate patience. With the rally and the tenure of below 2%, all in borrowing costs really haven't moved much for us. The mortgage markets have been a more fickle with CMBS spreads widening, more significantly, especially in the conduit world and for single asset deals that are in secondary markets are not fully stabilized. For high-quality stabilized properties in strong locations, the markets remained active with both life companies and CMBS issuers actively putting out mortgage money with 50% to 60% leverage loans pricing at a 4% area for 10 years. The banks are also increasingly active in financing 5 to 7 year term loans on a floating rate basis at competitive spreads. So although we see some volatility, good quality assets like ours continue to be able to secure attractively priced long-term financing. With the most active buyers for our asset class looking to employ lower leverage, the financing markets remain favorable. 
I also want to note that over the past 3 years, our asset sales strategy and the delivery of development properties at superior yields has translated into a reduction in our leverage position. As our new deliveries stabilize, we expect these ratios will continue to improve and create additional investment capacity on our balance sheet. I just want to quickly touch on our earnings for the quarter. We reported funds from operation of $1.28 per share after adjusting for this season's charge, we came in at $0.01 ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range, which was related the better performance in the portfolio. Operating expenses came in better than budgeted while our revenues are pretty tightly aligned with our expectations. For 2016, we are increasing our NOI projections from are in service portfolio. As Doug detailed, we continue to see good leasing activity, particularly in San Francisco and in Boston. In Boston, we closed the Putnam lease and although will not impact earnings until 2017, the transaction included a relocation and the long terms extension with Wellington with future that will be straight line in 2016. We're also seeing increased activity on our vacancy, both in the high rise space at 200 Clarendon Street and at the Prudential Tower where we could see additional income from it later this year. At Embarcadero Center in San Francisco, we continue to be successful in completing a number of these renewables with significant rental rate increases and have activity on our availability. If these renewals are signed, our GAAP income reflects the straight-line impact of the rental rate increases, though the cash impact will not occur until the future renewal date, which is in most cases, later in 2016 or in 2017. As Doug mentioned, we terminated an 85,000 square-foot lease at 250 West 55th Street and receive a significant termination payment of $45 million. Also at 601 Lexington Avenue, we are finalizing a termination with its tenant in the high-rise, which will enable Citibank to relocate out of the low-rise office building, so it can be vacated for repositioning. Overall, we expect our 2016 termination income to be approximately $47.5 million higher than our guidance last quarter. These lease terminations will result in lower future rental income until such time as we find replacement tenants. The lost income is projected to be approximately $11 million in 2016. Given it's lumpy nature, our practice is to exclude termination income from our same property NOI guidance but it does have an impact. The leasing success that we are executing exceeded our expectations and would have improved our GAAP same-store NOI growth projection by about 50 basis points. However, the loss rental income related to our decision to enter into lease termination has more than offset this growth. The net impact on our GAAP same-store property NOI projection is a decrease of approximately 25 basis points from our guidance last quarter. The loss termination -- income from termination also impacts our cash same property NOI though we still project growth of 1% to 3% over 2015. As a reminder, our same-store property growth is weighed down by rollover at 767 5th Avenue and at 601 Lexington Avenue. Both of these are consolidated joint venture properties. The growth in our share of same property NOI is approximately 100 basis points higher for both GAAP and cash. We project our noncash straight-line rental income to be $35 million to $50 million in 2016 which is higher than our projection last quarter. The completion of our bond deal takes care of the $1 billion of our near-term debt maturities. We now have $2.9 billion of consolidated debt expiring over the next 2 years, of which $2.3 billion represents our share. These loans carry a cash interest rate of 5.9% and a GAAP interest rate of 4.4%. We have hedged the 10 year swap rate on $1 billion of the expected refinancing. The only material financing activity in our 2016 projections is the refinancing of our $350 million mortgage loan on Embarcadero Center 4 in the fourth quarter. This loan has a cash interest rate of 6.1% and a GAAP interest rate of 7%. So our interest expense run rate should be lower at the end of the year. Overall, we project our 2016 full-year interest expense to be $400 million to $450 million, which is net of capitalized interest of $40 million to $50 million. The impact of these changes results in our increasing our guidance range for 2016 funds from operations from operations to $5.78 to $5.93 per share. This is an increase of $0.26 per share at the midpoint which consists of $0.21 per share from the net impact of tenant termination and $0.05 per share from better projected performance at our same property portfolio. That completes our formal remarks. Operator, if you could turn the call over to questions, that would be great. Thank you.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is from the line of Jamie Feldman from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is from the line of Jamie Feldman from Bank of America.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about the largest chunks left to go and your thoughts on timing of those leases?
componenttext: Can you just talk about the largest chunks left to go and your thoughts on timing of those leases?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is called no good deed goes unpunished, right? So the 3 largest components that are likely to be talked about the next few quarters are at the 200 Clarendon Street in 120 St. James, which is the building in Boston. The additional lease up at the Prud
componenttext: This is called no good deed goes unpunished, right? So the 3 largest components that are likely to be talked about the next few quarters are at the 200 Clarendon Street in 120 St. James, which is the building in Boston. The additional lease up at the Prudential Center, which is about 90,000 square feet of space, and the changes that we're going to be going through at 757 General Motors Building, which are both the retail space at the base and the floors that we're getting back in July. That's where the bulk of that is coming from. And I think the prognosis is positive and we're working forward on transactions on all stuff but I mean, it maybe a quarter, it maybe 3 quarters before we announced those transactions are completed.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you commented on some of the higher end tenants particularly in New York City maybe taking longer to make decisions given stock market volatility. Could you just provide more color on exactly what you're seeing and whether things are getting del
componenttext: Okay. And you commented on some of the higher end tenants particularly in New York City maybe taking longer to make decisions given stock market volatility. Could you just provide more color on exactly what you're seeing and whether things are getting delayed?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I said, I think overall tenor of the market and I'm going to let John Powers comment, is been that things are taking a little bit longer but the activity remains the same. So as an example, when I look at our portfolio of tenants looking at the spac
componenttext: So as I said, I think overall tenor of the market and I'm going to let John Powers comment, is been that things are taking a little bit longer but the activity remains the same. So as an example, when I look at our portfolio of tenants looking at the space of the General Motors Building of the 34th and 35th floors force, we've got 3 or 4 tenants that are actively interested in pieces of those floors. I think that there are days when there's more focus on looking at their screens than they're looking at office space, so I think it's just a long decision making process. And John, you want to make any additional comments?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I would add is that we finished last year with a very good leasing year, very good leasing velocity year. I'm talking about Manhattan overall. It was down 6% from 2014 but then again, it was a 6% higher than the last 5 years. During the year
componenttext: I guess, what I would add is that we finished last year with a very good leasing year, very good leasing velocity year. I'm talking about Manhattan overall. It was down 6% from 2014 but then again, it was a 6% higher than the last 5 years. During the year, we had issues in August, in September as Owen and Doug said, and we had spread widely as Mike talked about and that never moved into the leasing market It might have been a few deals slowing down a little. So right now, we have the same kind of activity in the financial markets and people are looking at it, but a lot of large tenants are planning for significant period of time and are not continuing with what with they do. Some of the smaller tenants in the smaller deals I think look more closely at the screens than the larger organizations do.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Emmanuel Korchman with Citi.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Emmanuel Korchman with Citi.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe Mike or Doug, if we think about the $80 million of NOI uplift that we all keep talking about, how much of that is going to actually impact '17 numbers and how much of that is you thinking about that $80 million as sort of a run rate going into '18?
componenttext: Maybe Mike or Doug, if we think about the $80 million of NOI uplift that we all keep talking about, how much of that is going to actually impact '17 numbers and how much of that is you thinking about that $80 million as sort of a run rate going into '18?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wish I could give you an honest answer because the timing is what's really is going to drive that. I can tell you that much of it will start to bleed in, in latter parts of '16 and much of it will bleed in over '17. So there's no question that by the en
componenttext: I wish I could give you an honest answer because the timing is what's really is going to drive that. I can tell you that much of it will start to bleed in, in latter parts of '16 and much of it will bleed in over '17. So there's no question that by the end of '17, we'll have all of it in our estimations right now. I can't tell you that it's 60% in the first quarter of '17 or 80% in the first quarter of '17. A lot of it is going to be dependent upon the physical characteristics of the space and when we can start recognizing revenue.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it's fair to assume that some majority portion will be a '17 impact and then there will be bleed over -- or there would be a bleed over that impacts '18 specifically?
componenttext: But it's fair to assume that some majority portion will be a '17 impact and then there will be bleed over -- or there would be a bleed over that impacts '18 specifically?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the fact is that a lot of it is going to be coming in very bulky manner in 2017, not all on January 1, 2017 but over each quarter. But by the fourth quarter, it will all be there. But again, a significant piece of it is going to be in before
componenttext: Yes, I think the fact is that a lot of it is going to be coming in very bulky manner in 2017, not all on January 1, 2017 but over each quarter. But by the fourth quarter, it will all be there. But again, a significant piece of it is going to be in before that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just thinking about San Francisco for a second. How much of the showings of the demand at Salesforce is overlapping with either current or prospective tenants at Embarcadero?
componenttext: Great. And then just thinking about San Francisco for a second. How much of the showings of the demand at Salesforce is overlapping with either current or prospective tenants at Embarcadero?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a question we had last quarter as well and it's an interesting question. So the existing incumbent tenants at Embarcadero Center, we have 1 tenant that we're talking to at Embarcadero Center that is likely to leave and moved to Salesforce.
componenttext: I think that's a question we had last quarter as well and it's an interesting question. So the existing incumbent tenants at Embarcadero Center, we have 1 tenant that we're talking to at Embarcadero Center that is likely to leave and moved to Salesforce. There are some tenants that are looking at those Embarcadero Center and Salesforce that are not tenants on our portfolio right now.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to go back to comments earlier on investment markets. Feel like there's going to be a little bit of a pullback from the oil based economies in China which make some sense. But you also mentioned other geographies picking up and I guess, on net,
componenttext: Just want to go back to comments earlier on investment markets. Feel like there's going to be a little bit of a pullback from the oil based economies in China which make some sense. But you also mentioned other geographies picking up and I guess, on net, do you think those other geographies will be able to offset the loss inflows from those other 2 segments and curious if that's more based on your expectations or have you started to see that unfolding in the markets already?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we have seen it unfolding in the markets over the last couple of quarters. I cited $3 billion plus, $4 billion actually, deals in high-quality office space, high-quality office deals in gateway markets that went to North American led investme
componenttext: I think that we have seen it unfolding in the markets over the last couple of quarters. I cited $3 billion plus, $4 billion actually, deals in high-quality office space, high-quality office deals in gateway markets that went to North American led investment groups, so either U.S. pension funds, other U.S. investors or Canadian investors. So I think that there is a bit of a geographic rotation but to thus far, certainly, U.S. investors, Canadian investors. We're increasingly seeing Japanese investors in the marketplace. Investors from Asia outside of China, there are other groups that are in the marketplace and so far, have led to a lack of reduction in pricing at least today.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just on the flip side of that, you're seeing more opportunities on the value add side of things and I was just curious if you can provide more color of exactly what's driving that. If there are more projects coming to market? Are the traditional
componenttext: Okay, and just on the flip side of that, you're seeing more opportunities on the value add side of things and I was just curious if you can provide more color of exactly what's driving that. If there are more projects coming to market? Are the traditional buyers pulling back? A combination of those and have cap rates moved significantly in that space?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the value add, I think we have mentioned for many quarters prior to this and also in this quarter, we're focusing on new investments were we can use our real estate talent. So that would be either new development or redevelopment of existing assets.
componenttext: So on the value add, I think we have mentioned for many quarters prior to this and also in this quarter, we're focusing on new investments were we can use our real estate talent. So that would be either new development or redevelopment of existing assets. And I do think right now, we have a fairly robust pipeline of things that we're looking at in both of those categories and most of our core markets. These are areas where many of the sovereign wealth funds and offshore investors, you know it's not 100% the case but they're less active, so it's helpful to us.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Jed Reagan with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jed Reagan with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: There were some concerns put out there last week that New York City job and rent growth is likely soften this year and then non-core asset values in the city might be repriced lower. Are you expecting those kind of changes yourselves and do you think this
componenttext: There were some concerns put out there last week that New York City job and rent growth is likely soften this year and then non-core asset values in the city might be repriced lower. Are you expecting those kind of changes yourselves and do you think this could affect some other markets in your portfolio?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So before I let John respond more specifically about his view, the company's perspective has been that we have been seeing modest amounts of rental rate growth over the last few years because as we've characterize the market, it's a healthy market, not an
componenttext: So before I let John respond more specifically about his view, the company's perspective has been that we have been seeing modest amounts of rental rate growth over the last few years because as we've characterize the market, it's a healthy market, not an accelerating market. So I think our perspective has been very constant over the last 3 or 4 of these call that the issues associated with the growth of rental rate and economics in the city is largely due to the amount of supply that is in the market from either relocations to the new building on the far west side or downtown and the retrenchment that occurred in 2013 and '14, those deals actually, starting to get completed. So as an example, Time move finally down to the World Financial Center and their building on 6th Avenue is now vacant and available to lease and they're doing a repositioning on it. Everyone knew that the building was going to be there and now it's in the market. So there are a number of those types of macro supplies that we've been watching and following and again, why we made our decision and has tempered our views on what would be going on in Manhattan in calendar year 2016 and '17? John, I don't know if you want to add anything to that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add to my previous comment. I said last August and September, the financial markets have had some -- a drop off and there were concerns. We have that now. It didn't moved to the leasing market last time. We don't know if whether it would move
componenttext: Let me just add to my previous comment. I said last August and September, the financial markets have had some -- a drop off and there were concerns. We have that now. It didn't moved to the leasing market last time. We don't know if whether it would move to the leasing market this time. It hasn't yet but obviously, if the financial markets continue to have problems and the economy has problems then that will affect everyone. But on the New York side, we don't see any change over the last few months in the leasing. I would say the only change that's really noteworthy and Doug has mentioned the supply for a number of times is the deal with the news that didn't get done at 2. So that's 2.8 million square-foot building that's not getting built downtown. So on the supply side, we understand that, that's the way out but we do look way out, let's say over the next 3 or 4 years. So certainly on the supply side, we don't need another 2 million square foot building on Sixth Avenue to come to the market in terms of the supply. So we're just moving along in New York. No big change yet but obviously, we're concerned like everyone is with the financial markets and what's happening globally and if that's going to happen a real impact on the leasing market in the coming months.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as far as your kind of non-core value add type of assets, are you expecting a repricing downward on those types of buildings in the city or elsewhere?
componenttext: And just as far as your kind of non-core value add type of assets, are you expecting a repricing downward on those types of buildings in the city or elsewhere?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we necessarily anticipate that. It certainly, could happen and I do think that market is stronger for core assets in gateway cities than it is as you go out the risk spectrum and real-time investment but we're not necessarily expecting a rep
componenttext: I don't think we necessarily anticipate that. It certainly, could happen and I do think that market is stronger for core assets in gateway cities than it is as you go out the risk spectrum and real-time investment but we're not necessarily expecting a repricing of those assets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're certainly, not getting any retrading on the deals that we're working on in New York.
componenttext: We're certainly, not getting any retrading on the deals that we're working on in New York.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just you mentioned the $200 million, $250 million of planned asset sales for 2016, just curious if the recent downdraft in share prices make you want to sell more aggressively than you're currently planning potentially or just how you're thinkin
componenttext: Okay. And just you mentioned the $200 million, $250 million of planned asset sales for 2016, just curious if the recent downdraft in share prices make you want to sell more aggressively than you're currently planning potentially or just how you're thinking about that??

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our asset sales said driven by selling non-core assets which we do every year. Innovation Place was probably the most recent example of that. And then, from time to time, we have opportunistically sold assets where we achieved what we thought was extraord
componenttext: Our asset sales said driven by selling non-core assets which we do every year. Innovation Place was probably the most recent example of that. And then, from time to time, we have opportunistically sold assets where we achieved what we thought was extraordinary pricing. This year, I mentioned an early prediction of asset sales in the $200 million to $250 million range. As I mentioned also, we've already done 7 Kendall Center which is a little over $100 million. So I don't -- we're not changing our disposition plan for this year based on current market conditions. We're basing it on our desire to continue to sell non-core assets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up at Owen on the disposition side. Last cycle  you guys sold some rather large CBD office buildings and this time, it's like that's not in the card. So just curious, is that simply because the CBD office towers that you own now have better
componenttext: Just following up at Owen on the disposition side. Last cycle  you guys sold some rather large CBD office buildings and this time, it's like that's not in the card. So just curious, is that simply because the CBD office towers that you own now have better growth profiles than the ones you sold last time or is it the fact that as submarkets have been buildup, you see less opportunity to get back to the submarkets you want to be?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, we sold a lot of very significant portfolio of assets this cycle. 2014 was the largest year of asset selling at Boston Properties. The total sales for this cycle I think are in excess of $3 billion. Remember the joint venture we did with on 4 assets
componenttext: Alex, we sold a lot of very significant portfolio of assets this cycle. 2014 was the largest year of asset selling at Boston Properties. The total sales for this cycle I think are in excess of $3 billion. Remember the joint venture we did with on 4 assets over 2 years, another significant asset that we sold. Also a large reason why we made a very special significant dividend that I described and also the reason that our current year is ballistic. So feel like that we've done very significant asset selling this cycle.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, from the perspective that last time you sold outright stakes, this time it's been a bit more on the JV. So I didn't know if that had an impact in sort of how you see the investment opportunity. That's what the question was going.
componenttext: I guess, from the perspective that last time you sold outright stakes, this time it's been a bit more on the JV. So I didn't know if that had an impact in sort of how you see the investment opportunity. That's what the question was going.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that we did sell 100% of several assets in the portfolio. I agree they weren't as large as the joint venture transactions that we did. I think the JVs were a function of the fact that the marketplace was very aggressive for the joint venture s
componenttext: No, I think that we did sell 100% of several assets in the portfolio. I agree they weren't as large as the joint venture transactions that we did. I think the JVs were a function of the fact that the marketplace was very aggressive for the joint venture structure which was attractive to us. And second, the assets that we have in joint venture, we do believe in and in many cases are improving and growing the cash flow. So it's a combination of both.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, on California, Doug, appreciate the comments on the tech leasing environment out there. It sounds like things are going pretty good but just from the perspective of from our standpoint, as we read news headlines while you spoke about Twitt
componenttext: Okay. And then, on California, Doug, appreciate the comments on the tech leasing environment out there. It sounds like things are going pretty good but just from the perspective of from our standpoint, as we read news headlines while you spoke about Twitter but Yahoo having issues of various tech tenants having issues. On the demand side, on the user side, is it basically as though the market, this is just normal tech volatility and this is always been part of the cycle or what would be the red flags that would indicate that some of the tech issues headline are more so than just normal expected volatility in business models?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're asking what's the canary in the coal mine, right? And I think that that's a really difficult question to answer with a specific fact that we'll look at and say, okay, now the market is going to go turn. I think that in the last 4 or 5 years, the ci
componenttext: You're asking what's the canary in the coal mine, right? And I think that that's a really difficult question to answer with a specific fact that we'll look at and say, okay, now the market is going to go turn. I think that in the last 4 or 5 years, the city of San Francisco has reshaped itself so dramatically in terms of the tenant demand that the diversity of companies and the strength of those companies is so different that I think that it will be much more difficult to sort of look at any 1 particular industry or any 1 particular company and say, okay, things have really changed. I mean, clearly, a overall GDP reduction and a series of layoffs from major technology companies would be the thing that I think would make it a clear cut type of a demarcation but again, we just don't see that. I mean, we see these large tech companies that have got pretty strong balance sheets and pretty global reaches now being able to weather the storm in a pretty significant manner and with business strategies that have a very long term focus associated with them. So there is no question that there is going to be failures in certain tech industries. All of the mobile payment companies are not going to survive. I mean  there are, in all likelihood, a couple of unicorns that are not going to make just because from an valuation -- from a capital spec the my perspective. But we spent a tremendous amount of time looking at the demand from the sort of startup community versus the "traditional now" and more fundamentally sound technology company and on a relative basis, the city of San Francisco is in a really good place. So Bob, I don't know if you have any other comments you want to make.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you covered it.
componenttext: No, I think you covered it.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you touch on each of your 4 major market? Do you think market trends actually go up this year and can vacancy sort of hold where they are or do you see any risk of market rent flattening going down, vacancy going up? Maybe some context around that? It
componenttext: Can you touch on each of your 4 major market? Do you think market trends actually go up this year and can vacancy sort of hold where they are or do you see any risk of market rent flattening going down, vacancy going up? Maybe some context around that? It sounds like you're pretty bullish around your opening comments but I was curious about how that translates to what you really see if the market rent [indiscernible] level.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would characterize the way we feel as we are cautiously optimistic that rents will marginally improve across our markets. Meaning that in markets like San Francisco, we believe we will continue to see modest increases of rent. I don't think we'r
componenttext: Yes, so I would characterize the way we feel as we are cautiously optimistic that rents will marginally improve across our markets. Meaning that in markets like San Francisco, we believe we will continue to see modest increases of rent. I don't think we're going to see spikes in the suburban Boston and the CBD of Boston, we're going to see good growth in rents, not spikes. In Midtown Manhattan, we think we're going to see pretty flat marginal growth in rents, a couple of percent depending upon the quality of the space and the location of space. In a market like Reston, I think we can push rents, 2% or 3% maybe up to 5% depending upon the space. In the city of Washington, D.C. it's going to be a pretty flat year. So I think we think it's a good market, not a spiking market.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, helpful. And then specifically, if I look at 250 West 55th and I look at the lease termination. Can you help us understand if there was almost 20 years left on the lease, why didn't you say to the tenant and I think we all know who it is, why didn't
componenttext: Okay, helpful. And then specifically, if I look at 250 West 55th and I look at the lease termination. Can you help us understand if there was almost 20 years left on the lease, why didn't you say to the tenant and I think we all know who it is, why didn't you say to the tenant, look, you signed a contract, pay us the rent and go sublease it. Why wasn't that an option?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm think -- I'm going to give you the quick and dirty answer and John can choose to add some color if he would like. I think that's the approach that we took and I think we got to a point where we felt that, the economics of the payment that the tenant w
componenttext: I'm think -- I'm going to give you the quick and dirty answer and John can choose to add some color if he would like. I think that's the approach that we took and I think we got to a point where we felt that, the economics of the payment that the tenant was making us more than justify the risk that we would be taking, reletting the space at a valuation that would provide us with a significant enhancement on a total NPV basis.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our math is you got about 5 years give or take worth of rent? That's about you can lease it in the next 5 years. Is that about, right?
componenttext: And our math is you got about 5 years give or take worth of rent? That's about you can lease it in the next 5 years. Is that about, right?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm not going to speak specifically to what the tenant is paying us, because I just don't think that's appropriate but the way we look at it was we have not yet given the tenant any money to build up their space. So that sort of helps money. And we bel
componenttext: So I'm not going to speak specifically to what the tenant is paying us, because I just don't think that's appropriate but the way we look at it was we have not yet given the tenant any money to build up their space. So that sort of helps money. And we believe that we would be able to relet the space in short order at market transactions and that we will come out significantly ahead versus what the payment that the tenant made.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. Doug, I guess, on the 250, I guess, I just want to kind of circle back. So before this termination, the building was kind of what percent leased or committed and just what kind of discussions may be had you had behind the
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. Doug, I guess, on the 250, I guess, I just want to kind of circle back. So before this termination, the building was kind of what percent leased or committed and just what kind of discussions may be had you had behind the scenes with existing tenants about possible expansion needs in the building?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think prior to this, we were 92% leased and we were leases outstanding for another floor, so another 3% or 4%. So we're basically 94%, 95%. I would expect that the space that we're getting back and remember, I said, there's some space on the ground floo
componenttext: I think prior to this, we were 92% leased and we were leases outstanding for another floor, so another 3% or 4%. So we're basically 94%, 95%. I would expect that the space that we're getting back and remember, I said, there's some space on the ground floor, that's retail and then there's space on the second floor and there's one high-rise tower floor that we will in all likelihood leave the high-rise tower floor to tenants outside the building, similar to the way we've been leasing out the 33rd, 34th, 35th floors. So there's going to 5,000 square feet, to 12,000 square feet to maybe a full floor. I don't believe that anybody in the building will take the second-floor and the retail will come from retailers who are obviously, looking to place their inflation [indiscernible].

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, going to Salesforce Tower, I mean it sounds like you're making a little bit of progress here and have some leasing done and it sounds house you've got other things on the pipeline. Just help us kind of mapped out over the next couple of quarters
componenttext: I guess, going to Salesforce Tower, I mean it sounds like you're making a little bit of progress here and have some leasing done and it sounds house you've got other things on the pipeline. Just help us kind of mapped out over the next couple of quarters kind of what goals you have, kind of where you want to be maybe by the middle of the year, end of the year as you kind of turned the corner into '17. What sort of the leasing progression look like as we now get into the strike zone of delivery?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so again just in the context the building is going to be available for tenants other than Salesforce in the latter half of 2017 and into early 2018, so I would expect that we now have done another 5 floors, knock on wood, that we get last thing on yo
componenttext: Yes, so again just in the context the building is going to be available for tenants other than Salesforce in the latter half of 2017 and into early 2018, so I would expect that we now have done another 5 floors, knock on wood, that we get last thing on your page. At least literally after the signature in the next couple of days. And so our expectation is there's another 200,000 to 300,000 square feet of leasing that we hope to get done during calendar year 2016. Obviously for rent commencement in early '17 or early '18. I think that would be our sort of base case goal and Bob, you can comment and you'll probably tell me you're going to have the whole thing lease before the end of the year but I'd moderate that prospective.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add that just this past week we had for 200,000 to 500,000 feet for a very well-known tenant in the marketplace. And this week, we also had 3 senior real estate heads from Wells Fargo, Google, Intel, all come for a presentation on the buildin
componenttext: I would just add that just this past week we had for 200,000 to 500,000 feet for a very well-known tenant in the marketplace. And this week, we also had 3 senior real estate heads from Wells Fargo, Google, Intel, all come for a presentation on the building which was better attended than we expected. So I mean, clearly people are looking at this building and I remain very optimistic that we're going to lease it quickly.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I guess, last question maybe for Doug and/or Owen. As you just think about some of the development projects that you talked about or future developments. I realized you guys generally have a relatively high hurdle for pre-leasing but just what a
componenttext: Okay, and I guess, last question maybe for Doug and/or Owen. As you just think about some of the development projects that you talked about or future developments. I realized you guys generally have a relatively high hurdle for pre-leasing but just what are the discussions like in some of those and if you had to handicap, how much you think you'd start this year maybe without naming specific projects. What do you think that looks like?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Steve, as you said, we do have a high bar for development. We have -- we talked about our target yields and we also like to see significant pre-leasing. I went through some of the projects in my remark. The most significant ones are the TSA requirem
componenttext: Well, Steve, as you said, we do have a high bar for development. We have -- we talked about our target yields and we also like to see significant pre-leasing. I went through some of the projects in my remark. The most significant ones are the TSA requirement at Springfield, which, I don't think we're prepared necessarily to handicapped certainly pursuing it. Ray had a comment on Reston and what the prospects look like for the Signature site that we're working on in Reston right now. Brian, I don't know if you want to spend a minute on City Point, talk about the prospects are for that. So Ray, can I turn it over to you?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Owen. Thanks. So Reston today is 100% leased and no new supply coming online even from us or from the competition. We feel exceedingly strong about -- this may come as a shocker but we're pushing those back. We think that there's 4 sizes. The buildi
componenttext: Sure, Owen. Thanks. So Reston today is 100% leased and no new supply coming online even from us or from the competition. We feel exceedingly strong about -- this may come as a shocker but we're pushing those back. We think that there's 4 sizes. The building size and the internal demand we have within the market can clearly justify it but we're in discussions with about 3 or 4 major existing tenants of ours who are expect interest anywhere between 80,000 and 150,000 square feet.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, you want to spend a minute on City Point?
componenttext: Brian, you want to spend a minute on City Point?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the quiet story about the strength of the Boston market is the wall in market in general. If you look at it, our competitive set is like 5% in terms of vacancy and despite 2, 3 points down from the previous year. So good supply-side look at the marke
componenttext: Yes, the quiet story about the strength of the Boston market is the wall in market in general. If you look at it, our competitive set is like 5% in terms of vacancy and despite 2, 3 points down from the previous year. So good supply-side look at the marketplace. Then on the demand side, Doug mentioned this earlier, we've got good life science activity. Many companies looking from migration out of Cambridge into this immediate suburb. And also, in the called cyber cloud tech segment of the marketplace, good growth. And Doug mentioned the strength of the larger companies and the concern about it, what we're seeing again is in a quiet way these midsized companies 50,000 feet growing to 70,000, 100,000 square feet with strong financial statements and strong products. So we're really encouraged about what's taking place. Just one last note is there is a strong appeal for the products that have the amenities that are lacking in the marketplace those being the restaurants, and that's what so attractive to clients at City Point.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes, in a lot of ways, [indiscernible] at the market because we just got to approval on it, so it's very recent in terms of its news and its opportunity but again, just to reiterate, Doug had mentioned, the strength and the number of people we're talking is significant in this market and Kendall remains very tame.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
