componenttext: So Steve, to summarize, the projects I think to keep an eye is are Kendall Center, Springfield Metro, City Point and the Signature site. We're all working hard on getting pre-let, so we could start this project.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from line of Brad Burke from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And your next question comes from line of Brad Burke from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up to the last question. Taking everything that you just said and summarizing it, should we think about the negative macro headline that we're seeing over the past few months of having had any impact on how you're thinking about the pace of
componenttext: Just a follow-up to the last question. Taking everything that you just said and summarizing it, should we think about the negative macro headline that we're seeing over the past few months of having had any impact on how you're thinking about the pace of magnitude of total new development starts over the course of 2016?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we are generally conservative in our approach to new development. I've described -- we talked about our yield target being 7% plus for office. We have a pre-letting requirement, which we also think helps mitigate risk in development. I would also
componenttext: I think we are generally conservative in our approach to new development. I've described -- we talked about our yield target being 7% plus for office. We have a pre-letting requirement, which we also think helps mitigate risk in development. I would also point out that our development pipeline is not static. We just announced the delivery of several projects of our pipeline, that's going to continue. So even if we had a few projects this year, it's likely our development pipeline may actually go down during the year. So, yes, we're paying attention. The macro headlines do matter but at the same time, if we have a project that we think pencils to an attractive yield to shareholders and we have risk mitigation through pre-leasing, we're going to launch it.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just an update on how you're thinking about the appropriate amount of liquidity and appropriate amount of leverage in the current environment and whether that's shifted at all over the past few months?
componenttext: Okay. And just an update on how you're thinking about the appropriate amount of liquidity and appropriate amount of leverage in the current environment and whether that's shifted at all over the past few months?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brett, I think that we have acted to bolster our liquidity additionally with the bond deal we just did. We've looked at our future debt maturities and we did the so we're kind of taking some of those maturities off the table now. We've got all the capital
componenttext: Brett, I think that we have acted to bolster our liquidity additionally with the bond deal we just did. We've looked at our future debt maturities and we did the so we're kind of taking some of those maturities off the table now. We've got all the capital raised to fund out our development pipeline, so we have are very, very liquid balance sheet and in a strong position. And from a leverage perspective, on a net-debt-to-EBITDA basis, we're somewhere in the high 5s. So that's down pretty significantly over the last 4 or 5 years. We expect that to continue, as I mentioned in my comments is our development pipeline will be coming online and we have already raised the money to do that and those developments are expected to generate strong yields. So I think that our capacity to do additional things is going to grow, so we think we're very, very well-positioned from both a liquidity perspective and a leverage perspective right now.

componenttext: It is a very unique space. It's almost a side beside core at the lower second level with the floor plate beam close to 50,000 feet. And the ceiling heights make it -- and large windows make it very unique space. We have the flexibility to use the second floor in creative ways. We can clearly use it for accessing to the lobby and use it for office space but we could also access it from 8th Avenue for some of the retail space and use it for different type of use, studios or other. So we'll be looking at all of that.

componenttext: So I'll give you the macro view. The macro view is we are in conversations with a number of tenants and we're optimistic that are perceived view of the value and the critical nature of that space for someone's brand will melt together and we're optimistic we're going to have a deal done sometime in 2016 or someone to use the space in 2017.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of John Guinee with Stifel.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of John Guinee with Stifel.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Few questions here. First, Ray, Richie, general dynamics of Washington business journal article a couple of weeks ago moving into you doing a suite for them on Sunset Road in I think it is in Reston. There's also an article that Northrop Grumman is spendi
componenttext: Few questions here. First, Ray, Richie, general dynamics of Washington business journal article a couple of weeks ago moving into you doing a suite for them on Sunset Road in I think it is in Reston. There's also an article that Northrop Grumman is spending over $300 million to buy versus lease space in the Baltimore Washington area. Do you have any sense as what the defense contractors out there whether there is a tendency to lease versus own and control their own space? And then, you've got to do this without talking to your book. What do you think are the better submarkets in D.C. as the defense contractors, security driven get back into the market and lease space?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's rather a long question. I'll give my best to make it as speed as possible. First of all, I can't comment on the specifics of the tenant coming or the purchaser coming to Reston. And there is a little bit movement towards owning the space. As
componenttext: Well, that's rather a long question. I'll give my best to make it as speed as possible. First of all, I can't comment on the specifics of the tenant coming or the purchaser coming to Reston. And there is a little bit movement towards owning the space. As you know the accounting change taking place in '18 will have an impact on many corporations on how they booked their occupancy costs. But I still think that the defense contractors want to have, given the uncertainty of the long-term government contracts, they still want to stay relatively short in the lease terms, so they're not held out with either a long-term lease obligations or the lack of liquidity by owning real estate. So I think the isolated examples, John, but I don't see a general trend. Relative to the market for cyber command, obviously, we're optimistic that Fort Meade will continue to pump out both contracts and result in jobs. The Dallas corridor still is very strong with the presence of major Intel activities out there, NRO and CIA. So we like our positions on both of those markets. I will say that corridor is relatively soft and I think that's more about the fact that now Tyson's with the silver line has opened up another market that those defense contractors can go to with better access and lower occupancy cost. So that still faces challenges but we're putting our money in the Dallas corridor score door and the Fort Meade market.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Doug, this is a question on lease economics and value creation versus just simply no value creation and being on a hamster wheel. What we've seen happen over the last 4 or 5 years has been an interesting situation where you've seen
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Doug, this is a question on lease economics and value creation versus just simply no value creation and being on a hamster wheel. What we've seen happen over the last 4 or 5 years has been an interesting situation where you've seen rental rates go up but you've also seen CapEx and releasing costs remain high essentially financing corporate America. Clearly, if you get a mark-to-market of 0 cash, 5 GAAP and $50 NTI, that ends the map there as value disruption. What do you need in terms of roll ups in order to justify the CapEx you're putting into these buildings to say to your shareholders we got value creation here?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're just making 1 sort of subtle argument that there's no real value to the cash flow from a building once the lease has been signed. That's different than the amortization of the transaction cost into that building and I guess, I would argue tha
componenttext: Well, you're just making 1 sort of subtle argument that there's no real value to the cash flow from a building once the lease has been signed. That's different than the amortization of the transaction cost into that building and I guess, I would argue that in many cases, the expectation proceeded with what these buildings will do in the future is an important component to how they're being valued and so while on a short-term basis, it may be true that in a particular building where our lease rolling at a "flat mark-to-market " and you're transaction costs on a net effective basis is slightly dilutive, if there's a perception and in many of those markets, there's a perception which is based upon reality that rental rates will grow over time, there is significant value that's likely embedded in that cash flow from that particular lease on a forward basis. So that's how you have to think about it. Now there are in fact cases where we don't have a view that there is going to be rental rate growth of any significance and as Owen suggested, those are buildings were we are sort of saying, "You know, leasing things up and selling these buildings might be the best course of valor here." And so we have done a number of those sort of modest pruning over the couple of years were in fact never agreed with you that there isn't really a lot of value to be attributed to doing additional leasing in this area.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, wonderful. And then Mike LaBelle, I realize taxable income doesn't line up with EPS exactly but your dividend run rate's about $0.65 per share or $2.60 a year. In 2014, your earnings per share was $3.72 and when you take your $2.60 standard dividend
componenttext: Okay, wonderful. And then Mike LaBelle, I realize taxable income doesn't line up with EPS exactly but your dividend run rate's about $0.65 per share or $2.60 a year. In 2014, your earnings per share was $3.72 and when you take your $2.60 standard dividend and your $1.25 special, it came out to $3.85 which is pretty close to your earnings per share for '14. Your 2015, earnings per share guidance is about $2.75 at the midpoint. What's that tell us about -- I'm sorry, I misspoke I meant 2015 and now 2016. Your 2016 earnings per share guidance was about $2.75 at the midpoint. What's that tell us about the future dividend policy?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As for your question, I think that -- as our development comes online and if we slow down our asset sales as Owen had mentioned, that's going to grow our [indiscernible]. And as our taxable income grows, we will want to keep up with our traditional divide
componenttext: As for your question, I think that -- as our development comes online and if we slow down our asset sales as Owen had mentioned, that's going to grow our [indiscernible]. And as our taxable income grows, we will want to keep up with our traditional dividend policy of dividending out 100% of our over taxable income, so you would expect the dividends would grow. Whether that occurs in 2016 or not, I can't tell you right now. What I can say is that at this point, we have not made any change to our dividend policy for this year. Obviously, in prior years, we have sold a tremendous amount of assets and we have delivered, I think it's $8 a share in special dividends in the last few years. And so we've lost income from those assets that we sold. We replaced it with development and we've elected to keep our dividend -- our regular dividend in line because we've been able to based on our taxable income. But we've got a sizable development pipeline that is going to be adding to our income in the next few years. So depending on what happens on asset sales, I would expect our taxable income is going to go up.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could share any surprises or any takeaways from your bond offering last month? If there was a widening disparity of investor appetite between A- and lower credits or any investor concerns on the office fundamental?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could share any surprises or any takeaways from your bond offering last month? If there was a widening disparity of investor appetite between A- and lower credits or any investor concerns on the office fundamental?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that our bond offering went very well. I think it went better than expected given the volatility that we were seeing in the market. We wanted to try to do something either in December or January, so we have been looking at the market for a w
componenttext: Look, I think that our bond offering went very well. I think it went better than expected given the volatility that we were seeing in the market. We wanted to try to do something either in December or January, so we have been looking at the market for a while and it's been pretty volatile throughout. The demand for a deal was over 4x what we expected the rates, so we were able to tighten in during the process and get to a level that we thought was a really good level and there's been other companies that are highly rated companies including a company yesterday, not in the REIT space that has been very, very successful. I think as you go down the risk spectrum and to lower investment grade and non-investment grade, the widening credit spreads in the last 30 days has been more significant than the 20 to 30 basis points that I mentioned for companies like ourselves.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to comment, so Mike has done a terrific job managing down our balance sheet and putting us in where I consider to be an enviable position relevant to our -- both our liquidity and our access to capital and he's done a really good job of workin
componenttext: I just want to comment, so Mike has done a terrific job managing down our balance sheet and putting us in where I consider to be an enviable position relevant to our -- both our liquidity and our access to capital and he's done a really good job of working with the bond investors to educate them on the principal foundations of how our business runs. And so we did our deal and I think we've traded 5 to 7 basis points wide in a period where the market is trading 30 basis points wide. So I think the reason that we are as successful as we were because the company in really in good stead with the bondholders and it's very satisfying and gives us a lot of comfort that going forward in 2016 and 2017, when as Mike spoke earlier, we do have additional maturities that were going to be in a pretty good place to access either the unsecured or secured markets at whatever the market pricing at the tightest level as possible.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The fixed income have a similar amount of concerns on tech slowdown and New York fundamentals or just less concern about the future?
componenttext: The fixed income have a similar amount of concerns on tech slowdown and New York fundamentals or just less concern about the future?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think they think about it in a significant way but I think they look at it closely the covenant structure of rebond and they look at the overall leverage ratio of our company and how we perform over the past decade as being an unsecure issuer and they g
componenttext: I think they think about it in a significant way but I think they look at it closely the covenant structure of rebond and they look at the overall leverage ratio of our company and how we perform over the past decade as being an unsecure issuer and they get very comfortable with the way we've managed our book of business.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Doug, on your answer to question earlier on market growth. Can you clarify if that was for asking rents or effective rent that you're saying?
componenttext: And Doug, on your answer to question earlier on market growth. Can you clarify if that was for asking rents or effective rent that you're saying?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm talking about gross phase rent.
componenttext: I'm talking about gross phase rent.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So they can see tightening in the markets. Do you see TIs decreasing?
componenttext: So they can see tightening in the markets. Do you see TIs decreasing?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the TIs have come down in some places and I think the TIs have basically stabilized in others. So as an example, I still think in San Francisco, if you're doing a 10 or 8, 15 year lease on a -- with a tenant that is going to be rebuilding spa
componenttext: I think that the TIs have come down in some places and I think the TIs have basically stabilized in others. So as an example, I still think in San Francisco, if you're doing a 10 or 8, 15 year lease on a -- with a tenant that is going to be rebuilding space, they are likely looking for a 70,000 plus square foot. By the way, the $70 a square foot is probably getting 60% of the way to what their cost are and it might be getting [indiscernible] 5 years ago because the cost of construction as well changes to the energy codes and other codes that are requiring them to do thing that they would not have to do was just simply increase the overall cost of occupancy. So I think from the tenants perspective interestingly, they actually see a diminution in the transaction cost in many of these deals. We are sort of at as a flatness.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line Rich Anderson from Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line Rich Anderson from Mizuho Securities.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I'll just ask 1 question, try to keep it short. Doug, you mentioned very early on in the comments about taking back small incremental space in New York and try to get in front of the supply pressures. Do you have a visibility into that pipeline? In other words, what amount of the space in New York do you think tends to signal an interest to either shrink or exit their space at some point in the future?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I'm going to let John answer that question. And interestingly, I think we had a presentation that we've done for a number of groups where we service have gone out and shown people what is ultimately anticipated coming out of the market over the next 2 years. And it's -- all of that is built into it. John, why don't you sort of describe the results?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, right now I can say that we don't have any discussions with any of our tenants about shrinking. That's probably as I can put it. We have done over the last couple of years, as you know, a number of law firm deals. Some of those law firms have taken
componenttext: Well, right now I can say that we don't have any discussions with any of our tenants about shrinking. That's probably as I can put it. We have done over the last couple of years, as you know, a number of law firm deals. Some of those law firms have taken the same amount of space because they're growing but they're more efficient in the space that they have. And other of those law firms have dropped significantly, sometimes by 15% or 20%. But right now, we don't see an tenants that are in the portfolio that we're talking to or for that matter, tenants that are looking from outside that are shrinking.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's the motivation to be taking this proactive step?
componenttext: What's the motivation to be taking this proactive step?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well different tenants have different motivations. We're talking to someone that 399 for a very large block of space that's  in 3 or 4 locations and they want to consolidate. That's an important motivation. We're talking to some tenants in the building th
componenttext: Well different tenants have different motivations. We're talking to someone that 399 for a very large block of space that's  in 3 or 4 locations and they want to consolidate. That's an important motivation. We're talking to some tenants in the building that have bought other companies that want to expand and want to consolidate everyone into 399. So it's always a specific business issue for the tenants that you're dealing with or the prospects that you're dealing with.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But let me just be a little more clear. So our decision to redo [indiscernible], Reed Smith, Kirkpatrick and Lockhart was a decision where we said, "Okay, there are a number of new buildings that are being built across the city and there are a number of b
componenttext: But let me just be a little more clear. So our decision to redo [indiscernible], Reed Smith, Kirkpatrick and Lockhart was a decision where we said, "Okay, there are a number of new buildings that are being built across the city and there are a number of buildings that are going to be vacated across the city when the tenants that are in them are moving to buildings that are currently vacated." And our tenants are a likely candidate for all of those future availabilities and we think we have the ability to help them get into more efficient space. Takes some case back in calendar year 2015 or 2016 or 2017 in a very modest way that can be both accretive to them in terms of being able to reduce their footprint prior to their expiration in 2019 or 2020 and give us an opportunity to lease space at rents that are better than what those current tenants are paying. And so it was the recognition that there were a number of competitive availabilities that our tenants were going to be looking at over the next few years and taking advantage of our attributes in terms of timing and ability to do things with them earlier that led us to go into those directions. And that space is available today and so we feel really good about all of those decisions.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Tom Catherwood from Cowen and Company.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on D.C. Obviously the 9% leasing spreads this quarter were the highest since 2011 but Doug, building off your comment, you expect rents to be flattish in 2016. Do you think the driver of those kind of moderating to no growth rents is more s
componenttext: Quick question on D.C. Obviously the 9% leasing spreads this quarter were the highest since 2011 but Doug, building off your comment, you expect rents to be flattish in 2016. Do you think the driver of those kind of moderating to no growth rents is more slower demand or is it an impact of kind of increased supply in the market?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ray, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Ray, do you want to take that?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a shot. The things we look at is not only the new construction that is new development taking place. What we're seeing in D.C. is a repositioning of older assets moving them from B- to A- and that level of supply is probably at an all-time hig
componenttext: Let me take a shot. The things we look at is not only the new construction that is new development taking place. What we're seeing in D.C. is a repositioning of older assets moving them from B- to A- and that level of supply is probably at an all-time high. That's why we're so aggressive and now talking to our tenants. We just renewed [indiscernible] with '17 expiration. We're talking to [indiscernible] with a 2020 exploration. We're trying to get our large existing tenants locked up because they are 3the targets of those new buildings coming online. And unlike the other 3 markets that we're in, D.C. is very much a lease expiration driven market. We don't have Salesforce coming in, taking 700,000 square feet as Bob enjoys in San Francisco. So our strategy is to get out with our existing tenants, lock them up and then aggressively go after other people's tenants to back our new developments. So I think to summarize this, it's much more about the increasing supply moderating any future growth in demand.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I appreciate that. And another one up in Cambridge. Obviously, the up-zoning of Kendall Square is a big deal. Do you have the per square foot value of that additional FAR that you guys received?
componenttext: Got it. I appreciate that. And another one up in Cambridge. Obviously, the up-zoning of Kendall Square is a big deal. Do you have the per square foot value of that additional FAR that you guys received?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't want to haphazardly give you an answer. I will just say that as follows, we have the ability in some places to build structure on top of parking areas and then in other times, there may be a requirement to remove a particular existing asset and
componenttext: I wouldn't want to haphazardly give you an answer. I will just say that as follows, we have the ability in some places to build structure on top of parking areas and then in other times, there may be a requirement to remove a particular existing asset and add density to it. So the mathematics associated with what the value is are really difficult to sort of describe with a number. I will tell you that we believe that we will be able to achieve rents in excess of that mid to high 60s on a triple net basis in current market conditions and over time, we think those rents are going to go up because there's such a lack of supply in that area and so we believe we will be able to profitably figure out how to use that density.

componenttext: Okay. And then just last one. Owen, you touched on earlier that you guys are looking at more value-add and development opportunities. Just more on the development side. Kind of how far out are you guys looking in terms of kind of opportunities for this cycle or next cycle and which markets perhaps outside the side would you guys be interested in adding additional sites for?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's opportunity driven. We're actively looking at new investment opportunities in all of our markets. We have on balance sheet today actually, a very significant pipeline of both entitled and unentitled land that we're going to continue to push through t
componenttext:
It's opportunity driven. We're actively looking at new investment opportunities in all of our markets. We have on balance sheet today actually, a very significant pipeline of both entitled and unentitled land that we're going to continue to push through the entitlement and permitting process. New projects at this stage, it depends. It could be for a future cycle. I suppose it's for prospects exist for this cycle probably less likely. I just want to add a couple of things to that last question. So we have interestingly, a shadow, shadow pipeline that we talked about before. So as an example, in Reston, Virginia, when light rail comes, we are going to get an up-zoning in density and Peter, you can describe what we're going to be getting there on the land that we own in our existing footprint. In Boston, we are in the midst of beginning our Back Bay train station up zoning entitlements for up to 1.75 million square feet of space. So there are projects like that that are more long-range than our 2017 starts and probably 2018 or '19 or '20 starts that are physically in the company's balance sheet right now and we just need to perfect them. And then we have buildings like Fort of Harrison where again we're in the permitting process for up to 900,000 square feet and likely probably be a little less than that but when Central eventually gets permitted and we're in a position to start rebuilding, it's a market where we're looking for things. We talked about Dock72 where we're hopefully will be under construction of the next few weeks were in the first building, we have a potential to do another 1 million square feet. So again  there's a really good embedded inventory of places in the company that we can add inventory over time. 
So I think that completes all the questions. Hopefully  we've been able to demonstrate to you the whole progress we've made on our plans. Thank you very much for your attention this morning.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night as well as furnished on Form 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconciled all no
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night as well as furnished on Form 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements. If you did not receive a copy, these documents are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.bostonproperties.com. 
An audio webcast of this call will be available for 12 months in the Investor Relations section of our website. At this time, we would like to inform you that certain statements made during this conference call which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although Boston Properties believes the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, it can give no assurance that its expectations will be attained. Factors and risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by forward-looking statements were detailed in Wednesday's press release and, from time to time, in the company's filings with the SEC. The company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. Having said that, I'd like to welcome Owen Thomas, Chief Executive Officer; Doug Linde, President; and Mike LaBelle, Chief Financial Officer. During the question-and-answer portion of our call, Ray Ritchey, Senior Executive Vice President and our regional management teams will be available to address any questions. I would now like to turn the call over to Owen Thomas for his formal remarks.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arista, and good morning, everyone. Our focus today, in addition to the quarter and market conditions, will be a review of 2015 and our outlook for 2016. On current results, we produced another solid quarter with FFO per share $0.01 above conse
componenttext:
Thank you, Arista, and good morning, everyone. Our focus today, in addition to the quarter and market conditions, will be a review of 2015 and our outlook for 2016. On current results, we produced another solid quarter with FFO per share $0.01 above consensus and $0.01 above our guidance after adjusting for the defeasance transaction. Based on recent leasing accomplishments as well as a significant lease termination we just completed for $45 million, we have also increased the midpoint of our full year 2016 FFO per share guidance by $0.26. We leased 1.4 million square feet in the fourth quarter and 5.2 million square feet for all of 2015 and our portfolio occupancy is now 91.4%. 
So moving to the operating environment. The U.S. economy continues to grow albeit at modest levels with full year 2016 GDP growth expected to be 2% to 2.5%. There was a modest slowdown in the fourth quarter of 2015 as GDP rose only 0.7%. The jobs picture remains healthy with 292,000 jobs created in December, 2.7 million jobs created in all of 2015, 2.5% wage growth for last year and 5% unemployment, albeit with lower workforce participation rates. Economic growth continues to be uneven with energy-related industrial sectors in recessions. Our markets that are driven by technology and life sciences are continuing to exhibit tightening leasing conditions. Office markets nationally are also firming. The data indicates that absorption was 17 million square feet for the fourth quarter and 46 million square feet for all of 2015. Vacancy ended the year at 13.8%, down 20 basis points for the fourth quarter and 50 basis points for the year and asking rents rose 4.7% with Boston and San Francisco experiencing the highest increases. Construction levels actually dropped in the fourth quarter to 2% of existing stock but are up 9% from a year ago. Financial markets have become very volatile in 2016 driven largely by concerns that weaker economic growth outside the U.S. and falling oil prices will have a negative impact on the U.S. economy. Most economic data indicates a continued slowdown in the Chinese economy. The domestic equity market in China is down over 20% year-to-date and fears of additional currency devaluation are pervasive. China has funded an estimated $600 billion of currency reserves over the last 6 months, supporting the remedy to its current trading level. Local regulators appear to be taking additional steps to stem capital flows out of China. Oil prices have also dropped nearly 50% from highs last year to approximately $33 a barrel. This has caused disruption in the industrial component of the U.S. economy and widening credit spreads for high-yield names particularly related to the energy sector. We are also monitoring with interest investment activity from oil based sovereign well funds as several Middle Eastern funds have reportedly been redeeming more liquid offshore investments in 2015. And lastly, despite the Federal Reserve raising short-term rates 25 basis points in December, the 10-year U.S. Treasury has dropped below 1.9% given all the global economic uncertainty mentioned. 
So what does all this mean for real estate, investment activity and valuation? Our instincts are that investment activity from some of oil based sovereign wealth funds should slow due to the decreasing inflows and capital needs at home and that flows from China will recede due to increasing capital control. However, there continue to be numerous large-scale office deals completed in gateway markets at attractive pricing. Recent examples included AXA; selling 787 Seventh Avenue to CalPERS and 1285 Sixth Avenue to RXR and Blackstone selling 4 assets in Westwood to Douglas Emmett as well as 500 Boylston St. and 222 Berkeley in Boston to Oxford and JPMorgan. All these deals were large and completed with North American led investors at cap rates in the mid-4% range or lower. Our REIT is capital values for high-quality assets are holding up, notwithstanding in some cases, fewer bidders and a somewhat geographic rotation of investor appetite. Further as a tailwind, long-term interest rates are low and dropping, while cap rates spreads to treasuries are above long-term averages and rising. Investment yields and cash flow stability from high-quality real estate assets will continue to be an attractive investment alternative to fixed income. Our capital strategy remains largely unchanged in that we are investing more in new developments versus acquisitions which will be funded partially by additional dispositions. On acquisitions, we continue to actively review new investments but do not anticipate significant investments in stabilized buildings given continued robust pricing. We are, however, seeing a pick up in value add and development opportunities in our core market. 
Moving to disposition. In the fourth quarter, we completed the sale of Innovation Place in San Jose for $207 million, including a gain of $79 million and a land parcel sale in Maryland for $13 million. Our total dispositions for 2015 were $584 million on an hour share basis which led to a special dividend of $1.25 per share, which brings our total special dividend paid since 2005 to over $21 per share. For 2016, we expect to continue to sell noncore assets and assets where we are able to achieve extraordinary pricing likely at levels below 2015. Our balance sheet is strong. We have already raised the cash to fund our significant capital needs and we see upside in many of our core assets through roll ups and redevelopment. We recently sold 7 Kendall Center to MIT for $105 million based on a pre-agreed option associated with MIT's tenancy in the building. We also placed under contract for sale our Reston Eastgate site to a corporate user who will retain us to build a corporate facility for their use, further enhancing the Reston area. Though difficult to estimate precisely at this time, we would expect $200 million to $250 million of total assets sales in 2016. 
Moving to development. Our activities remain robust. In the fourth quarter, we placed in service from our development pipeline, 535 Mission Street and 690 Folsom Street in San Francisco, the Point in the Waltham and Annapolis Junction in Annapolis, Maryland. In the aggregate, these projects cost $254 million and with the exception of Annapolis Junction, which is currently not leased, we delivered 98% occupied and an unleverage cash yield of 7.8% which is above our target. Also, in the fourth quarter, we added to our active development pipeline, The Hub on Causeway at North Station, which is the podium phase of our North Station development in Boston, where we have signed anchor deals for 60% of the 200,000 square-foot retail component and are negotiating 85,000 square feet of additional retail and office leases. North Station is a very significant mixed use development being built adjacent to one of Boston's busiest transit stations and the TD Garden. This project is a 50% partnership with Delaware North and will provide us with significant long-term profit opportunity. At year end, our development pipeline consisted of 11 projects representing 4.6 million square feet and $2.6 billion in project costs. Our budgeted NOI yield for these projects is in excess of 7%. The commercial component of the pipeline is 58% pre-leased. We have all the cash, $1.5 billion, required to complete the development of the portfolio, which should add materially to our company's growth over the next 4 years. 
Looking ahead into 2016 on development. We have numerous entitled projects and new starts will be highly dependent on pre-leasing activity. More specifically, we secured 940,000 square feet in additional entitlement from the city of Cambridge for Kendall Center and are in discussions with several tenants for pre-leasing a 360,000 square-foot office building. For Springfield Metro Center in Northern Virginia, we are pursuing a 600,000 square-foot requirement from the TSA. Again, predicated on substantial pre-leasing, other potential projects for this year are 20 CityPoint in Waltham, Mass. and Block 5 office in Reston. All these projects aggregate 1.5 million square feet. 
Lastly, we continue to devote time and resources to refurbishing our existing high-quality asset base. As Citibank vacates 399 Park Avenue in late 2017, we'll be completing upgrades to the facade entrance, roof decks and outdoor spaces. A redevelopment of the office and retail space in the low rise at 601 Lexington Avenue was also planned. We are also updating lobbies and common space at 1330 Connecticut Avenue and Metropolitan Square in Washington, D.C. to accommodate existing tenant renewals and attract new tenants. 
So in summary, we are very enthusiastic about our prospects for success and ability to create shareholder value in 2016 and beyond. We have a very clear plan to improve and lease our existing assets as well as add new buildings through development to our portfolio. All of which we expect to result in attractive FFO growth over the coming years. We have selected noncore assets for sale to ensure continued portfolio refreshment. We have significant entitled and unentitled land holdings that we will continue to push through the design and permitting process and add selectively to our development pipeline in future years. Our balance sheet is strong with net debt-to-EBITDA below 6x and with much of our upcoming debt maturities having now been either refinanced or hedged. This strong capital position will also allow us to pursue and act on investment opportunities that may present themselves in the coming quarter due to increasingly turbulent financial market conditions. Now over to Doug for a further review of our markets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. So it seems like everyday we seem to jump on this roller coaster of global volatility in the financial markets. But I do want to step back and just sort of take a little bit of a perspective here. So about 8 months a
componenttext:
Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. So it seems like everyday we seem to jump on this roller coaster of global volatility in the financial markets. But I do want to step back and just sort of take a little bit of a perspective here. So about 8 months ago, when we were in the NAREIT conference, I think almost every meeting we had was dominated by questions focused on signs of weakness in the tech markets, the lack of public IPOs, questionable valuations of unicorns, whether there was a looming shadow vacancy in our tech -- in our biotech markets due to potential slowing from venture capital sources and that all of this was sort of going to be precipitating a market correction. I think honestly that these are the same questions that we were asked in November and they're the same questions that are on everyone's mind today. They continue to be top of mind. So just take that perspective as I give my comments. You're going to recall that the way we've been characterizing the Bay Area real estate market is really one of, as I would refer to, healthy where the activity is really pretty similar to what it was in 2013, which was a really good year, but clearly off the spike that we saw in 2014. And I think the pace of activity that we're getting today is pretty similar to the same activity that we've been seeing in the back half of 2015 and it's pretty constant. And I just sort of want to supply some facts to back that up. So in the Northern Peninsula and the Valley, in the last quarter or so, Apple has expanded by another million square feet. Google has leased over 500,000 square feet and they've entered into additional building purchase agreements. Palo Alto Networks has expanded by 300,000 square feet. Facebook has taken on 200,000 square feet. As Owen said, we were the beneficiary of Broadcom's desire to expand and they purchased our 574,000 square feet at Innovation Center and have filed permits for the next phase of development, which is up to 537,000 square feet. And then on top of all that, there have been another 12 deals in the Valley for over 1.3 million square feet with blocks of space over 50,000 square feet. And we, in January, signed 88,000 square feet of renewals and expansions in our single-story Mountain View assets that's R&D property over $48 triple net rent. If you go to the city. Leasing activity in the city finished off 2015, clearly off of the 2014 level of high when Salesforce and Twitter and Dropbox all combined for over 1.4 million square feet, just those 3 tenants. But again, it was at the exact same level as we were in 2013. Tech demand continues to average around 50% of the volume in the city and there has been a pretty consistent volume of deals. Now recently, there's been continued attention to sublet space. Well, the Dropbox sublet, which was planned at China basin, it was all absorbed by Stripe and Lyft. There is some Twitter availability that was described in the mid-market area and it's all under lease negotiation. In fact, there's over 850,000 square feet of tech leasing that's expected to get done in the first quarter and it's almost entirely expansion led by Airbnb, which has taken an additional 150,000 square feet from the former Dolby building. The largest block of sublet space that was in our portfolio was a 5-floor block in EC3 coming back from the Morgan Lewis-Bingham merger that occurred a few years ago. We leased 4 of those 5 floors. Now there is some speculative construction in the city, 181 Fremont and 350 Bush and The Exchange are all under construction and they're adding about 1.4 million square feet of space. And Park Tower at Transbay is supposedly going to be -- sorry, it was another 750,000 square feet. But again, the overall vacancy rate in the city of San Francisco is under 6% and people continue to talk about the Prop M and issues there but the point is that after the FAR deposit in October, the bank was at about 1.75 million square feet. But if the First and Mission project, and 590 Brannan St. get approved, the bank will be empty. No additional supply availability. At Embarcadero Center, we completed another 220,000 square feet of office leasing during the quarter. Full floors totaled 162,000 square feet and new tenants moving into Embarcadero made up 145,000 square feet of that. During the third quarter, you may recall, and I'm going to refer to this a few times, we described our "revenue bridge" to get to the end of 2017 and I think one of the sell side analyst on our last call sort of asked, well, so how much of that's in the bag? Well, in Embarcadero Center, the larger deals that we completed last quarter, about 95,000 square feet, are going to add about 2.4 million square feet to that 2017 revenue versus '15. The new floor deals that we did this quarter, 145,000 square feet are going to add 4.4 million square feet. We have another 4 more floors close to being completed, another 89,000 square feet. Those floors a going to add 5.1 million square feet for a total of 12 million square feet of incremental growth from the Embarcadero Center. So -- $12 million of incremental growth from Embarcadero Center. The mark-to-market on these transactions is between 40% and 70% on a gross basis. And none of those transactions are in our same-store statistics for the quarter. In fact, there's only about 28,000 square feet of CBD deals in the San Francisco region in that same store data in our supplemental. Traditional FIRE [ph] demand continues to be very strong at Embarcadero Center and across the city. At 535 Mission, we're now 99% leased. So this is the last time you're going to be hearing about that project for quite some time. We've completed 51,000 square feet of leases. Average gross rent of about $80 a square foot. The building should be fully contributing by the third quarter of '16, cash return 7.8%, 150 basis points greater than our pro forma. I had hoped to announce that we had signed leases for additional 5 floors at Salesforce Tower, 108,000 square feet, bringing us to 821,000 square feet of leasing of that 1.4 million square-foot building or 59%. While 2 of the leases are back for 2 of those floors but the remainder is yet to come in and we expect to see it hopefully by this Friday. So we're going to have 108,000 square feet of leasing done. We're adding venture capital and management consulting clients as industries being represented in the building. We still have active single and multi floor discussions going on with asset managers and hedge funds and more VCs, law firms, consulting firms, real estate brokerage firms and other nontech service firms that encompass another 300,000-plus square feet of space. Activity continues to be really strong at Salesforce Tower. And most of these requirements are lease expiration driven occupancy -- tenants that are recognizing the value and excitement about the Salesforce Tower and wanting to be there. So again, in summary, activity across the California portfolio, our Bay Area portfolio continues to be very strong. 
Let's jump over to Manhattan Midtown. Again, not much has changed on our activity and expectations for the Midtown market. Our tone has been pretty consistent for the last 24 months, somewhat subdued. When we made the strategic decision to get in front of our many pending lease expirations due to the large block future availability, the supply in the market. And our view that providing early release in the form of taking back some space in small increments will be the best interest of both us and our customers. Well, during this quarter, we completed another 11 deals, 120,000 square feet. 8 of them had starting rents above $90 a square foot and 6 were above $100 a square foot. Compared to the last quarter, where we did 12 deals, 90,000 were over -- square feet -- in 10 deals over $90 a square foot and 7 deals over $100 a square foot. Now it's clear that during periods of high stock and credit market volatility, many things do, in fact, distract the high end users. And while some of the active tenants are probably elongating their decision-making process, they continue to look for space and sublet space in Midtown is at an 8 year low. In 2014, there were 570,000 square feet of leases done with starting rents between $90 and $99 a square foot. In 2015, there was more than 1.2 million. For deals over $100 a square foot, there was over 1 million square feet in 2015. The reason I talk about this is because the bulk of our availability and rollover in our portfolio in the next few years occurred in spaces with -- that command rents in excess of $90 or $100 a square foot. Now transaction size continues to be small, with the preponderance of the activity under 20,000 square feet for nonrenewal, which is the reason we have, again strategically, decided to cut up the remaining floors that we have at 250 West 55th Street and we have leases out for all of our remaining prebuilt suites and we have signed half of our deals on the 2 of the 3 available floors that we have. We have signed leases now for 242,000 square feet with incremental gross revenues of $18 million that will be contributing in 2017, another component of our bridge. We signed a termination agreement last night with a tenant that leased 85,000 square feet in a combination of 1 high-rise floor, the second floor and a portion of the ground level space at 250 West 55th Street. While working with the tenant on a transaction that would allow them to minimize their future obligations while recognizing both the cost and the time associated with finding a replacement tenant, the parties agreed to a onetime payment and a transfer of the responsibility of retenanting the building to Boston Properties. That space was never built out and we never provided TI. 
Switching over to 399. As Owen said, we've unveiled our plan for the upgrade, including the addition of outdoor terraces in our "Oasis in the Sky", as we position the building to relet 640,000 square feet of 2017 expirations. Those are late '17 expirations. We are in lease negotiations now on 200,000 square feet of that space and we completed our first full floor deal in the mid-rise where we are pricing the space with starting rents around $115 a square foot. There are a number of medium-sized financial institutions with 2018 and '19 expirations that really value to be more affordable, low-rise large block space, we have those 165,000 -- 100,000 square-foot floors and 55,000 square-foot floors but with connectivity to our slightly more expensive space in the mid-rise. 
Going down to Washington, D.C. 2/3 of our activity this quarter in the Washington area was in Northern Virginia where we completed 128,000 square feet of leases with a GSA, renewal at our VA95 project and also some GA -- GSA contract dependent-expansions that are Kingstowne projects. Then we also did 10 small transactions in Reston Town Center. In January, we completed a 60,000 square-foot renewal at the Town Center with starting rents of over $54 a square foot. And again, if you compare that to the Toll Road, where rents are on average $33 to $35 a square foot, the premium from Reston continues to show. Reston is 97% leased. Our signature residential project is under construction and we are in lease negotiations for 80% of the 25,000 square feet of retail that's associated with that project. And if our leasing team follows its typical pattern given the lack of blocks of space and the continued demand in Reston, we should have a lead tenant for the 275,000 square foot signature office development sometime in 2016. In CBD of D.C., we completed our second office lease at 601 Mass Ave. and we have pretty good activity on the remaining 47,000 square feet. Our largest availability is going to be at Metropolitan Square where we have 120,000 square-foot tenant expiring at the end of first quarter. We are in active discussions on more than 110,000 square feet of that upcoming availability. Our view is that the overall market conditions in D.C. really haven't changed much. On the margin, there's probably a little bit more GSA related leasing that's anticipated for 2016, but it's probably going to have some economic limits that will push it a little bit further out of the CBD in the east end. The district continues to be very competitive. 
The majority of our Boston activity during the quarter was in suburban Waltham and Lexington. The Waltham Metro West Market, a "suburban market" continues to get stronger driven by organic expansion. This quarter, we did 16 leases in our suburban portfolio for 413,000 square feet and we have another 200,000 under active negotiation. Rents have increased 25% over the last 18 months. Delivery of the Waltham development is on target, August for 10 CityPoint, October for 1265 Main. Both projects come into service 100% leased. In January, the city of Boston learned that General Electric had chosen to move its corporate headquarters to the city. It's expected to bring about 800 jobs, but that's really not what the issue is. What it really speaks to is the overall economic ecosystem of the area. This region continues to be a magnet for both the life science industry, established technology companies as well as startup tech and maker organizations. This has led to continual improvement in business growth in the greater Boston area. The East Cambridge office and lab market is probably the largest beneficiary of growth and that has the best economic of any market that we're in. With 6.5 million square feet of office space and just under 8 million of lab space, direct vacancy is under 4%. Office rents continue to achieve new peaks with the most recent transactions being completed on the office space at over $65 triple net with annual increases. Tenant improvement allowances have been reduced and are not below $60 a square foot. As Owen mentioned, we finished out the year with an up-zoning of our Kendall Square development that's going to allow for the eventual development of 540,000 square feet of commercial office and 400,000 square feet of residential, including 80,000 up for sale. We're having substantive conversations right now with a number of existing tenants that are searching for growth and looking for that office space. The other news for our Cambridge portfolio is the recent decision of Microsoft to relocate a group that it has at 255 Main Street to the suburbs over the next 24 months. This is likely going to mean that we will have an opportunity to lease 125,000 square feet of space that is not going to be expiring until 2021. With the Volpe site RFP expected to be issued in May and the zoning application still in process, we would expect more Cambridge tenants with near-term space needs to be likely exploring suburban Waltham and Lexington and the Boston CBD because there's simply no place to go in the city of Cambridge right now. The Boston CBD continues to be a good market as supply has been absorbed over the last few years, though there is some speculative development the seaport of some modest-sized building. Again, GE has not landed on where its new home is going to be and it could take existing inventory or go to a new development. At 120 St. James, where we have 170,000 square feet of availability, there are now a number of tenants reviewing our options at the building and they range from 32,000 square feet of single floor up to the entire 170,000 square-foot block. 
At 200 Clarendon, we're in lease negotiations with tenants that would fill another floor in the high rise, and leave us with 90,000 square feet on floors 45, 46 and 47. High end demand in Boston has typically been for users under 30,000 square feet and we expect to lease the space in smaller increments. We have completed our multi-tenant transaction at 100 Federal Street where Putnam has signed a lease for 250,000 square feet, Wellington has executed a long-term renewal and relocation on 156,000 square feet its current using and BofA has been able to realize some space and rent savings by reducing its footprint by 137,000 square feet. All of the available space at 100 Federal Street has now been spoken for. Again, as you think about our bridge to 2017, these transactions at 100 Federal Street contribute approximately $6 million of incremental revenue. So last fall, we outlined $80 million of incremental revenue from our existing portfolio that we hope to have in place by the end of '17. Given all the transactions I've described, we now have commitments for approximately $36 million of that $80 million. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I'm going to start out with a few comments on what we're seeing on the debt markets. As you know, we've defeased our $640 million mortgage loan on 200 Clarendon Street in December. That resulted in a $0.13 per share char
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I'm going to start out with a few comments on what we're seeing on the debt markets. As you know, we've defeased our $640 million mortgage loan on 200 Clarendon Street in December. That resulted in a $0.13 per share charge for our fourth quarter earnings. To replenish our cash, we closed on $1 billion 10-year bond deal at an all in-yield of 3.77%. The excess funds will be used to repay our $211 million mortgage on Fountain Square, that is open for prepayment at par in April as well as fund our future development costs. We've reduced the cash interest rate by 200 basis points with this bond deal versus the expiring loan and the annual cash interest savings will be $11.5 million even though we borrowed an additional $150 million of proceeds. On a GAAP basis, the interest rate reduction is 75 basis points as both of the refinance loans were above market at acquisition, so they have a noncash fair value interest component that is amortized into and reduces GAAP interest expense. Clearly, the market volatility that Owen described is having an impact on the credit market. It's driving credit spreads wider particularly as you move out the risk spectrum. The bond market continue to operate efficiently though, and high-quality issuers like ourselves have access, albeit, at spreads that are 20 to 30 basis points wider than the 155 basis point spread that we issued in early January. Though there are frequently days when the global volatility does necessitate patience. With the rally and the tenure below 2%, all-in borrowing costs really haven't moved much for us. The mortgage markets have been a little more fickle with CMBS spreads widening more significantly, especially in the conduit world and for single asset deals that are in secondary markets are not fully stabilized. For high-quality stabilized properties in strong locations, the markets remain active with both life companies and CMBS issuers actively putting out mortgage money with 50% to 60% leverage loans pricing in the 4% area for 10 years. The banks are also increasingly active in financing 5 to 7 year term loans on a floating rate basis at competitive spreads. So although we see some volatility, good quality assets like ours continue to be able to secure attractively priced long-term financing. With the most active buyers for our asset class looking to employ lower leverage, the financing markets remain favorable. 
I also want to note that over the past 3 years, our asset sales strategy and the delivery of development properties at superior yields has translated into a reduction in our leverage position. As our new deliveries stabilize, we expect these ratios will continue to improve and create additional investment capacity on our balance sheet. I just want to quickly touch on our earnings for the quarter. We reported funds from operation of $1.28 per share. After adjusting for the defeasance charge, we came in at $0.01 ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range, which was related to better performance in the portfolio. 
Operating expenses came in better than budgeted, while our revenues are pretty tightly aligned with our expectations. For 2016, we are increasing our NOI projections from our in-service portfolio. As Doug detailed, we continue to see good leasing activity, particularly in San Francisco and in Boston. 
In Boston, we closed the Putnam lease. And although it will not impact earnings until 2017, the transaction included a relocation and long-term extension with Wellington with future rent bumps that will be straight-lined into 2016. We're also seeing increased activity on our vacancy, both in the high-rise space at 200 Clarendon Street and at the Prudential Tower where we could see additional income from it later this year. 
At Embarcadero Center in San Francisco, we continue to be successful in completing a number of lease renewals with significant rental rate increases and have activity on our availability. If these renewals are signed, our GAAP income reflects the straight-line impact of the rental rate increases, though the cash impact will not occur until the future renewal date, which is, in most cases, later in 2016 or in 2017. 
As Doug mentioned, we terminated an 85,000-square-foot lease at 250 West 55th Street and received a significant termination payment of $45 million. Also at 601 Lexington Avenue, we are finalizing a termination with a tenant in the high-rise, which will enable Citibank to relocate out of the low-rise office building, so it can be vacated for repositioning. 
Overall, we expect our 2016 termination income to be approximately $47.5 million higher than our guidance last quarter. These lease terminations will result in lower future rental income until such time as we find replacement tenants. The lost income is projected to be approximately $11 million in 2016. Given it's lumpy nature, our practice is to exclude termination income from our same-property NOI guidance, but it does have an impact. The leasing success that we are executing exceeded our expectations and would have improved our GAAP same-store NOI growth projection by about 50 basis points. However, the loss rental income related to our decision to enter into lease termination has more than offset this growth. The net impact on our GAAP same-store property NOI projection is a decrease of approximately 25 basis points from our guidance last quarter. The loss termination -- income from termination also impacts our cash same-property NOI, though we still project growth of 1% to 3% over 2015. As a reminder, our same-property growth is weighed down by rollover at 767 Fifth Avenue and at 601 Lexington Avenue. Both of these are consolidated joint venture properties. The growth in our share of same-property NOI is approximately 100 basis points higher for both GAAP and cash. 
We project our noncash straight-line rental income to be $35 million to $50 million in 2016, which is higher than our projection last quarter. The completion of our bond deal takes care of a $1 billion of our near-term debt maturities. We now have $2.9 billion of consolidated debt expiring over the next 2 years, of which $2.3 billion represents our share. These loans carry a cash interest rate of 5.9% and a GAAP interest rate of 4.4%. We have hedged the 10-year swap rate on a $1 billion of the expected refinancing. The only material financing activity in our 2016 projections is the refinancing of our $350 million mortgage loan on Embarcadero Center 4 in the fourth quarter. This loan has a cash interest rate of 6.1% and a GAAP interest rate of 7%. So our interest expense run rate should be lower at the end of the year. 
Overall, we project our 2016 full year interest expense to be $400 million to $450 million, which is net of capitalized interest of $40 million to $50 million. The impact of these changes results in our increasing our guidance range for 2016 funds from operation to $5.78 to $5.93 per share. This is an increase of $0.26 per share at the midpoint, which consists of $0.21 per share from the net impact of tenant termination and $0.05 per share from better projected performance in our same-property portfolio. 
That completes our formal remarks. Operator, if you could turn the call over to questions, that would be great. Thanks.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is called "no good deed goes unpunished", right? So I think, let's say, they're -- the 3 largest components that are likely to be talked about over the next few quarters are at the 200 Clarendon Street and 120 St. James, which is the building in Bost
componenttext: This is called "no good deed goes unpunished", right? So I think, let's say, they're -- the 3 largest components that are likely to be talked about over the next few quarters are at the 200 Clarendon Street and 120 St. James, which is the building in Boston; the additional lease-up at the Prudential Center, which is about 90,000 square feet of space; and the changes that we're going to be going through at 767 General Motors Building, which are both the retail space at the base and the 2 floors that we're getting back in July. Those -- that's where the bulk of that is coming from. And the -- I think the prognosis is positive, and we're working forward on transaction on all stuff. But I mean, it may be a quarter, it may be 3 quarters before we announced those transactions are completed.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you commented on some of the higher-end tenants, particularly in New York City, maybe taking longer to make decisions, given stock market volatility. Can you just provide more color on exactly what you're seeing and whether things are getting de
componenttext: Okay. And you commented on some of the higher-end tenants, particularly in New York City, maybe taking longer to make decisions, given stock market volatility. Can you just provide more color on exactly what you're seeing and whether things are getting delayed?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I said, I think the overall tenor of the market, and I'm going to let John Powers comment, is -- has been that things have just taken a little bit longer but the activity remains the same. So as an example, when I look at our portfolio of tenants lo
componenttext: So as I said, I think the overall tenor of the market, and I'm going to let John Powers comment, is -- has been that things have just taken a little bit longer but the activity remains the same. So as an example, when I look at our portfolio of tenants looking at the space of the General Motors Building on the 34th and 35th floors, we've got 3 or 4 tenants that are actively interested in pieces of those floors. I think that there are days when there's more focus on looking at their screens than they are looking at office space, so I think it's just a longer [ph] decision-making process. And John, you want to make any additional comments?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I would add is that we finished last year with a very good leasing year, very good leasing velocity year. I'm talking about Manhattan overall. It was down 6% from 2014, but then again, it was 6% higher than the last 5 years. During the year,
componenttext: I guess, what I would add is that we finished last year with a very good leasing year, very good leasing velocity year. I'm talking about Manhattan overall. It was down 6% from 2014, but then again, it was 6% higher than the last 5 years. During the year, we had issues in August, in September, as Owen and Doug said, and we had spread widely as Mike talked about, and that never moved into the leasing market. It might have won a few deals, slowing things down a little. So right now, we have the same kind of activity in the financial markets and people are looking at it, but a lot of large tenants are planning for significant period of time and are not -- are continuing with what with they do. Some of the smaller tenants in the smaller deals, I think, look more closely at the screens than the larger organizations do.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Emmanuel Korchman with Citi.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Emmanuel Korchman with Citi.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe Mike or Doug, if we think about the $80 million of NOI uplift that we all keep talking about, how much of that is going to actually impact '17 numbers? And how much of that is, you thinking about that $80 million, is sort of a run rate going into '1
componenttext: Maybe Mike or Doug, if we think about the $80 million of NOI uplift that we all keep talking about, how much of that is going to actually impact '17 numbers? And how much of that is, you thinking about that $80 million, is sort of a run rate going into '18?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wish I could give you an honest answer because I -- the timing is what really is going to drive that. I can tell you that much of it will start to bleed in, in latter parts of '16 and much of it will bleed in over '17. So there's no question that by the
componenttext: I wish I could give you an honest answer because I -- the timing is what really is going to drive that. I can tell you that much of it will start to bleed in, in latter parts of '16 and much of it will bleed in over '17. So there's no question that by the end of '17, we'll have all of it in our estimations right now. I can't tell you if it's 60% in the first quarter of '17 or 80% in the first quarter of '17. A lot of it's just going to be dependent upon the physical characteristic of the space and when we can start recognizing revenue.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it's fair to assume that some majority portion will be a '17 impact, and then there will be bleed-over -- or -- and then there'll be a bleed-over that impacts '18 specifically?
componenttext: But it's fair to assume that some majority portion will be a '17 impact, and then there will be bleed-over -- or -- and then there'll be a bleed-over that impacts '18 specifically?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the fact is that a lot of it is going to be coming in, in very bulky manner in 2017, not all on January 1, 2017, but over each quarter. But by the fourth quarter, it will all be there. But I -- again, a significant piece of it's going to be i
componenttext: Yes, I think the fact is that a lot of it is going to be coming in, in very bulky manner in 2017, not all on January 1, 2017, but over each quarter. But by the fourth quarter, it will all be there. But I -- again, a significant piece of it's going to be in before then.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
