headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I am -- that was a -- I think the question that we had last quarter as well and it's an interesting question. So the existing incumbent tenants at Embarcadero Center, we have one tenant that we're talking to at Embarcadero Center that is likely to leave a
componenttext: I am -- that was a -- I think the question that we had last quarter as well and it's an interesting question. So the existing incumbent tenants at Embarcadero Center, we have one tenant that we're talking to at Embarcadero Center that is likely to leave and move to Salesforce. There are some tenants that are looking at both Embarcadero Center and Salesforce that are not tenants on our portfolio right now.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to go back to your comments earlier on the investment markets. Feeling like there's going to be a little bit of a pullback from the oil-based economies in China, which makes some sense. But you also mentioned other geographies picking up, and I
componenttext: Just want to go back to your comments earlier on the investment markets. Feeling like there's going to be a little bit of a pullback from the oil-based economies in China, which makes some sense. But you also mentioned other geographies picking up, and I guess, on net, do you think those other geographies will be able to offset the lost inflows from those other 2 segments? And curious if that's more based on your expectations, or have you started to see that unfolding in the markets already?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we have seen it unfolding in the markets over the last couple of quarters. I cited $3 billion plus, $4 billion plus, actually, deals in high-quality office space, high-quality office deals in gateway markets that went to North American-led in
componenttext: I think that we have seen it unfolding in the markets over the last couple of quarters. I cited $3 billion plus, $4 billion plus, actually, deals in high-quality office space, high-quality office deals in gateway markets that went to North American-led investment groups, so either U.S. pension funds, other U.S. investors or Canadian investors. So I think that there is a bit of a geographic rotation, but to -- thus far, the -- certainly, U.S. investors, Canadian investors. We're increasingly seeing Japanese investors in the marketplace. Investors from Asia outside of China, there are other groups that are in the marketplace and, so far, have led to a lack of reduction in pricing at least to date.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the flip side of that, you also mentioned seeing more opportunities on the value-add side of things, and I was just curious if you could provide more color on exactly what's driving that. Is there -- are there more projects coming t
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the flip side of that, you also mentioned seeing more opportunities on the value-add side of things, and I was just curious if you could provide more color on exactly what's driving that. Is there -- are there more projects coming to market? Are the traditional buyers pulling back, a combination of those and have cap rates moved significantly in that space?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the value add, I think we have mentioned for many quarters prior to this and also in this quarter, we're focusing on new investments where we can use our real estate talent. So that would be either new development or redevelopment of existing assets
componenttext: So on the value add, I think we have mentioned for many quarters prior to this and also in this quarter, we're focusing on new investments where we can use our real estate talent. So that would be either new development or redevelopment of existing assets. And I do think right now, we have a fairly robust pipeline of things that we're looking at in both of those categories and most of our core markets. These are areas where many of the sovereign wealth funds and offshore investors, you know it's not 100% the case, but they're less active. And yes, that's helpful to us.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Jed Reagan with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Jed Reagan with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: There were some concerns put out there last week that New York City job and rent growth is likely to soften this year and then non-core asset values in the city will -- might be repriced lower. Are you expecting those kind of changes yourselves? And do yo
componenttext: There were some concerns put out there last week that New York City job and rent growth is likely to soften this year and then non-core asset values in the city will -- might be repriced lower. Are you expecting those kind of changes yourselves? And do you think this could affect some other markets in your portfolio?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- look, Jed, just before I let John respond more specifically about his views, the company's perspective has been that we've been seeing modest amounts of rental rate growth over the last few years because as we've characterized the market, it's a hea
componenttext: So -- look, Jed, just before I let John respond more specifically about his views, the company's perspective has been that we've been seeing modest amounts of rental rate growth over the last few years because as we've characterized the market, it's a healthy market, not an accelerating market. And so our -- I think our perspective has been very constant over the last 3 or 4 of these calls about the issues associated with the growth of rental rate and economics in the city is largely due to the amount of supply that is in the market from either relocations to the new building on the far-west side or downtown and the retrenchment that occurred in 2013 and '14, those deals actually starting to get completed. So as an example, Time-Life moved finally down to the World Financial Center. And their building on 6th Avenue is now vacant and available to lease, and they're doing a repositioning on it. Everyone knew that the building was going to be there but it's now in the market. So there are a number of those types of macro supply issues that we've been watching and following and, again, why we made our decisions and have tempered our views on what would be going on in Manhattan in calendar year 2016 and '17. And John, I don't know if you want to add anything to that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just add to my previous comment. I said last August and September, the financial markets had some -- a drop-off and there were concerns. And we have that now. It didn't move to the leasing market last time. We don't know whether it would move
componenttext: Well, let me just add to my previous comment. I said last August and September, the financial markets had some -- a drop-off and there were concerns. And we have that now. It didn't move to the leasing market last time. We don't know whether it would move to the leasing market this time. It hasn't yet. But obviously, if the financial markets continue to have problems and the economy has problems, then that will affect everyone. But in the New York side, we don't see any change over the last few months in the leasing. I would say the only change that's really noteworthy, and Doug has mentioned the supply for a number of times, is the deal with the news didn't get done at 2. So that's a 2.8 million-square-foot building that's not getting built downtown. So on the supply side, we understand that, that's way out but we do look way out, let's say, over the next 3 or 4 years. So certainly, that's -- on the supply side, we don't need another 2 million-square-foot building on Sixth Avenue to come in the market in terms of the supply. So we're just moving along in New York. No big change yet, but obviously, we're concerned like everyone is with the financial markets and what's happening globally and if that's going to have a real impact on the leasing market in the coming months.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as far as the -- your kind of non-core, value-add type of assets, are you expecting a repricing downward on those type of buildings in the city or elsewhere?
componenttext: And then just as far as the -- your kind of non-core, value-add type of assets, are you expecting a repricing downward on those type of buildings in the city or elsewhere?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we necessarily anticipate that. It certainly, could happen. I do think the market is stronger for core assets in gateway cities than it is as you go out the risk spectrum in real estate investment, but we're not necessarily expecting a repri
componenttext: I don't think we necessarily anticipate that. It certainly, could happen. I do think the market is stronger for core assets in gateway cities than it is as you go out the risk spectrum in real estate investment, but we're not necessarily expecting a repricing of those assets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're certainly not getting any retrading on deals that we're working on in New York.
componenttext: We're certainly not getting any retrading on deals that we're working on in New York.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just you mentioned the $200 million, $250 million of planned asset sales for 2016, just curious if the recent downdraft in share prices make you want to sell more aggressively than you're currently planning potentially. Or just how you're t
componenttext: Okay. And then just you mentioned the $200 million, $250 million of planned asset sales for 2016, just curious if the recent downdraft in share prices make you want to sell more aggressively than you're currently planning potentially. Or just how you're thinking about that?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our asset sales are driven by selling non-core assets, which we do every year. Innovation Place was the -- probably the most recent example of that. And then, from time to time, we have opportunistically sold assets where we achieved what we thought was e
componenttext: Our asset sales are driven by selling non-core assets, which we do every year. Innovation Place was the -- probably the most recent example of that. And then, from time to time, we have opportunistically sold assets where we achieved what we thought was extraordinary pricing. This year, I mentioned a -- an early prediction or -- of asset sales in the $200 million to $250 million range. As I mentioned also, we've already done 7 Kendall Center, which is a little over $100 million. So I don't -- we're not changing our disposition plan for this year based on current market conditions. We're basing it on our desire to continue to sell non-core assets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up at, Owen, on the disposition side, last cycle, you guys sold some rather large CBD office buildings, and this time, it sounds like that's not in the cards. So just curious, is that simply because the CBD office towers that you own now ha
componenttext: Just following up at, Owen, on the disposition side, last cycle, you guys sold some rather large CBD office buildings, and this time, it sounds like that's not in the cards. So just curious, is that simply because the CBD office towers that you own now have better growth profiles than the ones you sold last time? Or is it the fact that as submarkets have been built up, you see less opportunity to get back into the submarkets where you want to be?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, we've sold a lot of very significant portfolio of assets this cycle. 2014 was the largest year of asset selling in Boston -- at Boston Properties. The total sales for this cycle, I think, are in excess of 2 -- $3 billion. Remember, the joint venture
componenttext: Alex, we've sold a lot of very significant portfolio of assets this cycle. 2014 was the largest year of asset selling in Boston -- at Boston Properties. The total sales for this cycle, I think, are in excess of 2 -- $3 billion. Remember, the joint venture we did with Norges on 4 assets over 2 years, another significant asset that we sold. It's a -- also a large reason why we've made the very significant special dividends that I described and also the reason that our current gearing is ballistic. So we feel like we've done very significant asset selling this cycle.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I guess, Owen, from the perspective that last time you sold outright stakes, this time, it's been a bit more on the JV. So I didn't know if that had an impact in sort of how you see the reinvestment opportunity. That's where the question was going.
componenttext: But I guess, Owen, from the perspective that last time you sold outright stakes, this time, it's been a bit more on the JV. So I didn't know if that had an impact in sort of how you see the reinvestment opportunity. That's where the question was going.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that we did sell 100% of several assets in the portfolio. I agree they weren't as large as the joint venture transactions that we did. I think the JVs were a function of the fact that the marketplace was very aggressive for the joint venture s
componenttext: No, I think that we did sell 100% of several assets in the portfolio. I agree they weren't as large as the joint venture transactions that we did. I think the JVs were a function of the fact that the marketplace was very aggressive for the joint venture structure, which was attractive to us. And second, the assets that we have in joint venture, we do believe in and we, in many cases, are improving and growing the cash flow. So it's a combination of both.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on California, Doug, appreciate the comments on the tech leasing environment out there. It sounds like things are pretty good, but just from the perspective of -- from our standpoint as we read news headlines whether it's -- well, you spoke
componenttext: Okay. And then on California, Doug, appreciate the comments on the tech leasing environment out there. It sounds like things are pretty good, but just from the perspective of -- from our standpoint as we read news headlines whether it's -- well, you spoke about Twitter, but Yahoo having issues or various tech tenants having issues, on the demand side, on the user side, is it basically as though the market, this is just normal tech volatility and this is always part of the cycle? Or what would be the red flags that would indicate that some of these tech issues headlines are more so than just normal expected volatility in business models?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're asking what's the canary in the coal mine, right? And I think that, that's a -- it's a really difficult question to answer with a specific fact that we'll look at and say, "Okay. Now the market is going to go turn." I think that in the last 4 or 5
componenttext: You're asking what's the canary in the coal mine, right? And I think that, that's a -- it's a really difficult question to answer with a specific fact that we'll look at and say, "Okay. Now the market is going to go turn." I think that in the last 4 or 5 years, the city of San Francisco has reshaped itself so dramatically in terms of the tenant demand that the diversity of companies and the strength of those companies is so different that I think that it will be much more difficult to sort of look at any one particular industry or any one particular company and say, "Okay. Things have really changed." I mean, clearly, an overall GDP reduction and a series of layoffs from major technology companies would be the thing that I think would be -- make it a clear-cut type of a demarcation. But again, we just don't see that. I mean, we see these large tech companies that have got pretty strong balance sheets and pretty global reaches now being able to weather the storm in a pretty significant manner and with a -- with business strategies that have a very long-term focus associated with them. So there is no question that there are going to be failures in certain tech industries. They're -- all of the mobile payment companies are not going to survive. I mean, there are, in all likelihood, a couple of unicorns that are not going to make it, just from a valuation and from a capital perspective. But we spent a tremendous amount of time looking at the demand from the sort of startup community versus the "traditional now" and more fundamentally sound technology companies. And on a relative basis, the city of San Francisco is in a really good place. So Bob, I don't know if you have any other comments you want to make.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you covered it.
componenttext: No, I think you covered it.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you touch on in each of your 4 major market, do you think market rent actually go up this year? And can vacancy sort of hold where they are? Or do you see any risk of market rent flattening, going down, vacancy going up? Maybe put some context around
componenttext: Can you touch on in each of your 4 major market, do you think market rent actually go up this year? And can vacancy sort of hold where they are? Or do you see any risk of market rent flattening, going down, vacancy going up? Maybe put some context around that. It sounds like you're pretty bullish around your opening comments, but I was curious how that translates into what you really see if the market rents stay at sea level.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess -- so I would characterize the way we feel as we are cautiously optimistic that rents will marginally improve across our markets, meaning that in markets like San Francisco, we believe we will continue to see modest increases in rent. I don't
componenttext: Yes, I guess -- so I would characterize the way we feel as we are cautiously optimistic that rents will marginally improve across our markets, meaning that in markets like San Francisco, we believe we will continue to see modest increases in rent. I don't think we're going to see spikes in the suburban Boston and the CBD of Boston. We're going to see good growth in rents, not spikes. In Midtown Manhattan, we think we're going to see pretty flat marginal growth in rents, a couple of percent, depending upon the quality of the space and the location of the space. In a market like Reston, I think we can push rents 2% or 3%, maybe up to 5%, depending upon the space. In the city of Washington, D.C., it's going to be a pretty flat year. So I think we are -- we think it's a good market, not a spiking market.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, helpful. And then specifically, if I look at 250 West 55th and I look at the lease termination, can you help us understand, if there was almost 20 years left on the lease, why didn't you say to the tenant, and I think we all know who it is, but why
componenttext: Okay, helpful. And then specifically, if I look at 250 West 55th and I look at the lease termination, can you help us understand, if there was almost 20 years left on the lease, why didn't you say to the tenant, and I think we all know who it is, but why didn't you say to the tenant, "Look, you signed a contract, pay us the rent and go sublease it"? Why wasn't that an option?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm -- I think -- I'm going to give you the quick and dirty answer, and John can choose to add some color if he would like. I think that's the approach that we took, and I think we got to a point where we felt that the economics of the payment that the te
componenttext: I'm -- I think -- I'm going to give you the quick and dirty answer, and John can choose to add some color if he would like. I think that's the approach that we took, and I think we got to a point where we felt that the economics of the payment that the tenant was making us more than justify the risk that we would be taking, reletting the space at a valuation that would provide us with a significant enhancement on a total NPV basis.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our math is you got about 5 years, give or take, worth of rent, is that about sort of the -- if you can lease it the next 5 years you come out ahead. Is that about right?
componenttext: And our math is you got about 5 years, give or take, worth of rent, is that about sort of the -- if you can lease it the next 5 years you come out ahead. Is that about right?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm not going to speak specifically to what the tenant was -- is paying us, because I just don't think that's appropriate. But the way we look at it was we had not yet given the tenant any money to build up their space. So that's sort of house money. A
componenttext: So I'm not going to speak specifically to what the tenant was -- is paying us, because I just don't think that's appropriate. But the way we look at it was we had not yet given the tenant any money to build up their space. So that's sort of house money. And we believe that we will be able to relet the space in short order at market transactions and that we will come out significantly ahead versus what the payment that the tenant made us.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a couple of quick questions. Doug, I guess, on the 250, just -- I just want to kind of circle back. So before this termination, the building was kind of what percent leased or committed? And just what kind of discussions maybe have you had behind
componenttext: I guess, a couple of quick questions. Doug, I guess, on the 250, just -- I just want to kind of circle back. So before this termination, the building was kind of what percent leased or committed? And just what kind of discussions maybe have you had behind the scenes with existing tenants about possible expansion needs in the building?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think prior to this, we were 92% leased and we have leases outstanding for another floor, so another 3% or 4%. So we're basically 94%, 95%. I would expect that the space that we're getting back, and remember I said there's some space on the ground floor
componenttext: I think prior to this, we were 92% leased and we have leases outstanding for another floor, so another 3% or 4%. So we're basically 94%, 95%. I would expect that the space that we're getting back, and remember I said there's some space on the ground floor, that's retail, and then there's space on the second floor and then there's one high-rise tower floor that we will, in all likelihood, lease the high-rise tower floor to tenants outside the building, similar to the way we've been leasing up the 33rd, 34th, 35th floors. So they're going to be 5,000 square feet to 12,000 square feet to maybe a full floor. And I don't believe that anybody in the building will take the second floor and the retail will come from retailers who are, obviously, looking to place their installations on Eighth Avenue.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, going to Salesforce Tower, I mean, it sounds like you're making a little bit of progress here and will have some leasing done. Just -- and it sounds like you've got other things in the pipeline. Just help us kind of map out over the next co
componenttext: Okay. I guess, going to Salesforce Tower, I mean, it sounds like you're making a little bit of progress here and will have some leasing done. Just -- and it sounds like you've got other things in the pipeline. Just help us kind of map out over the next couple of quarters kind of what goals you have, kind of where you want to be maybe by the middle of the year or end of the year as you kind of turn the corner into '17. What does sort of the leasing progression look like as we now get into the strike zone of delivery?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So again, just in the context, the building is going to be available for tenants other than Salesforce in the latter half of 2017 and into early 2018. So I would expect that we now have done another 5 floors, knock on wood, that we'll get the last si
componenttext: Yes. So again, just in the context, the building is going to be available for tenants other than Salesforce in the latter half of 2017 and into early 2018. So I would expect that we now have done another 5 floors, knock on wood, that we'll get the last signature page.  I mean, the leases are literally after signature, in the next couple of days. And so our expectation is there's another 200,000 to 300,000 square feet of leasing that we hope to get done during calendar year 2016, obviously, for rent commencement in late '17 or early '18. I think that would be our -- that's our sort of base-case goal. And Bob, you can comment and you'll probably tell me you're going to have the whole thing leased before the end of the year, but I'd moderate that perspective [ph].

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add that just this past week, we had an inquiry for 200,000 to 500,000 feet from a very well-known tenant in the marketplace. And this week, we also had 3 senior real estate heads from Wells Fargo, Google, Intel, all come for a presentation o
componenttext: I would just add that just this past week, we had an inquiry for 200,000 to 500,000 feet from a very well-known tenant in the marketplace. And this week, we also had 3 senior real estate heads from Wells Fargo, Google, Intel, all come for a presentation on the building, which was better attended than we expected. So I mean, clearly, people are looking at this building. And I remain very optimistic that we're going to lease that quickly.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, last question maybe for Doug and/or Owen. As you just think about some of the development projects that you talked about or future developments, I realize you guys generally have a relatively high hurdle for pre-leasing. But just what a
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, last question maybe for Doug and/or Owen. As you just think about some of the development projects that you talked about or future developments, I realize you guys generally have a relatively high hurdle for pre-leasing. But just what are the discussions like on some of those? And if you had to handicap, how much you think you'd start this year? Maybe without naming specific projects, what do you think that looks like?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Steve, as you said, we do have a high bar for new development. We have -- we've talked about our target yields, and we also have -- we also like to see significant pre-leasing. I went through some of the projects in my remark. The most significant o
componenttext: Well, Steve, as you said, we do have a high bar for new development. We have -- we've talked about our target yields, and we also have -- we also like to see significant pre-leasing. I went through some of the projects in my remark. The most significant ones are the TSA requirement at Springfield, which, I don't think we're prepared necessarily to handicap, we're certainly pursuing it. Ray ought to comment on Reston and what the prospects look like for the Signature site that we're working on in Reston right now. Bryan, I don't know if you want to spend a minute on CityPoint, or talk about what the prospects are for that. So, Ray, can I turn it over to you?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Owen. Thanks. As Reston sits there today, effectively 100% leased and no new supply coming online either from us or from the competition. We feel exceedingly strong about -- this may come as a shocker, but we're pushing to go spec. We think that the
componenttext: Sure, Owen. Thanks. As Reston sits there today, effectively 100% leased and no new supply coming online either from us or from the competition. We feel exceedingly strong about -- this may come as a shocker, but we're pushing to go spec. We think that there's 4 sizes. The building size and the internal demand we have within the market can clearly justify it, but we're in discussions with about 3 or 4 major existing tenants of ours who have expressed interest in anywhere between 80,000 and 150,000 square feet.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Bryan, you want to spend a minute on CityPoint, 20 CityPoint?
componenttext: And, Bryan, you want to spend a minute on CityPoint, 20 CityPoint?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, CityPoint. The quietest story about the strength of the Boston market is the Waltham market in general. If you look at it, our competitive set is like 5% in terms of vacancy and despite 2, 3 points down from the previous year. So we got a good supply
componenttext: Yes, CityPoint. The quietest story about the strength of the Boston market is the Waltham market in general. If you look at it, our competitive set is like 5% in terms of vacancy and despite 2, 3 points down from the previous year. So we got a good supply side if you look at the marketplace. Then on the demand side, Doug mentioned it earlier, we've got good life science activity. Many companies looking from migration out of Cambridge into this immediate suburb. And then also, in the call it cyber or cloud tech segment of the marketplace, good growth. And Doug mentioned the strength of the larger companies and the concern about it, what we're seeing again is, in a quiet way, these midsized companies 50,000 feet growing to 70,000, 100,000 square feet with strong financial statements and strong products. So we're really encouraged about what's taking place. And I'd say to the last note, Owen, is just that there is a strong appeal for product that has the amenities that have been lacking in the marketplace, those being the restaurants, and that's what's been so attractive to clients about CityPoint.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bryan, lastly, the last one we should mention is the Kendall Center, the new project, the new office project at Kendall Center.
componenttext: And Bryan, lastly, the last one we should mention is the Kendall Center, the new project, the new office project at Kendall Center.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in a lot of ways, Owen, it's called new to market because we just got the approvals on it, so it's very recent in terms of its news and the opportunity, but again, just to reiterate what you and Doug had mentioned, the strength and the number of peop
componenttext: Yes, in a lot of ways, Owen, it's called new to market because we just got the approvals on it, so it's very recent in terms of its news and the opportunity, but again, just to reiterate what you and Doug had mentioned, the strength and the number of people we're talking to is significant in this market, and Kendall remains very [indiscernible]

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Steve, to summarize, so the projects I think to keep an eye on are Kendall Center, Springfield Metro, 20 CityPoint and the Signature site in Reston. We're all working hard on getting pre-let so we could start these projects.
componenttext: So, Steve, to summarize, so the projects I think to keep an eye on are Kendall Center, Springfield Metro, 20 CityPoint and the Signature site in Reston. We're all working hard on getting pre-let so we could start these projects.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from line of Brad Burke from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And your next question comes from line of Brad Burke from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up to the last question. Taking everything that you just said and summarizing it, should we think about the negative macro headlines that we've seen over the past few months of having had any impact on how you're thinking about the pace or t
componenttext: Just a follow-up to the last question. Taking everything that you just said and summarizing it, should we think about the negative macro headlines that we've seen over the past few months of having had any impact on how you're thinking about the pace or the magnitude of total new development starts over the course of 2016?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are generally conservative in our approach to new development. I've described -- we've talked about our yield target being 7% plus for office. We have a pre-letting requirement, which we also think helps mitigate risk in development. I wo
componenttext: Well, I think we are generally conservative in our approach to new development. I've described -- we've talked about our yield target being 7% plus for office. We have a pre-letting requirement, which we also think helps mitigate risk in development. I would also point out that our development pipeline is not static. We just announced the delivery of several projects off our pipeline, that's going to continue. So even if we add a few projects this year, it's likely our development pipeline may actually go down during the year. So, yes, we're paying attention. The macro headlines do matter, but at the same time, if we have a project that we think pencils to an attractive yield to shareholders and we have risk mitigation through pre-leasing, we're going to launch it.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just an update on how you're thinking about the appropriate amount of liquidity and appropriate amount of leverage in the current environment and whether that shifted at all over the past few months?
componenttext: Okay. And then just an update on how you're thinking about the appropriate amount of liquidity and appropriate amount of leverage in the current environment and whether that shifted at all over the past few months?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Brad, I think that we have acted to bolster our liquidity additionally with the bond deal we just did. We've looked at our future debt maturities and we did the defeasance, so we're kind of taking some of those maturities off the table now. We've go
componenttext: Well, Brad, I think that we have acted to bolster our liquidity additionally with the bond deal we just did. We've looked at our future debt maturities and we did the defeasance, so we're kind of taking some of those maturities off the table now. We've got all the capital raised to fund out our development pipeline, so we have a very, very liquid balance sheet and are in strong position. And from a leverage perspective, on a net debt to EBITDA basis, we're somewhere in the high 5s. So that's down pretty significantly over the last 4 or 5 years. We expect that to continue, as I mentioned in my comments, because our development pipeline will be coming online and we've already raised the money to do that, and those developments are expected to generate strong yields. So I think that our capacity to do additional things is just going to grow, so we think we're very, very well-positioned from both a liquidity perspective and a leverage perspective right now.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.

componenttext: So back on the topic of 250 West 55th, I think some of the space on the second floor is pretty unique. So how are you guys thinking about releasing that? Will it need to go to a specific type of user, or do you think you'll have demand that will be pretty broad-based?

componenttext: Bryan, you want to take that?

componenttextpreview: Sure. It is very unique space with the -- it's almost a side core at that lower second level with the floor plate being close to 50,000 feet. And the ceiling heights make it -- and large windows make it very unique space. We have the flexibility to use th
componenttext: Sure. It is very unique space with the -- it's almost a side core at that lower second level with the floor plate being close to 50,000 feet. And the ceiling heights make it -- and large windows make it very unique space. We have the flexibility to use the second floor in creative ways. We could clearly use it for -- access it through the lobby and use it for office space, but we could also access it from 8th Avenue, from some of the retail space and use it for a different type of use, studios or other. So we'll be looking at all of that.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful.

componenttext: There are -- yes, so I'll give you the macro view. The macro view is we are in conversations with a number of tenants, and we're optimistic that our perceived view of the value and the critical nature of that space for someone's brand will meld together. And we're optimistic we're going to have a deal done sometime in 2016 for someone to use the space in 2017.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of John Guinee with Stifel.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of John Guinee with Stifel.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. A few questions here. First, Ray Ritchey, general dynamics of Washington Business Journal article a couple of weeks ago moving into -- you're doing a build-to-suit for them on Sunset Hills Road, I think it is, in Reston. There was also an article t
componenttext: Great. A few questions here. First, Ray Ritchey, general dynamics of Washington Business Journal article a couple of weeks ago moving into -- you're doing a build-to-suit for them on Sunset Hills Road, I think it is, in Reston. There was also an article that Northrop Grumman is spending $300 million to buy versus lease space in the Baltimore/Washington area. Do you have any sense as -- with the defense contractors out there, whether there is a tendency to lease versus own and control their own space? And then, you've got to do this without talking your book, what do you think are the better submarkets in D.C. as the defense contractors, cyber security driven get back into the market and lease space?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's rather a long question. I'll give my best to make it as brief as possible. First of all, I can't comment on the specifics of the tenant coming or the purchaser coming to Reston. And there is a little bit of movement towards owning the space.
componenttext: Well, that's rather a long question. I'll give my best to make it as brief as possible. First of all, I can't comment on the specifics of the tenant coming or the purchaser coming to Reston. And there is a little bit of movement towards owning the space. As you know, the accounting change taking place in '18 will have an impact on many corporations on how they booked their occupancy costs. But I still think that the defense contractors want to have -- given the uncertainty of the long-term government contracts, they still want to stay relatively short in the lease terms, so they're not held out with either long-term lease obligations or the lack of liquidity by owning real estate. So I think those are isolated examples, John, but I don't see a general trend. Relative to the market for cyber command, obviously, we're optimistic that Fort Meade will continue to pump out both contracts and then resulting jobs. The Dulles Corridor still is very strong, with the presence of major intel activities out there, NRO and CIA. So we like our positions in both those markets. I will say that the Rosslyn-Ballston corridor is relatively soft. And I think that's more about the fact that now Tysons, with the Silver Line, has opened up another market that those defense contractors can go to with better access and lower occupancy cost. So that still faces challenges but we're putting our money in the Dulles Corridor and the Fort Meade market.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Then, Doug, this is a question on lease economics and value creation versus just simply no value creation and being on a hamster wheel. What we've seen happen over the last 4 or 5 years has been an interesting situation where you've seen rent
componenttext: Okay, great. Then, Doug, this is a question on lease economics and value creation versus just simply no value creation and being on a hamster wheel. What we've seen happen over the last 4 or 5 years has been an interesting situation where you've seen rental rates go up but you've also seen CapEx and releasing costs remain high, essentially financing corporate America. Clearly, if you get a mark-to-market of 0 cash, 5 GAAP and $50 NTI, that being the math is value destruction. What do you need in terms of rollups in order to justify the CapEx you're putting into these buildings to say to your shareholders, we've got value creation here?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're just making one sort of subtle argument that there's no real value to the cash flow from a building once the lease has been signed that's different than the amortization of the transaction cost into that building and I guess, I would argue th
componenttext: Well, you're just making one sort of subtle argument that there's no real value to the cash flow from a building once the lease has been signed that's different than the amortization of the transaction cost into that building and I guess, I would argue that, in many cases, the expectations associated with what these buildings will do in the future is an important component to how they're being valued, and so while on a short-term basis, it may be true that in a particular building where a lease is rolling at a "flat mark-to-market " and you're putting transaction costs in on a net-effective basis is obviously slightly dilutive, if there's a perception, and in many of these markets, there's a perception, which is based upon reality that rental rates will grow over time, that there is significant value that's likely embedded in that cash flow from that particular lease on a forward basis. So that's how you have to think about it. Now there are in fact cases where we don't have a view that, that -- there is going to be rental rate growth of any significance. And as Owen suggested, those are buildings were we are sort of saying, "You know, leasing these things up and selling these buildings might be the best course of valor here." And so we have done a number of those sort of modest prunings over the years where in fact, we have agreed with you that there really isn't a lot of value to be attributed to doing additional leasing in these assets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Okay, wonderful. And then, Mike LaBelle, I realize taxable income doesn't line up with EPS exactly, but your dividend run rate is about $0.65 a share or $2.60 a year. In 2014, your earnings per share was $3.72, and when you take your $2.60 standard
componenttext: Great. Okay, wonderful. And then, Mike LaBelle, I realize taxable income doesn't line up with EPS exactly, but your dividend run rate is about $0.65 a share or $2.60 a year. In 2014, your earnings per share was $3.72, and when you take your $2.60 standard dividend and your $1.25 special, it came out to $3.85, which is pretty close to your earnings per share for '14. Your 2015 earnings per share guidance is about $2.75 at the midpoint. What's that tell us about -- I'm sorry, I misspoke, I meant 2015 and now 2016. Your 2016 earnings per share guidance was about $2.75 at the midpoint. What's that tell us about future dividend policies?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a good question. I think that as our development comes online and if we slow down our asset sales, as Owen had mentioned, that's going to grow our taxable income. And as our taxable income grows, we will want to keep up with our traditional divide
componenttext: That is a good question. I think that as our development comes online and if we slow down our asset sales, as Owen had mentioned, that's going to grow our taxable income. And as our taxable income grows, we will want to keep up with our traditional dividend policy of dividending out 100% of our taxable income, so you would expect that our dividends would grow. Whether that occurs in 2016 or not, I can't tell you right now. What I can say is that, at this point, we have not made any change to our dividend policy for this year. Obviously, in prior years, we have sold a tremendous amount of assets and we have delivered, I think it's $8 a share in special dividends in the last few years. And so we've lost income from those assets that we've sold. We've replaced it with development and we've elected to keep our dividend, our regular dividend, in line because we've been able to base it upon our taxable income. But we've got a sizable development pipeline that is going to be adding to our income in the next few years. So depending on what happens on asset sales, I would expect our taxable income is going to go up.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could share any surprises or other takeaways from your bond offering last month? And perhaps if there was a widening disparity of investor appetite between A- and lower credit, or any investor concerns on the office fundamentals.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could share any surprises or other takeaways from your bond offering last month? And perhaps if there was a widening disparity of investor appetite between A- and lower credit, or any investor concerns on the office fundamentals.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that our bond offering went very well. I would say it went better than we expected given the volatility that we had -- we were seeing in the market. We wanted to try to do something either in December or January, so we have been looking at t
componenttext: Look, I think that our bond offering went very well. I would say it went better than we expected given the volatility that we had -- we were seeing in the market. We wanted to try to do something either in December or January, so we have been looking at the market for a while, and it's been pretty volatile throughout. The demand for our deal was over 4x what we expected to raise, so we were able to tighten in during the process and get to a level that we thought was a really good level. And there's been other companies that are highly rated companies including a company yesterday, not in the REIT space, that has been very, very successful. I think as you go down the risk spectrum and to lower investment grade and noninvestment grade, the widening in credit spreads in the last 30 days has been more significant than the 20 to 30 basis points that I mentioned for companies like ourselves.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to comment, so Mike has done a terrific job managing down our balance sheet and putting us in what I consider to be an enviable position relevant to our -- both our liquidity and our access to capital, and has done a really good job of working
componenttext: I just want to comment, so Mike has done a terrific job managing down our balance sheet and putting us in what I consider to be an enviable position relevant to our -- both our liquidity and our access to capital, and has done a really good job of working with the bond investors to educate them on the principal foundations of how our business runs. And so we did our deal. And I think we've traded 5 to 7 basis points wide in a period where the market has traded 30 basis points wide. So I think the reason that we are as successful as we were is because the company is in really good stead with the bondholders. And it's a -- I think it's very satisfying and it gives us a lot of comfort that going forward into 2016 and 2017, when -- as Mike spoke earlier, we do have additional maturities, that we're going to be in a pretty good place to access either the unsecured or the secured markets at whatever the market pricing is but at the tightest levels possible.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do the fixed income have similar amount of concerns on the tech slowdown and New York fundamentals or are they less concerned about the future?
componenttext: Do the fixed income have similar amount of concerns on the tech slowdown and New York fundamentals or are they less concerned about the future?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think they think about it in a significant way but ultimately then think they look at it closely, the covenant structure of REIT bonds, and they look at the overall leverage ratio of our company and how we performed over the past decade as being an unse
componenttext: I think they think about it in a significant way but ultimately then think they look at it closely, the covenant structure of REIT bonds, and they look at the overall leverage ratio of our company and how we performed over the past decade as being an unsecured issuer and they get very comfortable with the way we've managed our book of business.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then, Doug, on your answer to Ross's question earlier on market rental growth. Can you clarify if that was for asking rents or effective rents that you're seeing?
componenttext: Okay, and then, Doug, on your answer to Ross's question earlier on market rental growth. Can you clarify if that was for asking rents or effective rents that you're seeing?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm talking about gross-based rents.
componenttext: I'm talking about gross-based rents.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with vacancy tightening in some markets, do you see TIs decreasing?
componenttext: So with vacancy tightening in some markets, do you see TIs decreasing?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the TIs have come down in some places, and I think the TIs have basically stabilized in others. So as an example, I still think in San Francisco, if you're doing a 10- or a 15-year lease on a -- with a tenant that is going to be rebuilding sp
componenttext: I think that the TIs have come down in some places, and I think the TIs have basically stabilized in others. So as an example, I still think in San Francisco, if you're doing a 10- or a 15-year lease on a -- with a tenant that is going to be rebuilding space, they are likely looking for a $70-plus a square foot. By the way, the $70 a square foot is probably getting them 60% of the way to what their costs are and it might have been getting them [indiscernible] 5 years ago because just the cost of construction as well changes to the energy codes and other codes that are requiring them to do things that they would not have had to do, which is just simply increase the overall cost of occupancy. So I think from the tenants' perspective interestingly, they actually see a diminution in the transaction cost in many of these deals. We are sort of looking at it at as a flatness.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Rich Anderson from Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Rich Anderson from Mizuho Securities.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just ask one question, try to keep it short. Doug, you mentioned very early on in the comments about taking back small increments of space in New York and try to get in front of the supply pressures. Do you have a visibility into that pipeline?
componenttext: Yes, I'll just ask one question, try to keep it short. Doug, you mentioned very early on in the comments about taking back small increments of space in New York and try to get in front of the supply pressures. Do you have a visibility into that pipeline? In other words, what amount of the space in New York do you think tenants have signaled an interest to either shrink or exit their space at some point in the future?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to let John answer that question. And interestingly, I think we've had a presentation that we've done for a number of groups that we've -- where we sort of have gone out and shown people what is ultimately anticipated to be coming out to the mar
componenttext: I'm going to let John answer that question. And interestingly, I think we've had a presentation that we've done for a number of groups that we've -- where we sort of have gone out and shown people what is ultimately anticipated to be coming out to the market over the next 2 years. And it's -- I think all of that is built into it. And, John, why don't you sort of describe the results?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, right now I can say we don't have any discussions with any of our tenants about shrinking. That's probably succinct as I can put it. We have done, over the last couple of years, as you know, a number of law firm deals. Some of those law firms have t
componenttext: Well, right now I can say we don't have any discussions with any of our tenants about shrinking. That's probably succinct as I can put it. We have done, over the last couple of years, as you know, a number of law firm deals. Some of those law firms have taken the same amount of space because they're growing but they're more efficient in the space that they have. And other of those law firms have dropped significantly, sometimes by 15% or 20%. But right now, we don't see any tenants that are in the portfolio that we're talking to, or for that matter, tenants that are looking at -- from outside that are shrinking.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's the motivation to be taking this proactive step?
componenttext: What's the motivation to be taking this proactive step?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, different tenants have different motivations. We're talking to someone at 399 for a very large block of space that's in 3 or 4 locations and they want to consolidate. That's an important motivation. We're talking to some tenants in the building that
componenttext: Well, different tenants have different motivations. We're talking to someone at 399 for a very large block of space that's in 3 or 4 locations and they want to consolidate. That's an important motivation. We're talking to some tenants in the building that have bought other companies that want to expand and want to consolidate everyone into 399. So it's always a specific business issue for the tenants that you're dealing with or the prospects that you're dealing with.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just be a little bit more clear. So our decision to redo Weil Gotshal, Kirkland & Ellis, Reed Smith, Kirkpatrick & Lockhart was a decision where we said, "Okay, there are a number of new buildings that are being built across the city, and there are
componenttext: Let me just be a little bit more clear. So our decision to redo Weil Gotshal, Kirkland & Ellis, Reed Smith, Kirkpatrick & Lockhart was a decision where we said, "Okay, there are a number of new buildings that are being built across the city, and there are a number of buildings that are going to be vacated across the city when the tenants that are in them are moving to buildings that are currently vacated." And our tenants are a likely candidate for all of those future availabilities and we think we have the ability to help them get into more efficient space, take some space back in calendar year 2015 or 2016 or 2017 in a very modest way that can be both accretive to them in terms of being able to reduce their footprint prior to their expiration in 2019 or 2020 and give us an opportunity to lease space at rents that are better than what those current tenants are paying. And so it was the recognition that there were a number of competitive availabilities that our tenants were going to be looking at over the next few years and taking advantage of our attributes in terms of timing and ability to do things with them earlier that led us to go into those directions. And that space is available today, and so we feel really good about all of those decisions.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Tom Catherwood from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Tom Catherwood from Cowen and Company.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on D.C, obviously the 9% leasing spreads this quarter were the highest since 2011, but, Doug, building off your comments saying you expect rents to be flattish in 2016. Do you think the driver of those kind of moderating to no growth rents
componenttext: Quick question on D.C, obviously the 9% leasing spreads this quarter were the highest since 2011, but, Doug, building off your comments saying you expect rents to be flattish in 2016. Do you think the driver of those kind of moderating to no growth rents is more slower demand or is it an impact of kind of increased supply in the market?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ray, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Ray, do you want to take that?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take a shot. One of the things we look at is not only the new construction that is -- new development taking place. What we're seeing in D.C. is a repositioning of older assets, moving them from B- to A-, and that level of supply is probably a
componenttext: Yes, let me take a shot. One of the things we look at is not only the new construction that is -- new development taking place. What we're seeing in D.C. is a repositioning of older assets, moving them from B- to A-, and that level of supply is probably at an all-time high. That's why we're so aggressive and out talking to our tenants. We just renewed Steptoe with '17 expiration. We're talking to Aiken with a 2020 expiration. We're trying to get our larger existing tenants locked up because they are the targets of those new buildings coming online. And unlike the other 3 markets that we're in, D.C. is very much a lease expiration-driven market. We don't have Salesforce coming in, taking 700,000 square feet as Bob enjoys in San Francisco. So our strategy is to get out with our existing tenants, lock them up and then aggressively go after other people's tenants to backfill our new developments. So I'd say to summarize this, it's much more about the increasing supply moderating any future growth in demand.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I appreciate that. And then one quick one up in Cambridge. Obviously, the upzoning at Kendall Square is a big deal. Do you have an estimate of that per-square foot value of that additional FAR that you guys received?
componenttext: Got it. I appreciate that. And then one quick one up in Cambridge. Obviously, the upzoning at Kendall Square is a big deal. Do you have an estimate of that per-square foot value of that additional FAR that you guys received?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't want to haphazardly give you an answer. I will just say as follows that we have the ability in some places to build structure on top of parking areas and then in other times, there may be a requirement to remove a particular existing asset and
componenttext: I wouldn't want to haphazardly give you an answer. I will just say as follows that we have the ability in some places to build structure on top of parking areas and then in other times, there may be a requirement to remove a particular existing asset and add density to it. So the mathematics associated with what the value is -- are really difficult to sort of describe with a number. I will tell you that we believe that we will be able to achieve rents in excess of that mid- to high 60s on a triple-net basis in current market conditions, and over time, we think those rents are going to go up because there's such a lack of supply in that area. And so we believe we will be able to profitably figure out how to use that density.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your final question comes from the line of Craig Mailman from KeyBanc.
componenttext: And your final question comes from the line of Craig Mailman from KeyBanc.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I'll try to keep it quick. On Salesforce, net-net the 300,000 square feet you guys are working on with '17 expirations, do you think that, that would indicate an expansion space versus what those guys have in place or a contraction?

componenttextpreview: I think, in most cases, these are financial service companies that are looking for a modest amount of incremental expansion as they move forward. They're -- none of them are looking to reduce their footprint.
componenttext: I think, in most cases, these are financial service companies that are looking for a modest amount of incremental expansion as they move forward. They're -- none of them are looking to reduce their footprint.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the 200 to 500 that you guys are -- just got the inquiry on. Is that someone that's new to the market in expansion space or more of a forward exploration that they're looking to consolidate into your building?
componenttext: Okay. And then the 200 to 500 that you guys are -- just got the inquiry on. Is that someone that's new to the market in expansion space or more of a forward exploration that they're looking to consolidate into your building?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's an existing tenant in the marketplace that continues to expand.
componenttext: It's an existing tenant in the marketplace that continues to expand.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last one. Owen, you touched on earlier that you guys are looking at more value-add and development opportunities. Just more on the development side. Kind of how far out are you guys looking in terms of kind of opportunities for this cy
componenttext: Okay. And then just last one. Owen, you touched on earlier that you guys are looking at more value-add and development opportunities. Just more on the development side. Kind of how far out are you guys looking in terms of kind of opportunities for this cycle or next cycle and which markets perhaps outside of the Volpe site would you guys be interested in adding additional sites for?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's opportunity driven. We're actively looking at new investment opportunities in all of our markets. We have on balance sheet today, actually, a very significant pipeline of both entitled and unentitled land that we're going to continue to push thr
componenttext:
Yes, it's opportunity driven. We're actively looking at new investment opportunities in all of our markets. We have on balance sheet today, actually, a very significant pipeline of both entitled and unentitled land that we're going to continue to push through the entitlement and permitting process. New projects at this stage, it depends. I mean, it's -- they could be for a future cycle. I suppose it's -- prospects exist for this cycle although probably less likely. I just want to add a couple of things to that last question. So we have, interestingly, a shadow, shadow pipeline that we've talked about before. So as an example, in Reston, Virginia, we -- when light rail comes, we are going to get an up-zoning in density. And I will -- Peter, you can describe what -- how much of that we're going to be getting there on land that we own in, in our existing footprint. In Boston, we are in the midst of beginning our Back Bay train station upzoning entitlements for up to 1.75 million square feet of space. So there are projects like that, that are more long-range. They are not 2017 starts, they're probably 2018 or '19 or '20 starts that are physically in the company's balance sheet right now and we just need to perfect them. And then we have buildings like 4th and Harrison, where again, we're in the permitting process for up to 900,000 square feet and likely to probably be a little bit less than that, but when central SOMA eventually gets permitted and we're in a position to start a building, it's another market where we're looking for things. We've talked about block -- excuse me, Dock72 where we're -- we'll hopefully be under construction in the next few weeks with the first building where we have the potential to do another 1 million square feet. So again there's a really good embedded inventory of places in the company that we can add inventory over time. 
So I think that completes all the questions. Hopefully we've been able to demonstrate to you all the progress we've made on our plans. Thank you very much for your attention this morning.
