componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Boston Properties First Quarter Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Ms. Arista Joyner, Investor Relations Manager of Boston Properties. Please go ahead.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties' First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night as well as furnished on Form 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconciled all no
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties' First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night as well as furnished on Form 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with the Reg G requirement. If you did not receive a copy, these documents are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.bostonproperties.com. An audio webcast of this call will be available for 12 months in the Investor Relations section of our website.
At this time, we would like to inform you that certain statements made during this conference call, which are not historical may constitute forward looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although Boston Properties believes the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, it can give no assurance that its expectations will be attained. Factors and risks that could cause actual results to material differently from those expressed or implied by forward-looking statements were detailed in Tuesday's press release and from time to time, in the company's filings with the SEC. The company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements.
Having said that, I'd like to welcome Owen Thomas, Chief Executive Officer; Doug Linde, President; and Mike LaBelle, Chief Financial Officer. During the question-and-answer portion of our call, Ray Ritchey, Senior Executive Vice President and our regional management teams will be available to address any questions.
I would now like to turn the call over to Owen Thomas for his formal remarks.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arista. Good morning, everyone. This morning, I'll cover our quarterly results, the macro market conditions that we see as well as our current capital strategy and investment activity.Our current results, we produced another strong quarter wi
componenttext:
Thank you, Arista. Good morning, everyone. This morning, I'll cover our quarterly results, the macro market conditions that we see as well as our current capital strategy and investment activity.
Our current results, we produced another strong quarter with FFO per share of $0.05 above consensus, primarily due to improved operating performance. We've also increased the midpoint of our full year 2016 FFO per share guidance by $0.05. Released 1.5 million square feet in the first quarter, above historical averages, and our portfolio occupancies is now 91%, down 40 basis points from year end, due primarily to the Genentech vacancy of 186,000 square feet at 611 Gateway South San Francisco. We had solid rent roll up in our leasing activity with rental rates on leases that commenced in the first quarter, up to 16% on a gross basis and 26% on a net basis compared to the prior weeks. The leasing results in San Francisco, New York and Boston all exhibited strong growth over the quarter.
Now moving to market conditions. U.S. economic growth continues to be positive, though we certainly see a hint of slow down. Fourth quarter GDP growth is now reported at 1.5%, which is down 2% from the third quarter last year. And estimates for this quarter are below 1%. However, most forecasters for this year are still predicting growth in excess of 2.5% albeit after downward revision.
The job picture remains fairly healthy with 215,000 jobs created in March and the unemployment rate is steady at 5%. Labor participation statistics are unchanged. We also see office markets nationally continuing to improve. Net absorption was 5.9 million square feet in the first quarter. Vacancy rate remains essentially unchanged at 13.9%, asking rents rose 4.7% over the last year, construction levels also rose 6% over the last year but remained at 2% of total stocks, slightly above long-term averages for the U.S. office market. We continue to see the strongest-based demand in locations driven by technology, life sciences and other innovative industries notwithstanding all the financial disruptions for the last 9 months.
Moving to financial markets. They've improved materially from their low to mid-February. S&P 500 is up over 14%, credit spreads have narrowed, oil prices are up over 50%. Near-term interest rate increase is also look less likely with U.S. Federal Reserve, highlighting concerns about the sluggish growth and other central banks around the world, most recently the European Central Bank, signaling an accommodated posture. 10-year U.S. Treasury is hovering around 1.9%. It's traded below 2% since January. Credit spreads has narrowed less though for riskier credits.
Now moving to real estate. On private real estate, private market real estate valuation, prices remain strong for prime assets in gateway market. And we've seen plenty of evidence of this over the first quarters. I've seen a number of transactions in our core market that were offered and priced in 2016. Examples of these include: In Boston, 101 Seaport, that's a new 440,000 square-foot office building located in the Seaport District, 100% leased to PwC on a long-term basis, sold for $1,029 of square-foot and a 4% initial cap rate to a German fund.
In Washington, D.C, 733 10th Street, fully leased 270 square-foot office building sold for about a 4.7% initial cap rate, 1,065 square-foot, I believe, only the third building to trade above $1,000 per square-foot in the district. The buyer was a Middle Eastern Fund Manager.
In New York, there are 2 significant sales reported to be pending to non-U.S. investors. A significant partial interest in 10 Hudson Yard, a new 1.8 million-square-foot office tower selling for a low 4s, initial cap rate and nearly 1,200 of square-foot; and 550 Madison Avenue, a 850,000 square-foot office building that was being vacated for residential conversion that's trading for approximately $1,800 a square-foot.
And lastly, in San Francisco, 140 New Montgomery, a 300,000 square-foot older but fully renovated Class A office building in the Soma district, leased at current market rents, sold to a U.S. investor for approximately a 4 8 cap rate and over $960 a foot, a record price per square foot in San Francisco.
As with the fixed income market, our perception is pricing for riskier assets whether a non-core location and/or requiring lease up or renovation has softened to a degree in 2016. Long-term interest rates are low and cap rate spreads and treasuries are above long-term averages, both of which provide strong support to real estate valuation. As I've mentioned before, the relatively high investment yields and cash flow stability provided by high quality real estate assets will continue to be an attractive investment alternative to fixed income. 
Now moving to our capital strategy. It remains unchanged in that we're investing more in new developments and redevelopments that a stabilized acquisition, and these investments will be funded partially by select asset dispositions in the balance with debt financing.
On acquisitions, we continue to actively review and are seeing an increase for the reasons I mentioned earlier in value-add and development opportunities in our core markets. This past quarter, we purchased a 218,000 square-foot office building on Peterson Way in Santa Clara, California for $78 million. The asset is in an infill location with increasing density at 100% leased to a single tenant through 2021. During the remaining lease term, we plan to entitle the property for approximately a 630,000 square-foot office campus. So the way to think about pricing is we're paying $123 a square-foot for an untitled land while receiving a 4.6% cash yield as we entitle and pre-lease a new upsized office complex. We're also working on several additional acquisitions of size and value-add office buildings.
On dispositions. In the first quarter, as previously discussed, we completed the sale of 7 Kendall Center to MIT for $105 million. We continue to pursue select sales of non-core assets and maintain our estimate of 2016 asset sales of $200 million to $250 million.
Moving to development. We remain very active primarily in the execution of our predevelopment pipeline. In terms of forecasting potential start for the balance of 2016, we'll remain highly dependent on securing preleasing for entitled sites with potential starts for 2016 includes Springfield Metro Center, where we're pursuing a requirement with the TSA; Reston Block 5, located in the Reston Town Center; and 20 CityPoint, the Mirror building to 10 CityPoint being developed in Waltham. These 3 projects aggregate 1.1 million square feet.
We've been very active this past quarter advancing our predevelopment pipeline for projects that would start beyond 2016. Several important updates are as follows: as mentioned last quarter, in Cambridge at year end 2015, 940,000 square feet of additional entitlement were made available for our Kendall Center development. We're -- we are in advanced discussion with multiple office users to fully pre-lease the 540,000 square-foot office component of the entitlement. The balance of the project will be high-rise residential. The project is complex involving replacing 2 smaller existing buildings on the site and will likely commence in 2017. Given we are not acquiring additional land, this project is another great example of the embedded development value in many of our existing assets.
You probably read about our initial submission to the city of Boston for the development of additional site at the Back Bay Station. We are already managing the concourse level of the Back Bay Station as part of our agreement with the Massachusetts Department of Transportation. The project is in an early stage and could ultimately represent 1.3 million square feet of office retail and residential space located adjacent to a major Boston transit hub. The project is obviously subject to local approvals and public review and would not commence prior to late 2017.
You have also probably read that we have been designated by the MTA as developer for their site located at 343 Madison Avenue between 44th and 45th Street in New York. The site is the western half of the full city block between Madison and Vanderbilt Avenues and offers direct access to Grand Central Station and the new Long Island railroad station at Grand Central terminal. We will acquire a 99-year ground lease and build up to a 900,000 square-foot office tower, subject to a number of local approvals and the new work. The development at this property is likely several years out but we've commenced our predevelopment work.
As discussed, we're also conducting a significant upgrade of portions of our portfolio. This redevelopment projects that we're executing includes 399 Park, a low-rise building at 601 Lex in New York; 1330 Connecticut Avenue; Metropolitan Square and the Prudential Center retail.
At the end of the first quarter, our development pipeline consisted of 11 new projects and 1 redevelopment, representing 4.6 million square feet and $2.6 billion in projected costs. Our budgeted NOI for these projects remains an excess of 7% and the commercial component of the pipeline is 61% pre-lease. We have all the cash, $1.4 billion, required to complete the development of the portfolio, which should add materially to our company's growth over the next 4 years.
Moving for a moment to a comment on governance. We recently announced in our proxy that Morts Zuckerman will retire as Chairman of the Board and becomes Chairman of Emeritus of Boston Properties. Ivan Seidenberg will also retire from our board and Joel Klein will become our Lead Independent Director. We are also very pleased to be able to recruit Sharon Deistre and Bruce Duncan as independent directors of our board.
So in conclusion, we remain very enthusiastic about our prospects for success and ability to create shareholder value for the balance of 2016 and in future years. We have a very clear plan to improve and lease our existing assets as well as add new buildings through development to our portfolio. All of which, we expect to result in attractive FFO growth over these coming years. We have selected non-core assets for sale to ensure continued portfolio refreshments. We have significant entitled and unentitled landholding that we will continue to push through the design and permitting process and add selectively to our development pipeline in future years.
Our balance sheet is strong, with a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio below 6x and with the substantial portion of our upcoming debt maturities having now been either refinanced or hedged. This strong capital position will also allow us to pursue and act on investment opportunities that may present themselves in the coming quarter.
Now let me turn it over to Doug for a further review of our markets.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. The tone of the market color that I'm going to use this morning is pretty consistent with our last few calls. We have a few subtle changes but I wanted to sort of level set as to what I've said previously, and I'll d
componenttext:
Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. The tone of the market color that I'm going to use this morning is pretty consistent with our last few calls. We have a few subtle changes but I wanted to sort of level set as to what I've said previously, and I'll do that real quickly.
So what we've said before is that San Francisco has slowed from the phase it was going at in 2014 and 2015 and the Silicon Valley can be very active and actually has been expanding. New York is a good market but it's been impacted by growing supply and there's been some impact of the financial service market volatility on small tenant demand. So Washington D.C. is a challenged market and there's not much evidence of improvement. So the Reston area can be pretty active and there's little bit of growth there. And Boston suburban and Cambridge are seeing increasing demand while the CBD is a healthy market but it's really more driven by lease expirations and intermittent technology migration. So that sort of levels that what I'd said previously.
Let me start now with the Silicon Valley and given that Tucson way, which is parts of give you some sense of the thesis around on this site and our views of the Valley. So having sold individual place last quarter, our portfolio is unfortunately, it's pretty small down there. It's really comprised of 570,000 square feet of mountain view, single-story product where we actually completed another 89,000 square feet of leases this quarter with average starting rents of $50 triple net, which is more than double the expiring rents on that space. Then we have our standalone office building down in Mountain View, which is only 141,000 square feet. And we have our land redevelopment parcel on North First in San Jose. That's the totality of our portfolio down there.
The difficulty we've been having over the last 4, 5 years is finding high-quality buildings or sites within acceptable basis/return ratio. And the Peterson Way site offers an opportunity for us to deliver products in 2023 at a cost basis of under $700 a square-foot, and that assumes cost escalation on the cost side of the equation in terms of our building materials, labor, et cetera, and an initial return in excess of 7% at rents that are less than 10% above market rents today.
So we have a market whether it's 29 million square feet of gross leasing and user activity in 2015 and market size of about 240 million square feet. So it's a market we definitely want to be a part of and there was 11 million square feet of endorsement 2015. In the first quarter, there were another 8 leases over a 100,000 square feet each, including 275,000 square feet from Google, and another 200,000 square feet for Apple and those are clearly the 2 dominant users of space and it has its dramatic influence on the market but there are lots of other companies down there like Facebook and NVIDIA, and Broadcom, and VMware and Palo Alto Networks that are really leaders in their perspective fields and they are -- these are growing companies and what they're looking for is new, modern, efficient products to house their growth. So this is what we're going to hopefully build and this is the demand that we're going to satisfy.
Jumping over to the city. As we discussed in our call in January, we've seen velocity in the San Francisco CBD has moderated from the levels we saw in '14 and early '15. Actually, that's been a continuation into the beginning of 2016. I think the big difference between the market then, i.e., in '14 and '15, and today is really the lack of large growth requirements and by that, I mean, big tenants over 300,000 square feet. So at the moment, there's no 300,000 square feet or greater requirement that we are backing in the market. In '13, '14 and '15, you had unprecedented large growth from Google, in Dropbox, in Salesforce.com and Uber and Stride and flag and LinkedIn and they're just not there today. However, there continues to be lots of active tech demand and in the first quarter, AirBnB and Twilo and Comcast and Stripes all took down blocks over 100,000 square feet and just in April, Lift and FitFit and Uber have combined lease over 500,000 square feet and much of that actually is from the sublease market. So technology is still a vibrant part of the market. It's still expanding. It's just not quite in the same area than it was in '14 and '15. And interestingly, technology users now make up 31% of all of the space leased in the city of San Francisco.
The second change in the CBD market in San Francisco has been the velocity from start ups. If you look at debenture investing statistics, the seed in early stage investing is down by 22% quarter-to-quarter from prior year. And first time that it's actually down 31% and if you look at the cities sublist statistics, the overall level is very low at about the 1.4 million square feet but there are significant amounts of full floor availability between 12,000 and 15,000 square feet across the South financial in the Soma areas. This is the product that's most attractive to the startup community. Keep in mind that most sublet space has limited term so it's not competing with the lease expiration requirements from traditional tenants, which is where we are working at Embarcadero Center. So as you see, we completed another 128,000 square feet of leasing during the quarter, full floor tenants totaled 90,000 square feet at 128 and new tenants coming into Embarcadero Center totaled 85,000 square feet of that 128. The mark-to-market on these larger transactions is between about 40% and 70% on a gross basis, very consistent with what we've been seeing in the last couple of quarters and it's obviously a dramatic markup in our same-store statistics this quarter. The pipeline of leases that we have going in negotiation today at D.C. continues to be robust, 150,000 square feet of additional leases in negotiation, 66,000 square feet of that is either new tenant or extension. We also have active discussions with new tenant for additional 4 vacant floors totaling 100,000 square feet. So it's very, very busy at Embarcadero Center. I would say, however, that relative to end of 2015, what was actively described as strong as it has ever been in the history of our ownership, the pace of new tours has moderated a little bit.
We've signed additional leases for floors at Salesforce Tower, 108,000 square feet, which is in our system today. So occupancy is 59% and the next wave of these proposals are progressing and includes some single floor users as well as large tenants of between 2 and 4 floors. All of this discussion involved pending lease 2017 and '18 lease expirations. The steel on the core arising into the San Francisco skyline, and we hope to have our first tenant in occupancy in late 2017 or early 2018.
Now based on conversations we've had with shareholders and analysts recently, I think it's fair to say that there's been a prevalent concern about the next market I'm going to talk about, which is Midtown Manhattan. And our perspective has been pretty consistent since 2014 when we recognize there is going to be a supply issue from both new construction and the impending relocations that would impact lease economics. There continues to be good, not great leasing activity across the city and there are still tenant expansions across diversed industry groups, including examples of financial services companies within our portfolio there is today. Some of them were recent transactions in the marketplace from an extension perspective that included Facebook and CBS Broadcasting, Fox Media, Google, PricewaterhouseCoopers, Schroeders and Shout.
In January, we talked about the fact that the public capital market volatility was impacting the decision-making from small financial firms. In the first quarter, we're certainly a roller coaster for the debt and the equity markets. These conditions impact velocity at the high-end, which is predominantly a small financial services for demand pool. Across the market in the third quarter, there were 5 relocation transactions written at starting rents over $100 a square foot and that includes lease export 25 Park. So if you move -- remove the transaction, the average lease was 10,000 square feet. So 4 lease, 10,000 square feet on average. There was clearly a change in the market in the first quarter.
During the quarter, we completed 14 deals for about 173,000 square feet. Over 100,000 square feet of our demand at starting rents over $100 a square feet. They were all renewals and explore expansion. While we continue to see a constant and steady volume of leasing at between $80 and $120 per square feet, the velocity above $125 a square foot has slowed. These to this will leasing smaller units across the portfolio for a number of years, and we're going to take a very similar approach to the 2 General Motors floors we get back on July 1st. Subdividing them for smaller customers as required.
Our discussions regarding the entire FAO block continues to be very, very active. Given the magnitude of the commitment by the respective tenants, this will take some time, but we hope to have a firm signed lease later this year.
Last quarter, we announced our lease termination transaction at 250 West 55th Street. While we have not signed a lease on any of that space in the last 90 days, we have significant conversations underway for the entire second floor and a number of good operators have presented approvals for the ground floor space. So the activity on that exact is stronger than we anticipated.
At 399 Park, we're in lease negotiations with 2 existing tenants that would expand and permit to about 175,000 square feet of the city space rolling over in '17, 125,000 square feet of that demand represents expansions by these tenants. Now we've had some questions about the roll up and rolldown of the office space, the city is going to be living in '17 and our expectation is that it's going to be pretty moderate with a very slight roll up. So as an example, we completed the full floor extension on 1 of the floors that been in question and the roll up was about 3.75% on a gross basis, i.e., pretty flat. This quarter, our New York City portfolio, CBD portfolio had a roll up of over 35% on a gross basis. So clearly, 399 is one of the more moderate pieces of that. Now Mike needs some significant enhancements to our supplemental package this quarter and he is going to discuss those but the one I want to point out is that the delineation of our share of the portfolio NOI by market. In the case of our Washington, D.C. region, it illustrates what we've been saying for some time, which is that our Washington, D.C. CBD portfolio is 9.5% of the company's NOI. We've seen a number of comments suggesting that the D.C. office market has turned the corner. Our view is that there has been no remarkable change in the leasing environment. Most of the D.C. law firm have completed their new installations. Between '16 and 2019, we're tracking only 1 law firm expiration of over 100,000 square feet. The good news is that there's likelihood of little impact on any downsizing on the market. The bad news is that there's activity being generated from this sector. The GSA continues to be very -- take a very measured approach to their renewals and is now hunkering into what we refer to as election inertia, which contributes to pushing out decisions. In spite of the challenging environment, we did complete 117,000 square foot of lease that we worked at net square this quarter as well as get another 17,000 square feet of uncommitted space at 601 Matt Avenue lease.
This quarter, we also completed a 60,000 square feet renewal in Reston Town Center starting rents in the mid-50s and 5 smaller transactions totaling 17,000 square feet. Reston continues to be 97% leased. One green shoot in the Washington, D.C., Northern Virginia market place comes from a group of midsized technology tenants that have slowed this demanding. We have a few of these tenants in our Reston portfolio, some direct and actually some subtenants, and they are prime candidates for that next building in Town Center that I will mention.
The Boston region continues to be a magnet for life science industry and established tech companies as well as for startup technology and maker organizations. This has led to a continual improvement in leasing momentum in the greater Boston market this year. Leasing velocity in the Waltham Lexinton submarket in particular has accelerated during the last few months as a result of the type of demand and much of it is organic expansion. When we purchased a colony in 2011, there was about 50,000 square feet of technology tenants and no life science companies in the park. Today, we have over 500,000 square feet of these users and almost everyone of them is in an extension mode. This quarter, we completed another 179,000 square feet of our suburban portfolio and we have responded for more than 500,000 square feet of additional portfolio over the last month. Virtually every pharma company has put down a base in the Cambridge market and coupled with the growth of the biotech industry and the tech segments that are there, we have a market where the availability rate is under 5%. We are in active discussions, as Owen described, on a 100% of our recently permitted commercial density, which will likely involve terminating some leases and potentially taking down some existing buildings in order to accommodate the new growth. We expect to make our site specific applications this year with a potential construction commencement in early 2017. And again, as Owen said, it's part of this new development, we will also build additional residential high-rise product.
The Boston CBD continues to be a very steady market as supply have seen growth over the last two years so there isn't speculative development going on in Seaport area. While we do have a few technology tenants extending into the overall market, much of the demand is still lease expiration-driven. General Electric is going to be moving to accommodate the new construction, and rehab building currently owned by CNG and not utilizing existing inventory. This quarter, we completed over 525 -- 20,000 square feet of leasing and that includes the work that we did at 100, which is about 400,000 square feet of that. We also did 28,000 square feet at the top of 200 Clarendon, and a 50,000 square feet at Prudential Center.
Activity at 120 St. James, where we have 170,000 square feet of development has picked up dramatically and although we haven't signed any leases, we have a number of tenants reviewing their office at the building and they range from between 32,000 square feet, which should be partial floor to the entire 170,000 square foot block. All of those tenants would have occupancy in late '17 or early '18.
Last quarter, we provided a score card for our revenue bridge. We continue to make progress and with additional transactions this quarter, leasing at Embarcadero Center, the Prudential Tower, 200 Clarendon and 250 West 55th Street, we've accomplished about $48 million of that $80 million bridge.
And with that, I'll turn the floor over to Mike.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everybody. As Doug mentioned, we made some changes to our supplemental financial report this quarter that I'd like to go over. The purpose was really to more clearly reflect the characteristics and performance of our share of t
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everybody. As Doug mentioned, we made some changes to our supplemental financial report this quarter that I'd like to go over. The purpose was really to more clearly reflect the characteristics and performance of our share of the portfolio, given the sizable impacts of the consolidated joint ventures that we have put in place in the last couple of years.
In addition to delineating the geographic and tenant diversification in this manner, we've included supplemental information in our same property and in our light performance stages to include both the consolidated portfolio performance that we have historically provided as well as the performance of our share portfolio. You will also note that we folded our R&D segment into our office segment this quarter to the immaterial size of the R&D portfolio, especially after the sale of 415 Main Street in Cambridge during the first quarter.
Lastly, as Owen mentioned, we're embarking on several significant repositioning projects within the portfolio, which we consider nonrecurring in nature. In our capital expenditure disclosure in the supplemental, we're now segregating the capital spend for these projects, which our total budget approximately $155 million to be spent over the next few years.
Now turning to our results for the quarter. As you can see from our press release, we reported first quarter funds from operations of $1.63 per share, which is $0.03 per share or about $5 million higher than the midpoint of our guidance range. The performance of our portfolio has grown approximately $4 million of this out performance, with about half of it coming from faster than projected leasing activity. We continue to successfully execute early renewals at Embarcadero Center and in our Mountain View properties at a significant rent roll up that are straight lined into our revenues upon lease signing.
We also incurred earlier than projected occupancy from new leasing in smaller pieces across the portfolio. Approximately $2 million of the improvement resulted from lower than projected operating expenses that stems from warmer than normal weather conditions in the Northeast, which reduced our utilities expense a little bit as well as the deferral of repair and maintenance expenses that we project to be incurred later this year.
On development and management services fee income, we're approximately $1 million ahead of our projected -- projection. The majority relates to higher than anticipated service income generated in the portfolio. We also signed an agreement to act as development manager for the tenant that acquired our former Innovation Place project in North San Jose, and we will earn a multi-year development fee for once they commence this quarter.
Our first quarter same property performance was solid, with a combined portfolio of cash NOI up 5.6% and GAAP NOI of 1.5% from the first quarter last year. As I mentioned, the company share of NOI growth differs from the combined results and if you pull out the noncontrolling interest share, our share of the portfolio performance is even better. This quarter, our share of cash NOI growth was 7% and GAAP NOI growth was 2.8% from 2015, which is the new level of detail we provided on Page 41 of the supplemental under the heading Adjusted Combined.
As we look out to the remainder of 2016, we project our same property growth to moderate through the year. Our same property cash NOI growth will be impacted by free rent that was in place in the first quarter of 2015 but burned up during the year. And both GAAP and cash NOI would be negatively impacted by the pending vacancy of 70,000 square feet in the mid-rise at 767 Fifth Avenue and 150,000 square feet at 601 Lexington Avenue where we completed a series of lease terminations and relocations that will allow us to redevelop the low-rise buildings starting later this year. We expect this portion of building to be out of service for about 2 years. The redevelopment will result in a longer period of downtime but in late 2018, when we've reintroduced the new retail and low rise building to the market, we expect it will enhance the long-term value and future cash flow from the building.
Our leasing activity in the portfolio is steady and generally in line with our prior projections. Overall, we modestly increased our combined same-property NOI growth projections for GAAP NOI, and we still project roughly breakeven growth in 2015, and we continue to expect our combined same property cash NOI growth to be 1% to 3% from 2015. Again, when you remove the noncontrolling interest share from the consolidated portfolio, our share of growth for both GAAP and cash is projected to be 100 basis points higher. The increase in our NOI projection is reflected in our guidance for noncash straight line rents, which is now $40 million to $55 million for the full year.
We acquired Peterson Way this quarter with a plan to complete entitlement and develop the site in the future. In the meantime, the building is 100% leased for the next 5 years and it's projected to generate approximately a 4.6% cash return and a 5.8% GAAP return. As a result, we've increased our 2016 guidance for the incremental NOI contribution from our non-same property portfolio. That includes our new development and our acquisitions to $38 million to $44 million. The projected 2016 incremental contribution from this development and acquisitions for 2015 represents 3% year-over-year growth on our share of the total portfolio NOI.
We also increased our guidance for development and management services income by $2 million at the midpoint and now project services income of $22 million to $26 million for the year. The impact of these changes result in our increasing our guidance range for 2016 funds from operations to $5.85 to $5.95 per share. This is an increase of $0.05 per share at the midpoint, consisting of $0.02 per share from better projected portfolio performance, $0.02 from acquisitions and $0.01 from higher projected development and management services income.
That concludes our formal remarks, and I'll appreciate it if the operator would open up the line for any question.

And hopefully, over time, the seats of New York will have a demand generator that allows us to start that will be with a significant preleasing commitment associated with it. I think that the challenge with New York City and I'll let John Powers comment on this, is that while there are plenty of tenants who are paying about $100 a square foot, there are not a lot of big tenants that would be anchor tenants that would be paid over $100 a square feet in size. And so I think the market has to be naturally positioned to accommodate the demand that is there as opposed to hope that simply rising rents will be achieved by the traditional large scaled tenant demand that the city currently sees. John, you want to comment anymore?

componenttext: So the challenge with our preleasings spread is that they're so dependent upon the particular portion of the portfolio that's rolling over in any onetime. And so we may have a quarter where we have more -- much more significant growth then we may have a quarter where we have a much more muted perspective because of the specifics associated with again, the granularity of that. In general, the more dominant quarter is relative to its San Francisco roll over, the higher the numbers will be because on average, there is -- there's probably somewhere around a 50% or 55% mark-to-market on virtually everything that we are doing in Embarcadero Center. So as that gets a larger portion of each particular quarter, that's what's driving it. And then I think the second area would be our New York portfolio at new General Motors Building we have significant embedded upside so but those things rolled over into the market, you're going to see a much higher number and then our Cambridge portfolio where there's a significant embedded ups and those are sort of the 3 portions of the market, there when they hit the in any one quarter, we will push it in the right direction.

componenttext: I think the amount of debt will be able to get will be at least equal to what is aware and it'll all be senior. We won't need to use them as an index of that to that level. The cash flow of that property has grown pretty dramatically over the last 10 years that we owned it as we've rolled up rents pretty constantly over that time frame and there's still under rented from the REIT perspectives of net underwriting perspective, lenders will be constable within cash flow characteristics and the future cash flow characteristics. It's obviously a large loan. So that's the biggest challenge with it. Is that the current financing is $1.6 billion. It's actually going to good for the CMBS market. CMBS market can easily handle a loan of that size typically. With that market has been a little bit more volatile over the last 6 to 9 months. Although I would say that most of the volatility is when you start to get into the higher leverage points. So you're talking about a loan that is 40% to 50% leveraged, that market is more is a better place to be in today than different talking about a loan that is 60% to 65% leveraged. So we could freeness of these loans today in the CMBS market based upon the leverage points that we have. The existing loans indicative of a bunch of mechanician was company is also possible to execute in that type of environment where you will have somebody help you to put together a large syndicate so I think there's of different ways for us to tackle it. It doesn't expire until the end of '17. So obviously, there's time, but to me but in some hedges for about 1/3 of the exposure at this point. So that's kind of where I see that standing.

componenttext: So bad debt on a cash basis is 6% debt. On a non-GAAP basis, because of the -- when we consolidated this thing, the GAAP there is about 3%. I would say the CMBS market today for 50% financing is somewhere in the high 3s to 4.25. And as you go up leverage it toward 60%, it kind of gets to that 4.5 level. So there's a significant reduction, I would see, from a cash interest basis based upon current interest rates.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's quote change, but I do think it is shifting gradually. In terms of your question about the cycle, obviously, it's difficult for us to predict exactly when the cycle will end and then will have the next recession there and our people pre
componenttext: I don't think it's quote change, but I do think it is shifting gradually. In terms of your question about the cycle, obviously, it's difficult for us to predict exactly when the cycle will end and then will have the next recession there and our people predicting it in the near term. I don't think we're quite as concerned about a near-term recession. But as I mentioned in my remarks, growth is clearly slow and I think we anticipate that and continuing here for some period of time. But we're not blind to the prospects of a recession in the -- certainly, in the medium term. And then what, I mean, by seeing a shift, I do think our thinking about launching a new development is a shifting. I think our requirement is higher. It's difficult for us to say precisely that we need ex percent of our building pre-Let to launch it because it depends a lot on other factors like where is the tenant coming from, was the size of the building, elimination of the market at that time so we don't set the status of fixed hurdles. But I do think as we look at our portfolio, and we look at projects that we want to launch, a pre-let requirement is clearly required. And I mentioned in my remarks, 3 projects that we're looking at now for 2016. And we're not going to launch any of them without some kind of significant preletting.

But looking at your portfolio mix, New York is a still a pretty big component of BXP relative to the West Coast and when we look at where the credit of the economic growth as coalitions development coming out of the Bay Area versus New York. So should we expect more and more of the investment to be out West? Or should we expect it to be as it's been right now where, yes, we are in the others West Coast investment announcement at the same time you have sort of a New York investment announcement as well?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Alex, the -- we certainly think about our portfolio mix and our balance across the various regions as we think about making new investments and building developments. And for that reason, if you pro forma what we're going to look like over the next few
componenttext: So Alex, the -- we certainly think about our portfolio mix and our balance across the various regions as we think about making new investments and building developments. And for that reason, if you pro forma what we're going to look like over the next few years, the San Francisco component of our overall results is going to grow materially, primarily driven by the sales of the delivery of the Salesforce Tower but also by some of the other projects that we delivered last year like 680, 690 admission so forth. So it has been a conscious effort. And I think it's going to continue to be a conscious effort that we're going to grow our company in areas where there's the greatest tenant demand, which today is technology, life sciences. So the answer to your question is yes, but I would also say that the investments that we make are also opportunity-driven. So our teams and each of the regions worked vigorously on identifying new investments, on switching our development pipeline forward and so that the we think about it top-down the actual allocation are also driven by a worthy opportunities present itself.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean Alex, if you take Salesforce Tower, it's a 1.4 million square feet, and if average gross rents in there is in the mid-80s, you're talking about $115, $120 million of additional revenue, which is a significant jump in the overall percentage that San
componenttext: I mean Alex, if you take Salesforce Tower, it's a 1.4 million square feet, and if average gross rents in there is in the mid-80s, you're talking about $115, $120 million of additional revenue, which is a significant jump in the overall percentage that San Francisco have when the building is fully in-service in 2018, early 2019. I also think that and I think we've been pretty consistent in our description of this switch is we're demand-oriented company. We're looking to serve those users who are growing and where the demand is being generated and at the extent that there is more demand end-users that are sort of technology-oriented and happen to be in the West Coast, we're going to see everything we can to service those companies. On the other hand, New York City and the Boston and the Cambridge marketplace, which marketplaces the sound of the northern Virginia, also have a pretty interesting future demand pool that we are going to try and serve as best we can as well. And so I think that we are going to be aggressive about making investments that all of those places where we think there's an opportunity to find tenants who are growing and we're looking for high-quality office space.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll make a few comments and then I'll let Bob and Owen chime in. So the first is that the Google and Apple are by far the most dominant users of office space in the Silicon Valley. And their headquarters is in the Silicon Valley, and I think there's a
componenttext: So I'll make a few comments and then I'll let Bob and Owen chime in. So the first is that the Google and Apple are by far the most dominant users of office space in the Silicon Valley. And their headquarters is in the Silicon Valley, and I think there's absolutely no expectation that's going to change. I also think that the number of people who are living in the city of San Francisco and that our using commuter-oriented transit mostly in the form of private buses to get to those campuses down to the Silicon Valley is very, very significant. And so I think that the "value of the affordable housing" is less critical to the growth of the Silicon Valley than the natural establishment of those campuses and those businesses in terms of historically where they've been and their ability to still be able to attract labor from the urban market if they're looking for younger, more transit-oriented types of opportunities. Bob, any other thoughts?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I would just say I don't think the housing prices in the Silicon Valley have anything to do with the growth. I think all the growth is organic growth were there growing and getting bigger. If there were looking about residential values, they would move to the East Bay because that's the cheapest towns in the Bay Area.
