componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jed Reagan with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned seeing a slowdown in high-end tenant demand in New York City this past quarter. Just with some of the market volatility settling down the past couple of months, are you seeing signs of those types of tenants getting more active again?
componenttext: You mentioned seeing a slowdown in high-end tenant demand in New York City this past quarter. Just with some of the market volatility settling down the past couple of months, are you seeing signs of those types of tenants getting more active again?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll start, and I'll let John comment. So I actually -- I talked to a handful of brokers in the third week in January, and then I talked to them again last week. And I think to describe their personality is it's somewhat manic on the good and the bad.
componenttext: So I'll start, and I'll let John comment. So I actually -- I talked to a handful of brokers in the third week in January, and then I talked to them again last week. And I think to describe their personality is it's somewhat manic on the good and the bad. And the number of tours that is occurring right now in the greater midtown, small tenant market is significantly accelerated versus where it was when the Dow and the credit markets were a little bit more in turmoil. John, you have any other perspective?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mentioned on the last call that we had this in August and the beginning of September when the equity markets had a lot of jitters and spread and widened in the bond market. And we had the same thing happen in January. But it didn't stick with the le
componenttext: No. I mentioned on the last call that we had this in August and the beginning of September when the equity markets had a lot of jitters and spread and widened in the bond market. And we had the same thing happen in January. But it didn't stick with the leasing market in the fall, and I don't think it's going to stick with the leasing market now. Certainly, on the high-end, financial hedge funds, et cetera, they're very, very close to that market. And when there's issues there, they have concerns.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just switching to D.C., can you talk about your outlook for D.C. beyond 2016 as far as leasing activity and rent growth is concerned? Do you think that's a market that turns the corner in a noticeable way in '17 and '18, let's sa
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just switching to D.C., can you talk about your outlook for D.C. beyond 2016 as far as leasing activity and rent growth is concerned? Do you think that's a market that turns the corner in a noticeable way in '17 and '18, let's say, following the election?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take a crack at it, then Peter can add to it. What we lack in D.C. that you hear in the other markets are kind of unexpected demand drivers. Right now, we're still predominantly a lease expiration-driven market. So we can look in advance and see
componenttext: Yes, I'll take a crack at it, then Peter can add to it. What we lack in D.C. that you hear in the other markets are kind of unexpected demand drivers. Right now, we're still predominantly a lease expiration-driven market. So we can look in advance and see where the demand's coming from, from our existing tenants. And this matchup relative supply is pretty equal. In other words, we're not going to see a tremendous increase in vacancy, nor are we going to go see a tightness. It's a pretty balanced picture right now. But what we really need is for this election to take place, clear the slate and look at some technology and some other demand drivers coming to the marketplace. Until that additional demand comes, we're going to be a pretty status quo market. Peter, do you have anything to add?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would certainly say that's true in relation to the election. I do think looking at the job growth numbers and looking at where the GSA has been, they've been shedding net jobs. And that has stabilized in the last 12 months. And they're actually starting
componenttext: I would certainly say that's true in relation to the election. I do think looking at the job growth numbers and looking at where the GSA has been, they've been shedding net jobs. And that has stabilized in the last 12 months. And they're actually starting to add jobs again, which I think will be a positive. But as is always the case, the money won't start to flow until after the election for those things.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I wonder, Doug, just more generally, you guys talked about the development pipeline, but can you just talk more about where you think we are in the cycle and how that pertains to the shadow development pipeline? Has your level of comfort going ahe
componenttext: I guess I wonder, Doug, just more generally, you guys talked about the development pipeline, but can you just talk more about where you think we are in the cycle and how that pertains to the shadow development pipeline? Has your level of comfort going ahead with any of those projects changed as we've come through the cycle? And how do you think about the importance of pre-leasing at this point?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think its quote changed, but I do think it is shifting gradually. In terms of your question about the cycle, obviously, it's difficult for us to predict exactly when the cycle will end and when we'll have the next recession. There are a number of
componenttext: I don't think its quote changed, but I do think it is shifting gradually. In terms of your question about the cycle, obviously, it's difficult for us to predict exactly when the cycle will end and when we'll have the next recession. There are a number of people predicting it in the nearer term. I don't think we're quite as concerned about a near-term recession. But as I mentioned in my remarks, growth is clearly slow, and I think we anticipate that continuing here for some period of time. But we're not blind to the prospects of a recession in the -- certainly in the medium term. And then what I mean by saying a shift, I do think our thinking about launching new developments is shifting. I think our pre-let requirement is higher. It's difficult for us to say precisely that we need x percent of a building pre-let to launch it because it depends a lot on other factors, like where is the tenant coming from? What's the size of the building? What's the nature of the market at the time? So we don't set those kinds of fixed hurdles. But I do think as we look at our portfolio and we look at projects that we want to launch, a pre-let requirement is clearly required. And I mentioned in my remarks, 3 projects that we're looking at now for 2016. And we're not going to launch any of them without some kind of significant pre-letting.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then it sounds like you are progressing well with the tenant for the FAO space. Can you give any estimate as to the potential NOI upside versus kind of the temporary tenant that you have there and maybe even versus what FAO was p
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then it sounds like you are progressing well with the tenant for the FAO space. Can you give any estimate as to the potential NOI upside versus kind of the temporary tenant that you have there and maybe even versus what FAO was paying?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been reticent to talk about the specific economics of the deal. We've talked in sort of big-picture perspective about the income that's being generated by the overall retail space in the past at the General Motors Building. I think it's -- we've sai
componenttext: We've been reticent to talk about the specific economics of the deal. We've talked in sort of big-picture perspective about the income that's being generated by the overall retail space in the past at the General Motors Building. I think it's -- we've said in the past that if you could figure out from our disclosure that the rent that FAO was paying was about $20 million a year. And we think the number is significantly higher than that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug or Owen, when we look at your occupancy by market, there's a real bifurcation in a couple places between the CBDs and the suburbans, and I'm just wondering if you could sort of comment. On Princeton, it's 75% occupied today versus your New York, whic
componenttext: Doug or Owen, when we look at your occupancy by market, there's a real bifurcation in a couple places between the CBDs and the suburbans, and I'm just wondering if you could sort of comment. On Princeton, it's 75% occupied today versus your New York, which is 95%. You've obviously got a few things you talked about down in South San Francisco that may get cleared up. But then when you look at kind of the Washington portfolio, you're doing well in D.C., specifically in Reston, but then suburban Maryland. Just how do you think about those markets in particular? And maybe Ray can comment on the Annapolis Junction, which just doesn't seem to be getting much traction on the leasing front.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me take a quick stab at that, Steve, because it's a fair question. So the good news is that the occupancy number that you were describing and the contribution from the properties that are in that occupancy number is significantly under-weighted.
componenttext: Sure. Let me take a quick stab at that, Steve, because it's a fair question. So the good news is that the occupancy number that you were describing and the contribution from the properties that are in that occupancy number is significantly under-weighted. In other words, if it were leased, the relative rent that it would achieve is de minimis relative to the rents that we're achieving in our CBD properties. So as an example, the Washington, D.C. vacancy is in our VA 95 product. And it's interesting. It's actually the first time in the 20-some-odd years that we've had significant availability in that particular part. But the net rents -- or the net rents that we're achieving are $13 a square foot. The big pieces of availability in our portfolio are at Tower Center in New Brunswick, which is in excess of 300,000 square feet of that availability, and then the property in South San Francisco at Gateway. So if you pull those 3 out, the VA 95 couple, the Gateway and the Tower Center, you have a very different picture. But it is true that the majority of our challenged space is in the suburban marketplace.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, Doug, it just seems like it takes a lot of management effort for maybe not a lot of reward. And I guess, is it worth longer-term keeping it versus focusing your efforts on other things in the portfolio?
componenttext: Yes. I guess, Doug, it just seems like it takes a lot of management effort for maybe not a lot of reward. And I guess, is it worth longer-term keeping it versus focusing your efforts on other things in the portfolio?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Steve, it's a great point. It's a debate we constantly have as a management team. So I described a lot of investor enthusiasm for real estate, but it's primarily for leased buildings in our core markets. And there's less investor enthusiasm for unlease
componenttext: So Steve, it's a great point. It's a debate we constantly have as a management team. So I described a lot of investor enthusiasm for real estate, but it's primarily for leased buildings in our core markets. And there's less investor enthusiasm for unleased buildings in suburban markets. So our trade-off is we don't want to sell assets just to sell them at deeply discounted prices. We want to perform the real estate skill, lease the buildings and get a proper price for them. But -- and I would say, if you go back and look at the asset sales that we've done, clearly, we've done some of the large joint ventures on the urban assets. But mixed in with that, if you go back over the last couple of years, we have sold noncore assets in some of our suburban locations in Boston and in Washington, D.C. And also, as Doug said, one other thing I just want to clarify, when you talked about the Princeton vacancy, the Carnegie vacancy is -- the currency occupancy is 86%, all resident in Tower Center, as Doug described.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, any comment from Ray on just the Annapolis Junction that just doesn't seem to be getting a lot of traction at this point?
componenttext: And I guess, any comment from Ray on just the Annapolis Junction that just doesn't seem to be getting a lot of traction at this point?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll be glad to take a crack at that, Steve. First of all, again, we only own 50% of those buildings with our partners, the Goulds. And we're seeing the NSA demand be focused more back on the base as opposed to reaching out to satellite office locat
componenttext: Well, I'll be glad to take a crack at that, Steve. First of all, again, we only own 50% of those buildings with our partners, the Goulds. And we're seeing the NSA demand be focused more back on the base as opposed to reaching out to satellite office locations. And the MegaCenter, which was the main driver for the Annapolis Junction project, they're changing their use of that. That was like a WeWork for spies. I mean, it was a scenario where people would come in to have temporary occupancy. Those requirements are also getting moved back on the base. So we are seeing a slowdown in the demand. But again, our presence there is relatively small on a relative basis to the overall Boston Properties enterprise.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, just one last question for Bob Pester. I know this is hard. You say there's not a lot of large requirements in the marketplace today. But what we've heard from brokers in the past is a lot of these larger requirements are sort of stealt
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just one last question for Bob Pester. I know this is hard. You say there's not a lot of large requirements in the marketplace today. But what we've heard from brokers in the past is a lot of these larger requirements are sort of stealthily done, maybe on their way from the brokerage firm or directly with some landlords. Any perspective you can just sort of offer on that today? I realize if they're not on a brokerage list, then maybe they're not in the market or you would know about them, but how should we think about that?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's a bunch of baloney, Steve. We haven't seen that through the years we've been in this marketplace, where some megadeal happens that nobody knew about.
componenttext: Yes. I think that's a bunch of baloney, Steve. We haven't seen that through the years we've been in this marketplace, where some megadeal happens that nobody knew about.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: So yes, my question was kind of along the same lines, just regarding the Annapolis Junction. I realize it's 50% owned, but had a huge loan-to-value in place, $339 a square foot. That, we assume, is being relocated on base. Is that what you were referring to, Ray?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Basically, Erin, that they seem to be more concerned about security now more than ever. And so the outreach to, again, third-party space providers is not as great as it was before. We still have a strong presence there. We're pretty well occupied in
componenttext: Yes. Basically, Erin, that they seem to be more concerned about security now more than ever. And so the outreach to, again, third-party space providers is not as great as it was before. We still have a strong presence there. We're pretty well occupied in the other buildings other than the MegaCenter. And if Mike wants to talk about the debt, you could go ahead and ask questions to him.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, that's fine. And then that was on AJ 1, where the big debt was in place. On AJ 7, there was a 1-year extension done on the loan there, which is much more reasonable, 170,000 a square foot, but is there a lack of demand? I mean, that's a 100% le
componenttext: Okay. Yes, that's fine. And then that was on AJ 1, where the big debt was in place. On AJ 7, there was a 1-year extension done on the loan there, which is much more reasonable, 170,000 a square foot, but is there a lack of demand? I mean, that's a 100% leased asset, but is there some expectation that, that tenancy goes away as well?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a short-term lease. And no, there is no anticipated vacancy there. We just decided to stay short and kind of evaluate the overall position as we go forward.
componenttext: Well, it's a short-term lease. And no, there is no anticipated vacancy there. We just decided to stay short and kind of evaluate the overall position as we go forward.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That lease is actually, as Ray has correctly stated, a 1-year lease. However, the government invested about $40 million in technology in that building. And for better or worse, the nature of that park, those 1-year leases are just the way they get allocat
componenttext: That lease is actually, as Ray has correctly stated, a 1-year lease. However, the government invested about $40 million in technology in that building. And for better or worse, the nature of that park, those 1-year leases are just the way they get allocated funding. So what they do is basically give you a 1-year deal and then 9 1-year extensions. So we have every expectation that they're going to stay in that space.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. And then how much did the government invest in the One Annapolis Junction asset?
componenttext: Yes, okay. And then how much did the government invest in the One Annapolis Junction asset?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, we put the bulk of that investment in. And as Ray described it, it really was a plug-and-play skiff with raised flooring, all the way down to the desktop computers and a 24-hour operating entity in there, which was first SAIC and is now Leidos,
componenttext: Actually, we put the bulk of that investment in. And as Ray described it, it really was a plug-and-play skiff with raised flooring, all the way down to the desktop computers and a 24-hour operating entity in there, which was first SAIC and is now Leidos, one of their successor entities, with a staffed help desk 24/7. And as Ray indicated, what happened, having met with the director of logistics and facilities early in this part of the year -- earlier this year rather, they've had a couple of security issues up there. There was a facility outside the base. There was obviously the Edward Snowden incident. And it has, I think, scared them into moving certain requirements on base when they've been able to do that. We're in the process now with Leidos of throttling back based on our conversations with the logistics folks from NSA, the level of services that we've been providing to a number that we can adjust the rent downward and take that part out of the operating expense, if you will. So where we've been leasing space there in the $120 to $130 range. We just did a deal at $95, which quite frankly, if we can continue to do deals at that rate, I think we can put the building back on a pretty sound footing.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is there any indication in the size of the amount of square footing going back on base in total?
componenttext: Okay. Is there any indication in the size of the amount of square footing going back on base in total?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: They didn't really share that information with us.
componenttext: They didn't really share that information with us.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to San Francisco here for a second. I know we can talk about it quite a bit. But just curious, it does look like you've got some leasing done at Salesforce Tower. Can you just comment on -- I think you said that you're hoping for another 1
componenttext: Just going back to San Francisco here for a second. I know we can talk about it quite a bit. But just curious, it does look like you've got some leasing done at Salesforce Tower. Can you just comment on -- I think you said that you're hoping for another 100,000 square foot or so in the next couple of quarters. Just curious, who's taking the space there today? Obviously, the larger guys are not out there, but where is demand coming from today?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- we've talked about this in the past. And it hasn't changed, but I want to just reiterate that. So all of the demand that we are seeing at Salesforce Tower is really lease expiration-driven demand. I mean, there may be a couple of tenants that ar
componenttext: So the -- we've talked about this in the past. And it hasn't changed, but I want to just reiterate that. So all of the demand that we are seeing at Salesforce Tower is really lease expiration-driven demand. I mean, there may be a couple of tenants that aren't in the market or a floor that have asked for a presentation, but it is a truly representative FIRREA-oriented group of tenants that are looking for high-quality, brand-new, visible, state-of-the-art office space. So it's brokerage firms, consulting firms, accounting firms, lawyers, investment professionals, asset managers, venture capitalists. That's sort of the laundry list of the types of users, who are the most likely tenants to be in that building that, remember, the first available floor is now 32. And so you're in the high rise of a high-rise office building in the pinnacle location in San Francisco.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe going back to the East Coast, just any comment you can provide on Penn Station redevelopment, your interest and maybe the process from here?
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe going back to the East Coast, just any comment you can provide on Penn Station redevelopment, your interest and maybe the process from here?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: John?
componenttext: John?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not bidding on the Penn Station redevelopment. We've looked at it carefully. There's 2 opportunities. One is Penn Station, and the other is the Farley building. It's very complex. Both of them are very complex. Penn is primarily exclusively a retail
componenttext: We're not bidding on the Penn Station redevelopment. We've looked at it carefully. There's 2 opportunities. One is Penn Station, and the other is the Farley building. It's very complex. Both of them are very complex. Penn is primarily exclusively a retail play. And Farley is a combination of retail, probably summer hotel and office. But it's very complex. And as I said, we analyzed it carefully and decided not to participate.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions here. First, you guys obviously spoke a lot about Midtown and what's going on, and then also the growth at West. But looking at your portfolio mix, New York is still a pretty big component of BXP relative to the West Coast. And if we look
componenttext: Just 2 questions here. First, you guys obviously spoke a lot about Midtown and what's going on, and then also the growth at West. But looking at your portfolio mix, New York is still a pretty big component of BXP relative to the West Coast. And if we look at where a lot of the economic growth is, there seems to be a lot more coming out of the Bay Area versus New York. So should we expect more and more of the investment to be out West? Or should we expect it to be, as it's been right now, where, yes, there's a West Coast investment announcement and, at the same time, you have sort of a New York investment announcement as well?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Alex, the -- we certainly think about our portfolio mix and our balance across the various regions as we think about making new investments in buildings or in developments. And for that reason, if you pro forma what we're going to look like over the ne
componenttext: So Alex, the -- we certainly think about our portfolio mix and our balance across the various regions as we think about making new investments in buildings or in developments. And for that reason, if you pro forma what we're going to look like over the next few years, the San Francisco component of our overall results is going to grow materially, primarily driven by the sales of the delivery of the Salesforce Tower, but also by some of the other projects that we delivered last year, like 680, 690, 535 Mission and so forth. So it has been a conscious effort. And I think it's going to continue to be a conscious effort that we're going to grow our company in areas where there's the greatest tenant demand, which today is technology and life sciences. So the answer to your question is yes, but I would also say that the investments that we make are also opportunity-driven. So our teams in each of the regions worked feverishly on identifying new investment, on pushing our development pipeline forward. And so that the -- that we think about it top-down. The actual allocations are also driven by where the opportunities present themselves.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, Alex, just if you take Salesforce Tower, right, it's 1.4 million square feet. And if the average gross rent in there is in the mid-80s, you're talking about $115 million, $120 million of additional revenue, which is a significant jump in the overa
componenttext: I mean, Alex, just if you take Salesforce Tower, right, it's 1.4 million square feet. And if the average gross rent in there is in the mid-80s, you're talking about $115 million, $120 million of additional revenue, which is a significant jump in the overall percentage that San Francisco will have when the building is fully in-service in 2018 or early 2019. I also think that -- and I think we've been pretty consistent in our description of this, which is: We're a demand-oriented company. We're looking to serve those users, who are growing, and where the demand is being generated. And to the extent that there is more demand and users that are sort of technology-oriented, and they happen to be in the West Coast, we're going to do everything we can to service those companies. On the other hand, New York City and the Boston and the Cambridge marketplaces and, to some degree, Northern Virginia also have a pretty interesting future demand pool that we are going to try and serve as best we can as well. And so I think that we are going to be aggressive about making investments in all of those places, where we think there's an opportunity to find tenants, who are growing, and who are looking for a high-quality office space.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is, I think in your opening comments, you said the activity down in the Silicon Valley area is much more active than in San Francisco. Is that -- did I hear correctly?
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is, I think in your opening comments, you said the activity down in the Silicon Valley area is much more active than in San Francisco. Is that -- did I hear correctly?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if you look at the activity in the Silicon Valley in 2015, it dwarfed what went on in San Francisco.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, if you look at the activity in the Silicon Valley in 2015, it dwarfed what went on in San Francisco.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So then my question is, how much of that is just where businesses are growing because of what's happening internally in the business versus there may be easier access to "cheaper, more affordable housing" that's causing people to maybe -- down South
componenttext: Okay. So then my question is, how much of that is just where businesses are growing because of what's happening internally in the business versus there may be easier access to "cheaper, more affordable housing" that's causing people to maybe -- down South, maybe there's San Jose or South of there, there's more affordable housing for people versus the explosive residential rent growth that's been in San Francisco. So how much of it has been employee-driven versus business-driven?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll make a few comments, and then I'll let Bob and Owen chime in. So the first is that the Google and Apple are by far the most dominant users of office space in the Silicon Valley. And their headquarters is in the Silicon Valley, and I think there's
componenttext: So I'll make a few comments, and then I'll let Bob and Owen chime in. So the first is that the Google and Apple are by far the most dominant users of office space in the Silicon Valley. And their headquarters is in the Silicon Valley, and I think there's absolutely no expectation that that's going to change. I also think that the number of people, who are living in the city of San Francisco, and that our using commuter-oriented transit, mostly in the form of private buses to get to those campuses down in the Silicon Valley, is very, very significant. And so I think that the "value of the affordable housing" is less critical to the growth of the Silicon Valley than the natural establishment of those campuses and those businesses in terms of historically where they've been and their ability to still be able to attract labor from the urban market if they're looking for younger, more transit-oriented types of opportunities. Bob, any other thoughts?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just say I don't think the housing prices in the Silicon Valley have anything to do with the growth. I think all the growth is organic growth, where they're growing and getting bigger. If they were looking about residential values, they would
componenttext: Yes. I would just say I don't think the housing prices in the Silicon Valley have anything to do with the growth. I think all the growth is organic growth, where they're growing and getting bigger. If they were looking about residential values, they would move it to the East Bay because that's the cheapest housing in the Bay Area.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's one heck of a commute.
componenttext: And that's one heck of a commute.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tom Lesnick with Capital One Securities.

componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. First, I understand it's a relatively small segment of your overall business, but it looks like the multifamily and hotel segment has been dragging on same-store NOI the last little bit here. What's your prognosis for that segment going forward?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on the same-store side, our hotel was down a little bit. That drove it this quarter. The challenge is it's to such a small portfolio that any kind of little change has an impact. And also, if you look at the residential page of our supplemental, t
componenttext: I think on the same-store side, our hotel was down a little bit. That drove it this quarter. The challenge is it's to such a small portfolio that any kind of little change has an impact. And also, if you look at the residential page of our supplemental, the Avenue is in one year and not in the other. So you really have to look at the same-store base, which is not as -- it's not as bad because that excludes the Avenue, which was sold during the year. The Avant and the Atlantic Wharf property, rest of the Wharf, have both stayed very, very well occupied year-to-year and continue to improve.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would also just add, we are interested in continuing to grow our residential portfolio, primarily through development. And if you look at our active development pipeline and our predevelopment pipeline, we have a number of projects that we anti
componenttext: Yes. And I would also just add, we are interested in continuing to grow our residential portfolio, primarily through development. And if you look at our active development pipeline and our predevelopment pipeline, we have a number of projects that we anticipate, under construction now, where we anticipate building. We talked a little bit about Reston, certainly in Cambridge, North Station, there's several examples of this around the company.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then maybe one for Ray. It looks like you guys are introducing paid parking at Reston Town Center. Just wondering, is it possible for you to quantify the incremental revenue opportunity there? And are there any other opportunities across the entire portfolio, where you could also realize upside potential?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Peter address that. He's way more political than I on those types of investments. So go ahead, Peter.
componenttext: I'll let Peter address that. He's way more political than I on those types of investments. So go ahead, Peter.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we want to get into necessarily quantifying it. I would say that there's approximately 8,000 parking spaces there. We undertook this for a couple of reasons. Obviously, revenue is one. But we've got a circumstance where we have to cont
componenttext: Well, I don't think we want to get into necessarily quantifying it. I would say that there's approximately 8,000 parking spaces there. We undertook this for a couple of reasons. Obviously, revenue is one. But we've got a circumstance where we have to control that to honor our obligations with both the retailers and the office tenants there, and people in adjacent residential parking in our spaces, so to speak, as well as commuters doing the same thing. And part of implementing it now is we've got enough of a runway that with the introduction of Metro proximate to Town Center probably in about 3, 3.5 years, we want to be in a position where this system is up and running. It's going to be a license plate recognition system. You'll be using an app to park there. And we think it's going to be a pretty significant enhancement for our customer base coming to the Town Center.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: One point I would like to make is we talked to some other major retailers about the experience of implementing paid parking, and after the fact they actually noted an increase in sales of up to 10% of the retailers because the people who do come to the ma
componenttext: One point I would like to make is we talked to some other major retailers about the experience of implementing paid parking, and after the fact they actually noted an increase in sales of up to 10% of the retailers because the people who do come to the malls now find it way more convenient and, as a result, spend more time there and spend more dollars. So we view it as a great thing for our retailers and our office tenants. And the income we get will certainly be helpful, but by no means the main driver.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have time for one final question, and that question comes from Craig Mailman with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We have time for one final question, and that question comes from Craig Mailman with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

componenttext: Just curious going back to San Francisco, your commentary on it being a little bit slower. Just curious if that's filtered in, impact at all, rent level discussions as you're trying to fill up the rest of Salesforce.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It actually hasn't. The overall availability in San Francisco, I think, is under 6% right now. And I think what we have done is we have tried to price all of our product appropriately for the market. We are not striving to set records for the sake of sett
componenttext: It actually hasn't. The overall availability in San Francisco, I think, is under 6% right now. And I think what we have done is we have tried to price all of our product appropriately for the market. We are not striving to set records for the sake of setting records. Where we think we are hitting the market bid, and we're doing it pretty consistently, it's because we're asking a true, honest market price that both the tenant and the landlord feel good about. And so we've not seen any diminution in our pricing component of our concession package and rental rate economics over the past 3 to 4 months.

Okay. So that concludes the questions and our formal remarks. Thank you for your time this morning and your interest in Boston Properties.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Boston Properties Second Quarter Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Ms. Arista Joyner, Investor Relations Manager for Boston Properties
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Boston Properties Second Quarter Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Ms. Arista Joyner, Investor Relations Manager for Boston Properties. Please, go ahead.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties' Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night, as well as furnished [indiscernible] 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconci
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Boston Properties' Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and supplemental package were distributed last night, as well as furnished [indiscernible] 8-K. In the supplemental package, the company has reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements. If you did not receive a copy, these documents are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.bostonproperties.com. An audio webcast of this call will be available for 12 months in the Investor Relations section of our website. 
At this time, we would like to inform you that certain statements made during this conference call which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although Boston Properties believes the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, it can give no assurance that its expectations will be attained. Factors and risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by forward-looking statements were detailed in Tuesday's press release and, from time to time, in the company's filings with the SEC. The company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statement. 
Having said that, I'd like to welcome Owen Thomas, Chief Executive Officer; Doug Linde, President; and Mike LaBelle, Chief Financial Officer. During the question-and-answer of our call, our regional management teams will be available to address any questions. I would now like to turn the call over to Owen Thomas for his formal remarks.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Arista. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll cover our quarterly results, the macro market conditions as we see them, as well as our current capital strategy and investment activity. On current results, we produced another strong quarte
componenttext:
Okay, thank you, Arista. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll cover our quarterly results, the macro market conditions as we see them, as well as our current capital strategy and investment activity. On current results, we produced another strong quarter with FFO per share $0.04 above consensus, primarily due to accelerated lease termination income. We've also increased the midpoint of our full-year 2016 FFO per share guidance by $0.06. In the quarter, we leased 925,000 square feet, nearly half of that in the New York region and this quarterly volume is above historical averages by number of leases but below on total square feet. Our portfolio occupancy is now 90.8%, down 20 basis points from the end of the first quarter. We had another quarter of strong rent roll ups in our leasing activity with rental rates on leases that commenced in the second quarter up 18% on a gross basis and 28% on a net basis compared to prior lease. As we anticipate our leasing spreads continue to be strongest in San Francisco and Boston and positive in all regions. 
Now, moving to the economy. U.S. economic growth continues to be sluggish and slowing. First quarter GDP has been reported at 1.1%, down from 1.4% in the fourth quarter of last year, and estimates for all of 2016 are approximately 2% after downward revision. The important picture is -- been recently healthy with 287,000 jobs created in June but has been volatile throughout 2016. Also, the unemployment rate has been relatively flat at 4.9%. Now economically the most significant news for the quarter was the U.K. surprise referendum outcome to leave the European Union. We've also had a series of tragic terrorist events and an attempted coup in Turkey. There's already evidence of a slowdown in the U.K. economy and the IMF predicts the global GDP will follow. Sterling has dropped over 10% and Central banks in Europe and the U.K. are all signaling an accommodated posture. Given dollar strength and slowing growth, we believe that it will be more difficult for the U.S. Federal Reserve to increase rates further in the near term. The 10 year U.S. treasury has dropped 30 basis points to 1.6% over the quarter as a result. Lower rates have fueled record highs for the S&P 500 and a surge in REIT share prices in the U.S. Given the growth in the U.S. economy, albeit anemic, office markets nationally continue to improve slowly. Net absorption was 8.4 million square feet for the second quarter. Vacancy improved 10 basis points to 13.8%, asking rents rose 6.5% year-over-year. Construction levels are up 5% year-over-year but remain at 2.2% of total stock, which is slightly above long-term averages. We continue to see the strongest space demand in innovation centers. So how are we managing our business given this environment of sluggish growth, punctuated by increasingly frequent economic and political events and an uncertain presidential election in November? First, we will continue to take advantage of reasonably healthy tenant demand and lease up our existing vacancy and new developments. Second, we'll focus our new investment activity around innovation centers where we see the strongest prospects for growth. And lastly, we will also protect the downside given the prospect of volatility by requiring pre-leasing for new office development, avoiding the purchase of stabilized assets at low cap rate and keeping our overall corporate leverage at conservative levels. 
Moving to private market real estate valuation. We believe prices remain strong for prime assets and gateway markets. As evidence, we've seen a number of transactions in addition to what I've discussed last quarter in our core markets that were recently committed in 2016. In Cambridge, 1 Kendall Square, which is a 645,000 square-foot office lab and retail asset sold for $1,124 a square foot and a low 4s initial cap rate, though the sale did include a 173,000 square-foot development site, the buyer was a U.S. REIT with a capital partner. In New York, a partial interest in 7 West 34th Street, which is a 477,000 square foot office building fully lent to Amazon was sold for $1,176 a square foot at a low to mid-4s cap rate to an Asian investor. In San Francisco, the piers on the Embarcadero waterfront, albeit a small 82,000 square-foot building sold for a low 4s cap rate and $1,250 a square foot, which is a record for San Francisco and this was sold to a U.S. pension advisor. And in L.A, 12100 Wilshire and 11601 Wilshire sold at separate transactions to U.S. REIT, possibly with non-U.S. capital partners at a mid-3s cap rates and approximately $625 a square foot. As cap rates spread widen with increasing interest rates and European investment are exacerbated by Brexit and other geopolitical events, we continue to see a tailwind for U.S. real estate valuation, particularly on our core markets. 
Our capital strategy remains unchanged and that we are investing primarily in new developments and redevelopments, funded partially by select asset dispositions and the balance with debt financing. So let me start with acquisitions. This quarter, we closed the purchase of a 50% interest in Colorado Center located in Santa Monica, California and that closed on July 1. Colorado Center comprises 1.2 million square feet on a 15-acre site and is one of the premier office campuses in West Los Angeles. Though the complex is very well parked with 3,100 stalls located 1 block from the Bergamot Station and the newly opened commuter rail line between downtown Los Angeles and Santa Monica. 
Moving to economics, the property is 68% leased which provides us with a significant upside opportunity. Our net purchase price is $504 million or $850 a square foot and renovation and tenant capital will be required to lease a property. So the going in NOI cap rate is 3.4%, upon full lease up of the complex, we expect to achieve yields of approximately 5.5% and over 6% after a full mark-to-market of the tenant base. Teachers owns the other 50% of Colorado Center and we will provide all leasing property and construction management for the asset. We also look forward to advancing our relationship with Teachers as part of this investment. In addition to the financial aspects of transactions, Colorado Center has provided Boston Properties with the opportunity to enter the West Los Angeles market with a significant asset. We view West L.A. as an important innovation center and currently one of the most vibrant office markets in the United States. Our intent is to methodically over time, build up Los Angeles into a full independent region for our company. We hired the on-site property management staff and Ray Richie is providing senior-level direction to our Colorado Center in Los Angeles effort. Property management oversight, construction development and other support are all being provided from our San Francisco office. As the Los Angeles region grows, we anticipate a migration to local personnel, both hired externally and internally transferred. 
Lastly, I'm also pleased to report we are off to a very strong start in the leasing program for Colorado Center and Doug is going to provide more details on this. Now on dispositions. We're in the market with VA95, our 11-building 740,000 square-foot suburban office campus located in Springfield, Virginia. This park may be sold in whole or part. We're pursuing a recapitalization of Metropolitan Square, a 660,000 square-foot office building located in the CBD of Washington, D.C. Given these transactions and our completed sale of 7 Kendall Center, we could reach as much as $350 million in 2016 asset sales. 
Moving to development. We remain active delivering assets into service, advancing our predevelopment pipeline and evaluating new investments. In terms of potential starts for 2016, we're competing for a 630,000 square foot office build a suite for the TSA in Springfield, Virginia. We're also commencing the full rehabilitation of the low-rise building at 601 Lexington Avenue. The building is being renamed 159 East 53rd Street and will have a segregated street entrance and lobby for 195,000 square foot office building. We remain very active advancing our predevelopment pipeline for projects that would start after 2016. Several important updates from the second quarter include at Kendall Center in Cambridge, we're in advanced discussions with an office user to fully pre-leased a 400,000 plus square foot office building which will require demolition of an existing 80,000 square-foot low-rise building. This project would not commence until 2017 and efforts continue on developing commitments and projects for the remaining approximately 500,000 square feet of potential entitlements at Kendall Center. It has been reported that Boston Properties and a local developer attempting to entitle  MacArthur Station Residences, which is a 402 unit, 25 storey residential development located adjacent to the MacArthur Bart Station in the neighborhood of Oakland, California. We signed a letter of intent to invest in the project and are working on the entitlement process. Given the high cost of multifamily products in the San Francisco market, we believe we can deliver high-quality units at approximately 20% discount to San Francisco rents in a location that is a 16-minute transit ride from the Embarcadero station in downtown San Francisco. The project will not commence until 2017, also subject to achieving entitlement. This past quarter, we also delivered 3 projects fully into service including 601 Mass. Avenue in Washington, 10 CityPoint in Waltham and 804 Carnegie Center in Princeton. In the aggregate, these buildings comprise 850,000 square feet or 94% leased, cost $487 million to build and are being delivered at a 7.8% NOI return on cost, which is above our projection. Given the value of the properties at a much lower cap rate, deliver of these projects again demonstrates the value creation power of our development platform. Now given the delivery, at the end of the second quarter, our development pipeline now consists of 8 new projects and 1 redevelopment, representing 3.8 million square feet and $2.1 billion in projected costs. Our budgeted NOI yield for these developments is in excess of 7% and the commercial component of the pipeline is 52% pre-leased. We expect the addition of these projects to our in service portfolio to add materially to our company's growth's over the next 3 years. So to conclude, we remain very enthusiastic about our prospects for success and ability to create shareholder value in the years ahead. We have a clear and achievable plan to materially grow FFO to the lease up of existing assets the delivery of new buildings or development. We have selected non-core assets for sales to raise capital and ensure continued portfolio refreshment. We have significant entitled and unentitled land holdings that will continue to push through the design and permitting process and add selectively to our development pipeline in future years. Our balance sheet is strong with conservative leverage which we'll allow us to pursue and act on investment opportunities that present themselves in the coming. So's with that, let me turn it over to Doug.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everyone. I won't touch on global interest rate environment and the pending election, Brexit, global political events. And if you take these things altogether, this should elevate uncertainty volatility and they impact capital
componenttext: Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everyone. I won't touch on global interest rate environment and the pending election, Brexit, global political events. And if you take these things altogether, this should elevate uncertainty volatility and they impact capital spending decisions. In our business, a long-term lease up is a major investment and requires a significant capital outlay on the part of the tenant. If you listen to any of the real estate market conditions calls or read the quarterly update that are put up by the leasing brokerage community, I think it's pretty clear that the leasing velocity across many of our markets is feeling this impact. In addition, while the national statistics may show very little general inflation, we can tell you that very tightly labor conditions in the construction industry have pushed up the price of competitive improvement work. So it's easier today to delay all of these commitments and it's cheaper from a capital investment perspective to renew. So let me give you some specifics on our reasons and I'm going to start with San Francisco. During the first quarter, we completed a 128,000 square feet of office leasing at. During the second quarter, we completed over 158,000 square feet of office leasing and as of July 1, we had more than 233,000 square feet of full floor leases under negotiation. These leases average a positive mark-to-market of more than 40% on a gross basis, 70% on a net basis, very consistent with the leasing spreads that we're reporting on a quarterly supplemental. It at the same time, I will tell you that the overall leasing velocity in the San Francisco CBD is well off the level for 2014 and early 2015, there are couple of explanations for this. First, as I described last quarter, the city at the moment is not the experiencing the unprecedented large growth from tech companies, Google and Dropbox and Salesforce.com, Uber, Stripes Black, LinkedIn were so active in 2014 and 2015 with significant expansion. Yet there is still growing tech demand. In the first quarter, Airbnb and Twilio and Comcast and Stripe also down block of about 100,000 square feet and during the second quarter, Lift, Fit Bit, Expedia,  Reddit combined, have lease over 650,000 square feet of space. And today, there are more than a dozen active requirements from technology users looking for 100,000 square feet or more, including a couple that are close to 200,000 square feet. Twitch, Nerd Wallet and are those. Second, and mostly recently, high-quality, well-built sublet space has served as the dominant large block availability. And much of the recent demand has flowed into this quadrant. 3 of the 4 largest yields in the second quarter of over 100,000 square feet went to sublet space. Sublet availability has remained flat with the activity compensating for additional availability. Third, small space sublets are much less active, if you exclude capital raised by Uber and Snapchat during the second quarter. Overall, venture investing is pretty down significantly year-to-year. Early stage investing is down from the prior year and first time, investing is also down. These are the kinds of companies that gets funded and that are putting small spaces on to the market and are also the kind of companies that would be occupants. Finally, financial services and professional services firm continues to be neutral demand generators. At Salesforce tower, we continue to negotiate with the same group of transactions we were working on last quarter, plus a few additions. Most of those discussions involve tenants with late 2017 and 2018 lease expirations. The structure of the building is up to about the 40th floor and we expect to have our first tenants in occupancy in late 2017 or early 2018. We anticipate delivering the first block of space to Salesforce.com in the second quarter of '17 and then, we have 4 future delivery dates that extend out into the fourth quarter of 2018. We will not recognize revenue until the tenants has impleaded their buildup on a fallback for basis. Given the were going to be receiving aspirin. So at this point, we think it's prudent for modeling purposes to assume though NOI in 2017 the startup operating expenses will offset any rents. We have been extremely active quarter in the New York City region while statistically, overall midtown market activity was little bit light, we think it's largely because renewals have been prevalent and they're really not that typically included in this activity as measured by the major brokerage firm. Our total New York regional activity in the second quarter was over 435,000 square feet and it included 320,000 square feet of renewals and expansion at 399 Park Avenue. We have now re-leased 155,000 square feet of our 2017 City Bake office exploration and 49,000 square feet of the 2017 Morgan Lewis exploration. The overall rent up in these spaces was about 2% which is very consistent with my past remarks where I said the 399 was basically a flat building. They included over 110,000 square feet of space at starting rents over $100,000 a square foot. This quarter across the portfolio, our New York City roll up was about 14%. Our repositioning preconstruction activities are underway at 399 and we should be under construction by the fourth quarter. On July 1, 2 full floor high-rise at the General Motors building became available. While we continue to see a consistent and steady flow of leasing volumes between $80 and $125 a square foot, above this is little bit slower. We have been successful leasing smaller suites across our portfolio and are going to take a similar approach to the 2 General Motors. We have shown the space and we have issued proposal to a number of tenants proportions of these floors. The most exciting news of the General Motors building is that the Under Armour has leased 53,000 square feet of the former FAO space. Their plans are being developed as we speak and we expect they will create an incredibly dynamic expense for their brand, the building, and the city when they open. At the moment, we still have a temporary tenant utilizing the space and we anticipate turning the space over to Under Armour sometime in 2018. There are 17,000 square feet remaining and we'll likely become part of the other retailing units at the building. We don't believe it's appropriate to discuss the economics of the lease but our contribution to our $80 million revenue bridge is consistent with our prior projection. We are in deep lease negotiations with more than 55,000 square feet of the space that was sublet to a lease termination last quarter at 250 West 55th. While we expect to have the lease signed in the third quarter, the space is in rock condition and we will not recognize revenue until the tenant has completed its installation which will likely not occur until the end of '17 or early '18. All of our remaining prebuilt suites are under lease negotiations and we may break one of the 2 remaining floors of the top of the building the great additional inventory. At the June meetings, we had a number of comments suggesting that the D.C. CBD office market had turned the corner again. Our view has not changed and we have not seen any demonstrable positive change in the leasing market in D.C. in the CBD. Between '16 and '19, we are tracking only one uncommitted law firm expiration over 100,000 square feet. D.C. is truly a full releasing market for any sizable space. We are currently engaged ourselves with 2 law firms with 2020 expiration of over 100,000 square feet for our availability at that time. The GSA continue to have a very measured approach for their renewals and we're not aware of any requirements with our net demand generators. The market is now hunkering into its election inertia, which contribute to pushing out decisions. In spite of the challenging environment, we did complete 20 office leases totaling 150,000 square feet across the region. D.C. will continue to see new products come on the market even in the form of gut renovation and in some cases, ground-up development such as Capital at Crossing which is currently building 900,000 square feet of speculative product right now. This is likely to govern any significant recovery. As we enter the quarter, our Reston portfolio was 97% leased, leaving us with a smattering of small spaces. We did 6 mobiles this quarter, with starting rent in the mid-50s, our Town Center portfolio continues to outperform the rest of Northern Virginia. The merger of a number of government contractors with large installations in our Reston Town Center assets has created a medium term sublet space in our portfolio. With all the spaces being used, these contractors are looking for cost saving opportunities and this space is the most marketable in their portfolio. With very little direct space, we are eager to work with our tenants on new potential transactions which typically require additional sub-terms. We continue to see the Boston suburban market is having the strongest relevant demand growth across our portfolio. While we only completed 55,000 square feet of leases this quarter, we have more than 400,000 square feet of leases in negotiation from series of life science, technology and even a few financial services organizations. Leasing velocity in the Lexington submarket has accelerated during last few months as a result of this demand and much of it is organic expansion. Last quarter, I mentioned we had over 450,000 square feet of technology and life science company used at Bay Colony. Today, we're negotiating another 100,000 square feet of life science and technology expansions or relocations at that park. It's been widely discussed that the Cambridge market continues to be one of the tightest in the country with availability rates under 5%. Virtually every major pharma company has put down a base in the Cambridge market and coupled with the growth of the biotech industry and the tech titans, they are very strong demand drivers. I will describe the active discussion on the first phase of a new development of North. In addition to our development, MIT has approval for additional 1.3 million square feet of office and lab space. And the RFP for the site has been issued and offers will be view in the coming weeks. The current zoning of the Volpi site are nongovernmental owner allows for 1.17 million square feet of commercial space and 973,000 square feet of residential development. I mentioned a few quarters ago that Microsoft, which leases 134,000 square feet in our 255 Main Street building had chosen to consolidate and might exercise a termination option in its lease. Well, we did in fact receive that notice and the lease will expire on December 31, 2017, allowing us the opportunity to release that space well before the original exploration date. As lease today, the weighted average rental rate on the 216,000 square feet at 255 Main Street is more than $25 a square foot below market. The Boston CBD continues to be a lease expiration driven market with a steady flow of new technology companies entering or expanding, but that's nothing like what's going on in San Francisco. We leased another mid-rise floor at 200 Clarendon. We signed our first LOI for a full floor at 120 St. James. We have a full floor lease under negotiating at 11100 Avenue we're going to get back in 2017 and we're negotiating a 2.5 floor deal for Prudential Tower. 888 Street, our new office building is going to be opening in the third quarter, 71% leased with 2 or 3 floors in occupancy. The retail is going to open in December and the anchor office tenant which is 154,000 square feet is not planning on moving in until the fourth quarter of '17, so we don't anticipate our full run rate until the very end of '17 of that development. The flagship credential retail development is fully leased. We anticipate will be opening of the fourth quarter of '16 in the final retail tenants will be opened by mid-2017. We are off to a great start in Los Angeles as Owen suggested. Colorado Center is a 6 building campus with floor space between 30,000 square feet and 62,000 square feet. It is a large user project and it fits terrifically with our operating platform design. The West LA market has had a string of strong recorded rental rate growth as it benefits from both the creativity and entrepreneurship of local content, creators and providers and it is a growing labor market for a number of the San Francisco-based tech companies that are trying to broaden their workforce reach. In the 4 weeks that we have owned the property, we have signed a letter of intent with 160,000 square feet user and in active discussion with another tenants for 60,000 square feet as well as discussion with existing tenants for expansion. If we complete simply these 2 leases, we will have leased 63% of the available space. We have also hired a set of design professionals and consultants that are assisting us with our future repositioning plan. Let me end my comments with a further update on our revenue bridge. With additional leasing in Embarcadero Center and at the General Motors building, we have now pushed our completed transactions to over $58 million of the $80 million that we anticipated to receive by the end of 2017. And with that, I'll turn the floor over to Mike.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I just want to start with a quick summary of where we see the debt markets today. We do have some refinancing opportunities coming up and the debt markets have been open and improving in the face of the recent volatility
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I just want to start with a quick summary of where we see the debt markets today. We do have some refinancing opportunities coming up and the debt markets have been open and improving in the face of the recent volatility in the rate market and the uncertainty in the global recovery after Brexit. We have 2 mortgages that are maturing in the next 8 months. 1 is a $350 million mortgage at Embarcadero Center floor. It has a 7% GAAP interest rate that expires on December 1 and the second is a $750 million mortgage on 599 Lexington Avenue with a 5.4 percent GAAP interest rate that expires on March 1, 2017. Both of these loans have an open window and we can pay them off with no penalty this September and refinance it at significantly lower interest expense. We also used $500 million of our cash balances to fund the acquisition of Colorado Center in July, bringing our available cash down to approximately $700 million after quarter end. With $1.3 billion remaining to fund our development pipeline over the next couple of years, we may also look to enhance our liquidity with additional financing. Overall, our balance sheet remains conservatively leveraged and we have substantial capacity to add debt to fund new investments. Our leverage expected improve as we achieved a significant earnings contribution projected from our development as we move into late 2017 and 2018. Additionally, last week, Moody's announced a positive outlook on our unsecured debt ratings. The bond market has performed well through the recent volatility and our credits spreads have tightened, even with the most recent slight run up in long-term rates, we believe that we can borrow for 10 years in the unsecured bond market at around 3%. We also have access to the secured debt markets were comparable borrowing costs are in the low to mid-3% range for high quality properties that have reasonable leverage. You should also recall that we've entered into hedges for an additional amount of $550 million, targeting financing in the second half of 2016 at the 10-year swap rate of 2.42%. So at today's interest rate, we would have to amortize approximately 100 basis points of hedging cost into our interest expense at the first $550 million financing. Although we're evaluating the markets as we always are, we have not assumed any early financing activity in our earnings guidance. 
Turning to our earnings results for the quarter, you could see from her press release that we recorded second quarter FFO of $1.43 per share. That is $0.06 per share or about $10 million higher than the midpoint of our guidance range. The biggest factor and are exceeding our guidance was termination income that was approximately $6 million or $0.04 per share higher than our projection. All of this income was in our guidance for later in 2016, supra percents an acceleration of the timing of income recognition and to the second quarter but has no impact on our full-year projection. The largest peak was related to 100,000 Square foot space at 399 park are the new that had an edge release exploration in late 2017. We were able to sign a replacement lease for this space with the client seeking to occupy earlier and this in conjunction with the other lease that Doug mentioned represents 200,000 square feet of forward leasing which is a great start in covering our late 2017 exposure at 399 Park. The performance of our portfolio drove approximately $4 million or $0.02 per share of the outperformance this quarter. Revenue was slightly ahead of expectations while expenses, primarily utility and repair maintenance expense, were lower by about $3 million. Over $2 million of the expense reduction is related to R&M projects that have been reforecast into the back half of the year. So this portion will not flow through to our full-year guidance. As an property performance moderated this quarter but it was still strong with our share of combined cash and the why of 4.7% at combined GAAP and a why of 0.7% from the same quarter last year, the most significant impact affecting this quarter was 140,000 Square feet of space at 601 Lexington Avenue has expired midway through the quarter. As we discussed last quarter, we anticipate our same property NOI growth to continue to moderate for the rest of 2016. We will have downtime between leases for the 80,000 square feet of high-rise space at 750 75th Avenue that Doug talk about. We also have 160,000 square feet expiring this quarter at 191 Spring street which is in suburban Boston from a client who relocated and expanded at 10 CityPoint. We're working on up proposal for the majority of the space but there will likely be 12 to 18 months of downtime between leases. On the positive side, we are and expecting to continue to exceed growth from lease up and roll up of rents at Embarcadero Center, Prudential Center and 200 Clarendon Street. Overall, the leasing activity that we see is in line with expectation and we assume our share of same property combined in a way in 2016 will be up between 0.25% and 1.75% on a GAAP basis and between 2% and 4% on a cash basis over 2015. In our non-same property portfolio, we acquired Colorado Center this quarter and it is projected to add approximately $0.05 per share to our 2016 FFO. Based upon in tradition we're increasing our guidance for the incremental contribution from the non-same property portfolio to $46 million to $52 million over 2015. Colorado Center also has an impact on our noncash rents as there are several leases that are in free rent periods for the remainder of 2016. We received a credit from the seller equal to the amount of 3 rent but the accounting rules require this to be reflected as  a reduction in the purchase price as opposed to rental income which is was part of the reason why the net purchase price came down to $504 million. We now project our noncash rents in 2016 to be $52 million to $65 million. As you think about the change in our full-year guidance, remember that we had included within our prior guidance of virtually all of the second quarter earnings Pete. We just expected it to occur later in the year. So the impact of the remaining changes results in our increasing our guidance range for 2016 funds from operation to $5.92 to $5.99 per share. This is an increase of $0.06 per share at the midpoint, consisting of $0.05 per share from the acquisition of Colorado Center and $0.01 per share of better projected portfolio performance. I just want to close by adding some comments about 2017, although we will not be providing formal guidance until next quarter. First, just a reminder, that in 2016, we recorded $57 million in termination income which is much higher than typical and is primarily due to the large termination at 250 West 55th Street last quarter. This represents $0.34 per share of 2016 earnings that we do not expect to recur at the same level in 2017. Second is the described in a development pipeline, more than half of the leasing at 88 was the Street and all the producing at Salesforce Tower will not commence revenue at late '17 and late '18. The space is leased and the revenue equipment is in line with our previous projection that we outlined in our investor presentation as recently as June that show the projected quarterly development run rate accelerating as we move into 2018. Also, we've captured a good portion of the $80 million in NOI growth of that we've been projecting and we will see the impact in our revenues, particularly at the Prudential Center and Embarcadero Center next year. As Doug described, the majority of the projected revenue from the lease up of other properties such as 767 5th Avenue, 601 Lex, 200 Clarendon Street and 120 St James will likely hit by 2018. That completes all of our formal remarks. Operator, if you can open up the line for questions, that would be great. Thanks.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] here with many. Question, Owen or Doug. As you think about your stated strategy and one of the components is to being astute investors and looking at market timing for investment decisions by acquiring properties in times of opportunities,
componenttext: [indiscernible] here with many. Question, Owen or Doug. As you think about your stated strategy and one of the components is to being astute investors and looking at market timing for investment decisions by acquiring properties in times of opportunities, I take it you sort of you Colorado Center as part of L.A. but I'm curious to know what's going on in U.K. certainly, what's going on in Canada, you go to Toronto and London in the past. The currency is certainly, a lot more stronger today and 1 could argue that those are the opportune times to get to the market. So how should investors -- how should we think about -- how are you thinking about it today and maybe that is something that could be on the table?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have, as you know targeted market for the potential expansion of the company, one of those was L.A. We obviously made a significant move on that piece of the strategy last quarter and also, London has been on our list. And our view of London is that it
componenttext: We have, as you know targeted market for the potential expansion of the company, one of those was L.A. We obviously made a significant move on that piece of the strategy last quarter and also, London has been on our list. And our view of London is that it will continue to be a great world city and will be an interesting market for real estate investment and development. So that hasn't changed. However, in the short-term and medium-term, given the Brexit vote, there are more uncertainties about economic growth and space demand. We don't know the impacts on trade policy, what that's going to do to GDP growth. We don't know the impacts on for financial institution. What impact that will have on jobs in London. And so as we think about London, there's already been a 10% drop in the pound, which is helpful as a dollar investor but we also think pricing for assets should also change, given these uncertainties that I described. So we're still looking, we're still active but we're conscious of this additional and we would expect us to be reflected in pricing. And then, lastly, we're not particularly actively looking at Toronto.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
