componenttext: If we just think about the comments you made on Colorado Center with a good backlog of leasing that's going to come in. Is there going to be an outsized capital commitment needed to get those tenants into that project? Or is that going to come with sort of the second phase of replanning the project overall?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Manny, I think we've made a commitment to our tenants, and we've, I think, had these conversations with our partner that the buildings' common areas need to be refreshed in a more significant way than simply painting carpet. And so we've hired a series of
componenttext: Manny, I think we've made a commitment to our tenants, and we've, I think, had these conversations with our partner that the buildings' common areas need to be refreshed in a more significant way than simply painting carpet. And so we've hired a series of [indiscernible] professionals that are going through a programmatic view of all of that right now, which we're going to do one way or the other regardless of the leasing. And I think that those commitments are being described to the tenants as they talk about coming to the property.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Doug, one last one for me. If we think about leasing at 399 and GM, you mentioned smaller spaces at GM. Was that sort of your plan all along or has there been a shift in the market or demand profile of tenants that's now making you sort of rethink str
componenttext: And Doug, one last one for me. If we think about leasing at 399 and GM, you mentioned smaller spaces at GM. Was that sort of your plan all along or has there been a shift in the market or demand profile of tenants that's now making you sort of rethink strategies to get those spaces leased?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think our strategy has changed significantly. I mean, I've talked about this before that if you go back, call it, 4 or 5 years and you look at the number of relocations that involved tenants that are paying over $125,000 a square foot, and you can
componenttext: I don't think our strategy has changed significantly. I mean, I've talked about this before that if you go back, call it, 4 or 5 years and you look at the number of relocations that involved tenants that are paying over $125,000 a square foot, and you can probably count them on 1 hand, and so the market naturally is one that is a smaller market, meaning a floor at a max and generally less than that. And so having grown through the experience of 510 Madison Avenue plus the top of 250 West 55th Street, I think we've become pretty acute and adept at doing the right kind of prebuilt suite and marketing those types of spaces to the appropriate kinds of tenants. And we recognize that it's a velocity game, and we've got to increase velocity, and the best way to increase velocity is to be much more attuned to doing smaller deals.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Feldman with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Feldman with Bank of America.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I appreciate the comments on 2017 as we're building out our models. You talked about moderating same-store NOI heading into the end of the year. Based on the leasing you guys have done, when do you see the inflection point for same-store to turn pos
componenttext: Mike, I appreciate the comments on 2017 as we're building out our models. You talked about moderating same-store NOI heading into the end of the year. Based on the leasing you guys have done, when do you see the inflection point for same-store to turn positive or kind of start growing again?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we expect it to be positive, right? I mean, it's -- we're saying it's going to be 2% to 4% in 2016, so it's just -- it's been higher than that the first 2 quarters. So it's just going to come down a little bit because we've got some of the v
componenttext: Well, I think we expect it to be positive, right? I mean, it's -- we're saying it's going to be 2% to 4% in 2016, so it's just -- it's been higher than that the first 2 quarters. So it's just going to come down a little bit because we've got some of the vacancies that we talked about. But as you've seen our leasing stats, for many quarters in a row, we're having a positive mark-to-market on everything that we do. And I do anticipate that our occupancy is going to turn the corner in 2017 as well, as we filled some of the vacancies at 120 St. James, in the Hancock and Peru. So I don't have a number to give you right now, but I would expect a positive performance in 2017 on the same-store.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, I'm sorry, I shouldn't have said positive. I meant accelerating. So do you think '17 same-store is on track to be better than '16?
componenttext: Yes, I guess, I'm sorry, I shouldn't have said positive. I meant accelerating. So do you think '17 same-store is on track to be better than '16?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't -- I don't want to tell you where it's going to be, to be honest with you, Jamie. I just think it's going to continue to be positive. There's a lot of space that we can fill that is going to add to us over the next, I would say, 24 months. The que
componenttext: I can't -- I don't want to tell you where it's going to be, to be honest with you, Jamie. I just think it's going to continue to be positive. There's a lot of space that we can fill that is going to add to us over the next, I would say, 24 months. The question is the timing of when some of those spaces get filled and when the revenue recognition associated with those spaces are, and whether that is in '17 or pushing into '18. So I just -- it's a little bit of a timing game, but these are all really, really high-quality spaces. And I think we're proving that we're getting all the roll ups through the leasing that we're doing. So I feel very optimistic and positive about our ability to continue to grow our same-store and achieve the NOI bridge that we've been talking about.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then as we think about AFFO for the year. How are you guys tracking now?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then as we think about AFFO for the year. How are you guys tracking now?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the FAD's side, I would say that we're -- our guidance for 2016 is still somewhere in the low $4 range, I think $4 to $4.20, something like that per share. We did have a little bit of elevated transaction cost this quarter associated with some long-
componenttext: So on the FAD's side, I would say that we're -- our guidance for 2016 is still somewhere in the low $4 range, I think $4 to $4.20, something like that per share. We did have a little bit of elevated transaction cost this quarter associated with some long-term leases that we did both in Washington and New York City, there were 2 in particular, that were longer term and had some higher transaction costs associated with it that, kind of, hit our FAD a little bit this quarter. But we still expect it to be generally where we were when we talked about this last quarter.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then any early thoughts on the train shutdown heading to Brooklyn and what it means for your project out there longer term for leasing?
componenttext: And then any early thoughts on the train shutdown heading to Brooklyn and what it means for your project out there longer term for leasing?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make a quick comment and then John Powers, you can comment on this too. The good news for us is that we don't anticipate delivering our space until the second or third quarter of 2018. And from what we're told, the L train is going to be out of servi
componenttext: I'll make a quick comment and then John Powers, you can comment on this too. The good news for us is that we don't anticipate delivering our space until the second or third quarter of 2018. And from what we're told, the L train is going to be out of service for 18 months, which would line it backup for when, in fact, we deliver. So John, I don't know if you have any other thoughts?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the L train -- it's unfortunate for the Brooklyn residents, but not unfortunate for our project because that goes into Williamsburg and we're south of that. So the lines that their subway takers would use to get to our project, Dock72, will not be af
componenttext: Yes, the L train -- it's unfortunate for the Brooklyn residents, but not unfortunate for our project because that goes into Williamsburg and we're south of that. So the lines that their subway takers would use to get to our project, Dock72, will not be affected.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a follow-up for Mike on same-store NOI and just looking at the trend. Your cash same-store NOI guidance and your share 2% to 4%, if my math is right, it looks like you'll have to average around 0% for the rest of the year to get to the midpoint
componenttext: Maybe just a follow-up for Mike on same-store NOI and just looking at the trend. Your cash same-store NOI guidance and your share 2% to 4%, if my math is right, it looks like you'll have to average around 0% for the rest of the year to get to the midpoint. So is it just that you're looking for significant same-store occupancy drag for the rest of the year? Or is there something with straight-line rent because it seems like rent spreads and rent bumps are pretty strong. So is there something else I'm missing?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think the biggest drivers are New York City where we have 2 floors at the General Motors building coming back in July. We had the 4 floors at 601 Lexington Avenue that came back midway through the second quarter. And then, we have this space in su
componenttext: Look, I think the biggest drivers are New York City where we have 2 floors at the General Motors building coming back in July. We had the 4 floors at 601 Lexington Avenue that came back midway through the second quarter. And then, we have this space in suburban Boston, that I mentioned in my formal remarks, that is coming back. And so you are going to see some degradation in occupancy in the third quarter. And I think we may -- hopefully, we'll see some come back in the fourth quarter, late in the fourth quarter. But those are the things that are driving the -- our share of the same-store being, I would say, 0% to 1%, probably, in the next couple of quarters.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe for Doug or Ray Ritchey. I know it sounds like you guys are off to a great start with the leasing at Colorado Center. But can you talk a little bit about the amount of interest you're seeing in the balance of the vacan
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe for Doug or Ray Ritchey. I know it sounds like you guys are off to a great start with the leasing at Colorado Center. But can you talk a little bit about the amount of interest you're seeing in the balance of the vacant space? And whether the Paso leasing has surprised you guys? Or were any of the leases anticipated when you bought the asset?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when we started the diligence on the asset after we reached our agreement with Blackstone to purchase their interest, there was -- there were a few tenants that were "shopping the property," but had no real sense of with who the ownership is going to b
componenttext: So when we started the diligence on the asset after we reached our agreement with Blackstone to purchase their interest, there was -- there were a few tenants that were "shopping the property," but had no real sense of with who the ownership is going to be. And so I think there was a lack of concrete proposals. Ray has done a fabulous job of walking the walk and talking the talk and being out there. He's actually there right now, which is why he's not on this call, and he's been very proactive about meeting every tenant that we've made a proposal to, which I think is a different approach than the current -- the former ownership had with regards to leasing. And so I think we've turned a lot of heads in terms of the way we were managing this asset. And quite frankly, as I said before, these kind of buildings and these kinds of clients match up with the way we run our platform. And so we're used to and anticipate doing these types of things when we buy a property or when we're developing a property. So I think -- I don't want to say we're surprised by the level of activity. We're very encouraged by the receptivity that the activity has had to our approach, and the way we're pricing the property and the way we're committed to enhancing this environment and the experience for our tenants and our customers because that's what this is all about.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what's a reasonable time frame for expecting that asset to be leased up to a stabilized level?
componenttext: So what's a reasonable time frame for expecting that asset to be leased up to a stabilized level?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the underwriting that Owen was describing assume that we were not going to do any leasing for 18 months. Obviously, we're going to be doing a lot more leasing than that. And so I would anticipate that we will get these first couple of leases done some
componenttext: So the underwriting that Owen was describing assume that we were not going to do any leasing for 18 months. Obviously, we're going to be doing a lot more leasing than that. And so I would anticipate that we will get these first couple of leases done some time in 2016. Again, when the tenants actually occupy the space and revenue recognition occurs is a little bit out of our control. But we're hoping that we're going to be in the 90s by the middle of 2017, which is 12 months after we bought the property.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of John Kim with BMO.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of John Kim with BMO.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Owen, you mentioned methodically building your presence in LA, but your balance sheet position allows you to acquire almost anything accretively, and you have had some good leasing progress so far. So why not acquire more rapidly in the market?
componenttext: I think, Owen, you mentioned methodically building your presence in LA, but your balance sheet position allows you to acquire almost anything accretively, and you have had some good leasing progress so far. So why not acquire more rapidly in the market?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our approach is to create value and not to buy assets that are stabilized at low cap rates. So most of the investment that we've been making is -- has been in ground-up development as you know. I described 3 projects that we delivered this quarter at a
componenttext: So our approach is to create value and not to buy assets that are stabilized at low cap rates. So most of the investment that we've been making is -- has been in ground-up development as you know. I described 3 projects that we delivered this quarter at a 7.8% cash yield for a brand-new asset, again in our core markets, which we think is very value accretive. So we are looking at everything that's offered in West L.A. We're looking at development opportunities, there are not as many, given the restrictions that are on development in West L.A, which is one of the attractions, honestly of the market, so we're looking at that. And I think we would also certainly be much more interested in assets like Colorado Center that are very high quality, but they have something that needs to be done. So when we bought Colorado Center, it was 68% leased. And there was an upside opportunity in our minds from leasing it up, which I think, as Doug described, we're very much on track in dealing. So, yes, we could go out and pay, purchase the pipeline of assets that continue to be offered in the marketplace, but we want to be selective about getting a high-quality asset, getting an asset that is positioned for our type of tenants, which are generally larger. And also we would prefer an acquisition where there's something that we can do to add value as a property company.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Doug, I think you mentioned that you've achieved $50 million of the $80 million organic growth forecasted through 2017? Given that progress so far, is there upside to this organic growth number?
componenttext: Okay. And Doug, I think you mentioned that you've achieved $50 million of the $80 million organic growth forecasted through 2017? Given that progress so far, is there upside to this organic growth number?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- so what we're talking about is a bridge. So what we basically said was here are all the major holds in the portfolio in '16 and '17 and if we sell them all up, we'll get to $80 million. So I think the number is a consistent number and it's $58 millio
componenttext: I -- so what we're talking about is a bridge. So what we basically said was here are all the major holds in the portfolio in '16 and '17 and if we sell them all up, we'll get to $80 million. So I think the number is a consistent number and it's $58 million, not $50 million.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you provide some color on the Under Armour space? The remaining 17,000 square feet available. Where is that located within the former FAO Schwarz's space? And if you could just comment generally on experience-based retail. And if there are any o
componenttext: Okay. Can you provide some color on the Under Armour space? The remaining 17,000 square feet available. Where is that located within the former FAO Schwarz's space? And if you could just comment generally on experience-based retail. And if there are any other opportunities in your portfolio where you have leasing opportunities like this?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John, you want to take a crack at describing sort of the space and how the FAO space was configured and what's going to happen?
componenttext: Sure, John, you want to take a crack at describing sort of the space and how the FAO space was configured and what's going to happen?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The FAO space is on 4 different floors. And we've re-leased, as Doug said, the majority of the space. The balance of the space is not on the main floor and there are some different possibilities of how we could configure that. And we've worked up th
componenttext: Sure. The FAO space is on 4 different floors. And we've re-leased, as Doug said, the majority of the space. The balance of the space is not on the main floor and there are some different possibilities of how we could configure that. And we've worked up that with Under Armour.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with regard to experiential retail, I think it's a critically important component of what we're doing. And Bryan, you may want to describe what we're doing at the Prudential Center, and our decision, for example, to bring Italy into that property and
componenttext: And with regard to experiential retail, I think it's a critically important component of what we're doing. And Bryan, you may want to describe what we're doing at the Prudential Center, and our decision, for example, to bring Italy into that property and why we're doing that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Several years ago, we came to a conclusion that in order to be relevant in terms of retail formats, which is so important to our mixed-use projects, we had to have a large component of experiential retail. Our major decision was the decision to shut
componenttext: Yes. Several years ago, we came to a conclusion that in order to be relevant in terms of retail formats, which is so important to our mixed-use projects, we had to have a large component of experiential retail. Our major decision was the decision to shut down our traditional food court, which was a high-performing food court, one of the highest grossing in North America and we're repositioning with Italy. That will open up this November. We continue to see strong demand, not only across these mixed-use high-density projects, but the urban markets are incredibly high in demand. And we consistently see it, whether it's at Prudential Center where we have very few spaces remaining in terms of our repositioning of the entire asset, but we're also seeing it in our limited amount of retail we have in Cambridge. And then, also the significant amount we have preleased at our Hub project at North Station with our partners, the Jacobs, at Delaware North. And I think both those projects are indicative of that. We also see it just in terms of the urban storefronts in our downtown assets as well.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So and just to sort of keep going. So we're doing a similar project at 100 Federal Street where we're building basically a glass experiential boxes that we hope is going to be the gathering place for the downtown market. And John, you may want to describe
componenttext: So and just to sort of keep going. So we're doing a similar project at 100 Federal Street where we're building basically a glass experiential boxes that we hope is going to be the gathering place for the downtown market. And John, you may want to describe what we're doing at 601?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, 601 is a very exciting redevelopment. Doug mentioned -- I think Owen mentioned initially the smaller building, which is the, probably, atrium building. We're rebranding that completely. We're taking the skin off the building, we're taking all the me
componenttext: Well, 601 is a very exciting redevelopment. Doug mentioned -- I think Owen mentioned initially the smaller building, which is the, probably, atrium building. We're rebranding that completely. We're taking the skin off the building, we're taking all the mechanical systems. It will be essentially down to a slab and steel structure. And we're building it from scratch up. So that's going to be very well received in the market, that's almost 200,000 square feet. We're also looking at the atrium and have plans to make that into a spectacular food hall. And that will be just a little later in it's timing relative to the office building.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the development side of things and some commentary around protecting the downside. Preleasing has been a part of the strategy for a while here. But I was just curious, if the continued slowness in the economy has raised the bar in terms
componenttext: Just a question on the development side of things and some commentary around protecting the downside. Preleasing has been a part of the strategy for a while here. But I was just curious, if the continued slowness in the economy has raised the bar in terms of what you'd require from a preleasing perspective relative to maybe a year ago or so. And just also -- just a question on just leasing activity that you're seeing at Dock72?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to answer your question, and I've talked about this over the last couple of calls. Yes, I think that given the slowness in the economy, we have raised the bar, so to speak, in the level of preleasing that we require on new development. It's -- everyone
componenttext: So to answer your question, and I've talked about this over the last couple of calls. Yes, I think that given the slowness in the economy, we have raised the bar, so to speak, in the level of preleasing that we require on new development. It's -- everyone always asks for a number of this and that's not possible to provide because it depends on the size of the building, the activity level in the market, the speed of delivery, every piece of -- every circumstance is different. Where is the tenant coming from? Are existing portfolio from outside? But there's no question as we evaluate new developments, and we have a lot to evaluate even in our own company because of the large land holdings that we have. Preleasing is an absolute requirement, and our desire to have it be larger in the portfolio is there. So that is definitely happening. However, I think we still see projects, and I've described a couple of them, particularly there are several of the projects that we're looking at right now are actually 100% preleased. And those are the kinds of projects that we want to be doing and will create value for shareholders, even if we are layer in the economic cycle. As it relates to Dock72 leasing, I -- we're just too far away from delivery to expect much significant preletting. We're clearly in the market speaking with potential tenant, marketing the asset, but I think it's too early to expect -- for us to expect to have significantly preletting.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just with regard to WeWork. I guess, they've been in the news lately not necessarily for great reasons. But just curious, I mean -- I guess, there's no discussions with them potentially retrading that or?
componenttext: And just with regard to WeWork. I guess, they've been in the news lately not necessarily for great reasons. But just curious, I mean -- I guess, there's no discussions with them potentially retrading that or?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We are full systems go with WeWork at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and at the other 2 properties where we had leases. Let me comment that as we have, in our discussions with WeWork, all evidence that we have points to the fact that the facilities that they
componenttext: No. We are full systems go with WeWork at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and at the other 2 properties where we had leases. Let me comment that as we have, in our discussions with WeWork, all evidence that we have points to the fact that the facilities that they have opened are very successful. They're fully let and they're creating an attractive margin to WeWork. And we're seeing it in the projects where they are open with us, particularly 535 Mission has been very successful. So a lot of the press that you're describing is more about WeWork as a company. And again from reading the same press, reduction in the -- projections that they are projecting for their overall company, but as it relates to the performance of the individual instillations, we are evidence that -- suggest that they are doing well.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John, if I would just like to add one comment. We are very actively engaged with them at the Navy Yard. We're driving pile, so as Owen said it early on, it will be more exciting in the fall when the steel goes up. But we are in weekly communi
componenttext: Yes. This is John, if I would just like to add one comment. We are very actively engaged with them at the Navy Yard. We're driving pile, so as Owen said it early on, it will be more exciting in the fall when the steel goes up. But we are in weekly communication with WeWork. They've submitted their build out plan, we're adjusting their build out plans, we're coworking with them on the amenity space, they're very, very excited about the project.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: It's a follow-up on the space. I think, Doug, you said that the lease with Under Armour represents what you guys thought it was the $80 million. I'm just curious when you guys kind of underwrote the backfill of the FAO space. Does Under Armour, just by itself, represent the backfill, then the 17,000 square feet would be on top of that? Or it includes pro forma of the balance re-lease up?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: I think the answer is yes to both. So I'm not being sort of tongue in cheek about it. We are comfortable with the rent that we pro forma for Under Armour and based upon what's available, we think we'll do a little bit better.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, I'd thought that space was 60,000 square feet. It looks like it's closer to 70,000. Was FAO just not leasing all the leasable space? Or are you guys creating a low-grade space?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. There was 68,000 space. Some of that might have been, as John said suggested, it was on 4 levels. So there was second floor space. There were sort of two-stories of the first floor space because that's the level on Madison Avenue and the level on Fift
componenttext: No. There was 68,000 space. Some of that might have been, as John said suggested, it was on 4 levels. So there was second floor space. There were sort of two-stories of the first floor space because that's the level on Madison Avenue and the level on Fifth Avenue are on slightly different planes. And then, there was some subgrade space or concourse space and sub-concourse space. So there's a plethora of levels there and it was about 68,000 square feet.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And those levels can connect differently. We could put the second-floor level connected to the Madison. We can take part of the sub-concourse and put it with the bank. If the bank doesn't stay, then it's on Madison. It's fairly complicated, but we worked
componenttext: And those levels can connect differently. We could put the second-floor level connected to the Madison. We can take part of the sub-concourse and put it with the bank. If the bank doesn't stay, then it's on Madison. It's fairly complicated, but we worked it out, I think, with Under Armour. They're committed to the block of spaces square footage that Doug mentioned.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, just switching to the debt side of things. Mike, here, your comments are helpful. I'm just curious, it sounds like you guys don't necessarily think rates are going higher that quickly here. As you look to fund the remaining
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, just switching to the debt side of things. Mike, here, your comments are helpful. I'm just curious, it sounds like you guys don't necessarily think rates are going higher that quickly here. As you look to fund the remaining development spend, are you more apt to put construction facilities in place or kind of hit the unsecured market and shoot on the cash?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we will do some construction financing on some of the joint venture development projects that we have. So we're in the market for both the Brooklyn Navy Yard and for The Hub on Causeway. So we're leasing construction financing of those projec
componenttext: I think that we will do some construction financing on some of the joint venture development projects that we have. So we're in the market for both the Brooklyn Navy Yard and for The Hub on Causeway. So we're leasing construction financing of those projects. For the remaining cost for the wholly-owned development, I would expect that we would use cash on hand. And at some point, we would do some long-term financing at rates that we feel are very, very attractive to kind of lock-in and make sure that we lock-in as low rate as we can. So it will be evaluating that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And just as a surrogate, right? So a construction loan today is probably LIBOR plus 200 at the lowest level and 300, and you can do a 10-year financing at 3%. So the value of a construction loan from a rate perspective is de minimis.

componenttext: Sure. Bob, you want to take that one?

componenttext: Sure. First off, we're underwriting at rents that are approximately 25% to 30% less than San Francisco. It's going to take several years to get it entitled, and we don't anticipate delivering that building until probably 2019, 2020. So we're quite a ways off based on current market conditions from a standpoint of if the market is softening right now, which we are seeing in San Francisco?

componenttextpreview: It's -- this site is right adjacent of the MacArthur BART station. This is an area that has become very popular for rest and shops. It's one of, for lack of a better term, one of the hipper neighborhoods in the Oakland/Berkeley market. And it's one that i
componenttext: It's -- this site is right adjacent of the MacArthur BART station. This is an area that has become very popular for rest and shops. It's one of, for lack of a better term, one of the hipper neighborhoods in the Oakland/Berkeley market. And it's one that is gentrifying quite rapidly. So we see it as a very good location long-term.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just sticking onto Bay Area. On Salesforce Tower, you mentioned earlier [indiscernible] you thought you might get 5 to 15 new floors on this year. I think it was based on what you've done so far this year, how much additional spa
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just sticking onto Bay Area. On Salesforce Tower, you mentioned earlier [indiscernible] you thought you might get 5 to 15 new floors on this year. I think it was based on what you've done so far this year, how much additional space do you think you could get committed by the end of this year, then maybe by this time next year?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, the deals that we have in the works right now add up to about 8 floors. So if we're to do half of them, probably we'll get 5 or 6 of those floors done. And I think that our expectation is that we're going to continue to go with that type of the p
componenttext: So look, the deals that we have in the works right now add up to about 8 floors. So if we're to do half of them, probably we'll get 5 or 6 of those floors done. And I think that our expectation is that we're going to continue to go with that type of the pace so that as we get closer to people actually being able to go into the building and go to their floor and to sort of experience the spectacular configuration views, curtain wall, airflow, ceiling height that, that will ramp up the activity, and we anticipate that will be happening towards the end of this calendar year where we could actually do those tours on finished floors. And so I'll let Bob be the spokesperson because he's already made a commitment for the company, but we continue to be very encouraged by the leasing there. Bob?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Donald Trump would refer to the building as something really, really special. It's the A1 location in San Francisco. It's going to the biggest and the best building that's in the marketplace, and I'm very confident that it's going to lease up rapi
componenttext: I think Donald Trump would refer to the building as something really, really special. It's the A1 location in San Francisco. It's going to the biggest and the best building that's in the marketplace, and I'm very confident that it's going to lease up rapidly.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just last one for me. Can you talk about the tempo of leasing demand you're seeing across your portfolio between larger tenants versus smaller tenants? Would you say it -- it's fairer to say the larger tenants are more cautious today?
componenttext: Okay, and then just last one for me. Can you talk about the tempo of leasing demand you're seeing across your portfolio between larger tenants versus smaller tenants? Would you say it -- it's fairer to say the larger tenants are more cautious today?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that larger tenants are not necessarily more cautious. I think the larger tenants are fully committed to lease expiration-driven decisions that allow them to build out space. So anybody who is looking for hundreds of thousands of square feet of sp
componenttext: I think that larger tenants are not necessarily more cautious. I think the larger tenants are fully committed to lease expiration-driven decisions that allow them to build out space. So anybody who is looking for hundreds of thousands of square feet of space is doing that because across the broad markets that we're in because they have the lease expiration, and I don't think anyone is looking at the market and saying, well, we think things are going to get worse and therefore we're going to hold off. I think there -- people feel relatively good about sort of the position that the markets are in. On the smaller side, where there is a lot more flexibility, I think the volatility that Owen described and issues associated with the world at large are creating uncertainty, and uncertainty just doesn't drive significant capital decisions. And so we're seeing a lot more reticence to making decisions on new space for smaller companies.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Brad Burke from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Brad Burke from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question of the guidance. What you've done so far for the year and then the midpoint of the guidance for the third quarter of 141, looks like it would imply about 149 for the fourth quarter, so just wanted to understand anything we ought to be thin
componenttext: Just a question of the guidance. What you've done so far for the year and then the midpoint of the guidance for the third quarter of 141, looks like it would imply about 149 for the fourth quarter, so just wanted to understand anything we ought to be thinking about that would drive that sequential improvement from Q3 to Q4?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's really 3 things that we have. You know, one is development that are occurring and leasing up, which is part of that. We will have a couple of tenants at 888 that will take occupancy later this year that have a benefit to the company. And a
componenttext: I think there's really 3 things that we have. You know, one is development that are occurring and leasing up, which is part of that. We will have a couple of tenants at 888 that will take occupancy later this year that have a benefit to the company. And also interest expense, we talked about the fact that we don't have any early refinancing in our guidance, but we do have the Embarcadero Center on [indiscernible] and it's a 7% loan, so there's an assumption on our guidance, so there's going to be much lower interest expense when we refinance that in the fourth quarter. The other thing I would mention would be operating expenses, which are cyclically highest in the third quarter and lower in the fourth quarter, primarily due to utilities where the HVAC is obviously a little more expensive in the hotter times of the year that we're sitting in right now, actually. So those are kind of most of the drivers. And there's some positives that we talked about in terms of leasing activity later in the year that we're guiding later in the year, things like continued activity at Embarcadero Center where we got renewals that we're working on that we're trying to sign that will have kind of a blend and extend where we'll get some GAAP lift later in the year. So it's those kind of things.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also related to the guidance of the $58 million of the $80 million NOI bridge, just wondering how much of that is already being recognized as GAAP NOI, and to the extent that you're not recognizing any of it yet when you would expect that t
componenttext: Okay. And then also related to the guidance of the $58 million of the $80 million NOI bridge, just wondering how much of that is already being recognized as GAAP NOI, and to the extent that you're not recognizing any of it yet when you would expect that to roll on in your drivers?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've provided some information as to the timing of that. I can't give you exact numbers. I would say that somewhere between $15 million to $20 million is in today because that was, if you look at our slide, there was 535 Mission and 350 Bush lease up wit
componenttext: We've provided some information as to the timing of that. I can't give you exact numbers. I would say that somewhere between $15 million to $20 million is in today because that was, if you look at our slide, there was 535 Mission and 350 Bush lease up within there, and that is done. A good chunk of, I would say, half of the Embarcadero Center stuff will be in late this year and next year. And the Prudential Center stuff will be in next year, but not this year. And then, there's some big pieces that I think will be later. We're going to get some of the lease up at 200 Clarendon Street and perhaps a floor at 120 St. James that will hit sometime in '17. But the majority of that, I see, as being later because that is -- most of that space is, we have to wait until the tenant occupies to recognize revenue on that space. And then we've talked about Under Armour and the timing of that. And then, 100 Federal Street, which is another big piece of it, the lease is fully signed. But right now we're relocating another tenant to create the floors. We're not going to be able to deliver those floors until sometime in the middle of '17. So some of that will be into '17 and then into '18. So I didn't give you the numbers, but that's hopefully helpful with some guidance on the timing.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Tom Lesnick with Capital One Securities.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will be brief since we're going late in the call here. But quickly on Boston, we've seen pretty strong job growth here over the last quarter especially relative to some of your other markets. I think you mentioned in your earlier remarks about the stren
componenttext: I will be brief since we're going late in the call here. But quickly on Boston, we've seen pretty strong job growth here over the last quarter especially relative to some of your other markets. I think you mentioned in your earlier remarks about the strength of pharma and biotech right now. But I'm just wondering, are you seeing that wholesale across the entire region? Or are you seeing any sort of bifurcation between suburban and infill?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So most as of the technology-oriented companies in the biotech and the pharma and life sciences companies are concentrated in the Cambridge market, and then in the suburban market, so there's been some migration into the city. So I would tell you that on
componenttext: So most as of the technology-oriented companies in the biotech and the pharma and life sciences companies are concentrated in the Cambridge market, and then in the suburban market, so there's been some migration into the city. So I would tell you that on a sort of ranking, Cambridge is the strongest market, the Waltham, Lexington market is the second strongest, and then the CBD downtown markets are below that. And what we -- I think what our view is that the markets are very strong at the sort of lower level of building, but that there's a little less activity at the top of buildings and largely that's because the tenants that are driving demand, the top of the buildings traditionally are professional services and financial services companies, and there's just less growth there.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've seen it, I think, really an incredible stat. The P2 corner, as we call it, between Mass Turnpike and Route 2 at the Lexington side to the north along Interstate 95, the competitive set of buildings that we follow, 32 buildings are now at 4.25% vacan
componenttext: We've seen it, I think, really an incredible stat. The P2 corner, as we call it, between Mass Turnpike and Route 2 at the Lexington side to the north along Interstate 95, the competitive set of buildings that we follow, 32 buildings are now at 4.25% vacant, so it's the lowest I've seen in my career there. And I think it's indicative of your question, which was we do have good strong demand from both the pharma, biotech sector that's looking. And as Doug mentioned, solid company is not particularly huge companies, but companies that have growth in financial statements, so we were encouraged about that quarter in particular.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that insight. And then Bob, maybe one for you. There's been some recent news reports of Facebook pursuing a significant office expansion in the San Francisco proper. Are you able to comment, at all, on what kind of chatter you're hearing amon
componenttext: I appreciate that insight. And then Bob, maybe one for you. There's been some recent news reports of Facebook pursuing a significant office expansion in the San Francisco proper. Are you able to comment, at all, on what kind of chatter you're hearing among the brokers community. And if, at all, has this changed leasing dynamics, particularly in Central SoMa?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's very preliminary as far as them looking in the market. It's been rumored that they're interested in the Central SoMa area. The Central SoMa plan is not approved and won't be approved, probably, until the end of this year or early next year. So I
componenttext: Yes, it's very preliminary as far as them looking in the market. It's been rumored that they're interested in the Central SoMa area. The Central SoMa plan is not approved and won't be approved, probably, until the end of this year or early next year. So I think as far as them expanding in San Francisco, unless they get to an existing building, is going to be quite sometime off.

componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of John Guinee with Stifel.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not sure who this is for, but it looks like your earnings per share is over $3 this year. It looks like it's going to increase fairly rapidly next year. You've got a dividend of 260, sub-2%. Looks like you have some gains on sales. You may or may not be a
componenttext: Not sure who this is for, but it looks like your earnings per share is over $3 this year. It looks like it's going to increase fairly rapidly next year. You've got a dividend of 260, sub-2%. Looks like you have some gains on sales. You may or may not be able to 1031 exchange that into Colorado Center, but the long and the short of it is your sub-2% dividend may be holding back your stock price. You may have some taxable income issues. Can you talk about both the regular dividend and the special dividend?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good morning, John. So on the special dividend, as you know, that's driven by asset sales. I described 3 deals that we're working on, they're a couple of other little smaller things. And I said in my remarks that sales could be as high as $350 millio
componenttext: Yes. Good morning, John. So on the special dividend, as you know, that's driven by asset sales. I described 3 deals that we're working on, they're a couple of other little smaller things. And I said in my remarks that sales could be as high as $350 million. I would assume that's the highest they would be. All those deals may not happen. We don't know where they're priced. The original direction on asset sales was to 2 to 2.50. So we don't know yet exactly what the asset sales are going to be. So it's difficult for us to predict what the gains and so forth are going to be associated with that. So we're clearly -- look at that and working with our board later in the year to determine what, if any, special dividend we would pay. And then, as it relates to the recurring dividend, as you know, we mirror that to net income and, as you point out, net income will be rising. So again, with our board, as we get into later this year, we'll be evaluating the ongoing dividend to determine whether and how much we could increase it.

componenttext: I don't have a number for you here. I think that I can say that our taxable income is fairly close in line with where our dividend is.
