componenttext: Good morning. My name is Brandy, and welcome to the Boston Properties Third Quarter Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Ms. Arista Joyner, Investor Relations manager for Boston Properties. Please, go ahead.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Boston Properties' Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and the supplemental operating and financial data were distributed last night, as well as furnished to the SEC on Form 8-K. You can find reconcil
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Boston Properties' Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. The press release and the supplemental operating and financial data were distributed last night, as well as furnished to the SEC on Form 8-K. You can find reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures during today's call in the supplemental package. If you did not receive a copy, these documents are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.bostonproperties.com. An audio webcast of this call will be available for 12 months in the Investor Relations section of our website.
At this time, we would like to inform you that certain statements made during this conference call which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although Boston Properties believes the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, it can give no assurance that its expectations will be attained. Factors and risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by forward-looking statements were detailed in Tuesday's press release and from time to time, in the company's filings with the SEC. The company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements.
Having said that, I'd like to welcome Owen Thomas, Chief Executive Officer; Doug Linde, President; and Mike LaBelle, Chief Financial Officer. During the question-and-answer portion of our call, Ray Ritchey, Senior Executive Vice President and our regional management teams will be available to address any questions. I would now like to turn the call over to Owen Thomas for his formal remarks.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arista. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll cover our quarterly results, market conditions, as well as our current capital strategy and investment activity. On current results, we produced another solid quarter with FFO per share of $0.01 ab
componenttext:
Thank you, Arista. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I'll cover our quarterly results, market conditions, as well as our current capital strategy and investment activity. On current results, we produced another solid quarter with FFO per share of $0.01 above our prior guidance, primarily due to portfolio outperformance. We also increased our full year 2016 FFO per share projection by $0.03. For the quarter, we leased just under 900,000 square feet, which is below our historical averages. However, we have a very robust pipeline of in-service and development leasing activity, which we think will be signed before calendar year-end and which will bring our annual leasing for 2016 in line with or possibly above average. Our in-service portfolio occupancy is now 89.6%, which is down 120 basis points from the end of the second quarter, and this is due primarily to the addition of Colorado Center to the portfolio. We had another quarter of positive rent roll-ups in our leasing activity, with rental rates on leases that commenced in the third quarter up 6% on a gross basis and 8% on a net basis compared to prior lease. 
Now moving to the economy. U.S. economic growth continues to be positive but as we all know, it's been sluggish. Second quarter GDP growth has been revised up to 1.4%. It was 0.8% in the first quarter and estimates for all of '16 are 2% or less. The employment picture continues to improve gradually, with 156,000 jobs created in September and the unemployment rate has remained flat at 5%. Wages have perked up a bit, up 2.6%, though inflation remained low at 1.1% for the third quarter. 
Moving to capital markets. The 10-year U.S. Treasury has risen approximately 40 basis points to 1.75 [ph] the from the lows in July which has sparked a seemingly harsh REIT market correction of 5.5 plus percent over the past month. Though the status signaling won [ph] rate hike before year-end, further increases in the short to medium term we think will be tempered by low interest rates in the developed world, dollar strength, sluggish growth in the U.S. and low inflation. [ph] Given the growth in U.S. economy, office market nationally continue to improve, albeit more slowly. Net absorption was 8.7 million feet for the third quarter and the vacancy rate was flat to last quarter but improved 30 basis points from a year ago. Asking rents rose nearly 6% year-over-year and construction levels are up 6% year-over-year and are 2.3% of total stock, which is above the long-term average of 1.9% for the U.S. office market.
Moving to private real estate capital markets. We believe interest from primarily non-U.S. investors remains healthy for prime assets and gateway markets. However, transaction volumes are below 2015 levels and domestic institutional investors have been less of a factor in this segment of the market. Commodity assets are more difficult to sell, and there are fewer bidders for Class A trophies. [ph] There are, however, several examples of Class A assets continuing to sell for favorable prices in the third quarter. In Cambridge, 245 First Street, [ph] which is a 300,000 square-foot office and lab building sold to a domestic pension fund adviser for $1,020 per square foot in a mid-4 [ph] cap rate. In San Francisco, a sovereign wealth fund purchased a minority position in 101st Street and 303 Second Street for approximately $950,000 a square foot, which is a low 4s cap rate. And finally, in West L.A, 233 Wilshire was acquired by U.S. REIT in partnership with a sovereign wealth fund for $1,080 per square foot and low to mid-4s cap rate and there's a pipeline of additional deals in the West L.A. market we think with similar pricing metrics. We believe the relative stability of the U.S. market, given Brexit and other global turbulence, as well as the fact that U.S. cap rates spreads treasuries remain above long-term averages will provide a cushion for U.S. real estate valuations, particularly in our core markets. 
So in summary, operating performance improvement in office remains positive but is later in the cycle and slowing slightly. Interest rates are up modestly but will likely remain low and private capital flows into our space remain healthy, though somewhat diminished from previous quarters. Given this economic picture, we'll continue to take advantage of reasonably healthy tenant demand and lease up our existing vacancy and new developments. We'll focus our new your investment activity on new development and asset refurbishment in innovation centers where we see the strongest prospects for growth. We will also protect the downside by requiring pre-leasing for new office development, avoiding the purchase of stabilized assets at low cap rates, selectively selling assets and keeping our overall corporate leverage at conservative levels. 
Moving to the execution of our capital strategy. As you know, we completed the acquisition of Colorado Center in West L.A. last quarter. We had a very -- we've had very strong leasing activity at the project and are completing our redevelopment plan. We are also actively seeking to grow West L.A. into another major region for Boston Properties over the long term and are reviewing a number of on and off market opportunities. However, we will remain discipline and patient and focus only on investment that creates attractive returns to shareholders. 
Moving to dispositions. We recently completed with Blackstone the recapitalization of Metropolitan Square, which is a 620,000 square foot office building, 75% leased, located in close proximity to the White House in Washington, D.C. We've reduced our interest from 51% to 20% and will retain the leasing and management of the property. Pricing on a 100% basis was $360 million or $581 a square foot and the building will likely require an additional $160 per square foot of capital to complete its positioning. We realized $56 million of proceeds for the sale of our interest, net of existing financing, and we experienced a 14.2% leveraged IRR in the portion was sold over our 18 year period of ownership. We're also delighted to be developing a larger relationship with Blackstone through this transaction. 
We also closed in the third quarter the sale of a parcel in our broad run business park in County for $18 million. And finally, we've withdrawn from the market our VA 95 business Park in Springfield, Virginia. During the marketing process, the major tenant in the park, U.S. Customs, issued an RFP for a consolidation in Northern Virginia. The result and uncertainty around retaining this tenant diminished investor interest in the asset that ultimately we could end up benefiting from the consolidation opportunity. We do not anticipate any additional sales in 2016 though we intend to continue to sell non-core assets in 2017, subject to market conditions. Including these transactions, in 2016, we will complete the monetization of 3 assets for total gross proceeds on a hour share basis of $235 million, which is in line with projections provided at the beginning of the year. 
Moving to development. We remain active delivering assets in to service, advancing our predevelopment pipeline and evaluating new investments. In terms of starts for the quarter, we commenced the full redevelopment of the 220,000 square-foot low-rise building at 601 Lexington Avenue, 195,000 square-foot office component of the building is being renamed 159 East 53rd Street and will have a new dedicated street entrance and lobby providing branding opportunities for major tenants. The building is being re-clad, creating 30% more vision glass, a new high-efficiency HVAC system will be installed and access to the building's extensive and redesigned outdoor terraces will be improved. The 25,000 square-foot retail atrium is also being completely redeveloped with a prominent at grade entrance on 53rd Street and will house multiple dining amenities and a fitness center. Our share of the total budgeted cost of this project is $106 million and we forecast the yield on the office component to be in line with our target NOI yield of 7% for development. Returns on the retail announced or plaza components will be partially driven by the enhancements we realized and lease rate in velocity due to this new amenity for our 3 major office assets at the 53rd Street in Lexington Avenue. 
We also anticipate starting the development of an amenity building in the outdoor -- existing outdoor plaza at 100 Federal Street in Boston in the fourth quarter. We remain active advening our predevelopment pipeline for projects that would start after 2016. Several updates from this quarter include at Kendall Center in Cambridge, we're in the final stages of executing a lease with a major technology company to build their 476,000 square-foot headquarters at 145 Broadway, which will require a demolition of an existing 80,000 square-foot low-rise building on the site. Total budgeted development costs are $517 million or $1,086 per square foot with land at market value and the first year development NOI yield is projected to be approximately 7%. The project will not commence until 2017 and efforts continue on developing commitments and projects for the remaining 600,000 square feet of potential entitlements at Kendall Center. 
We're pursuing -- further, we're pursuing multiple new pre-lease development opportunity in the Washington, D.C. region, all of which are potential 2017 starts. On deliveries. This month, we delivered into service 12 65 Main Street in Waltham, Mass. This -- the building which we own in partnership with a local developer is 115,000 square feet and 100% leased to C&J Clarke. We are generating a 7.7% yield on our $26 million investment in this redevelopment. At the end of the third quarter, our development pipeline now consists of 8 new projects and 2 redevelopments totaling 4 million square feet and $2.2 billion in projected costs. Our projected NOI yield for these developments is in excess of 7% and the commercial component of the pipeline is 50% pre-let. We expect the addition of these projects to our in-service portfolio to add materially to our company's growth over the next 3 years. 
So to conclude, we continue to remain very enthusiastic about our prospects for creating shareholder value in the quarters ahead. We have a clear and achievable plan to materially grow FFO through to the development and delivery of new building, as well as the lease up of existing assets for which we currently have a particularly strong backlog of potential leases. We selected non-core assets for sales to rates capital and ensure continued portfolio improvement. We have significant entitled and unentitled landholdings that will continue to push through the design and permitting process and add selectively to our development pipeline in future years. Our balance sheet remains strong with conservative leverage which will allow us to pursue and act on investment opportunities that present themselves in coming quarters. So let me turn the call over to Doug for a further review of the market.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. So this is the third quarter and we introduced our 2017 earnings guidance last night and I'm going to devote my time this morning to providing the operating background that's behind our estimates and to describe the
componenttext:
Thanks, Owen. Good morning, everybody. So this is the third quarter and we introduced our 2017 earnings guidance last night and I'm going to devote my time this morning to providing the operating background that's behind our estimates and to describe the key drivers of our occupancy and revenue growth over the short term, as well as those situations where we have in fact completed transactions, signed leases, but are not going to be recognizing any revenue until 2018 and there's a significant amount of that. In a number of instances, our estimates reflect investment and repositioning decisions that were made during the past 12 months, which have a direct impact on our 2017 GAAP revenues and I want to take the time to provide incremental impact of those decisions. So let me now give you some specifics on our reasons and I'll start with San Francisco. So during the first quarter, we completed 128,000 square feet of office leasing at Embarcadero Center. During the second quarter, 158,000 square feet of leases and during the third quarter, we completed an additional 219,000 square feet of leasing. All of these leases average a positive mark-to-market of more than 40% on a gross basis and 70% on a net basis, very consistent with the leasing spreads we've been reporting in a quarterly supplemental. The incremental revenue from the deals we've now signed in San Francisco since the third quarter of last year, is over $16.5 million and will be at a full run rate starting in the third quarter of '17. The overall market conditions we've been describing in the last few quarters in the San Francisco CBD really remain the same. And while it may make a headline, the rate of activity in 2016 is not going to be quite at the level it was in '15 which by the way was just off the peak market of 2014. We actually think the real news is the stability of the market in San Francisco CBD. Each quarter, there continues to be a new crop of significant technology company lease expansions in addition to the traditional lease exploration driven market demand. This quarter, Switch signed a lease at 350 Bush for 185,000 square feet. FitBit took over 300,000 square feet off the sublet market; Lift has taken over 280,000 square feet at 185 Berry; Adobe is in the market and expanding by 200,000 square feet; Slack, which started at our building at 680 Fulsom in an 11,000 square-foot pre-build suite in 2014 is now looking for more than 200,000 square feet. And NerdWallet continues to be in the market for over 100,000 square feet. 
Continuing the trend we saw in the second quarter, high-quality, well-built sublet space is hitting the market and getting quickly absorbed and has really served the dominant large block availability. The largest block of sublet space in the market statistically last quarter was a 400,000 square-foot block at 211 Main, so there's no more sublet availability. And the largest block of space on the market this quarter was up over at Twitter's buildings up on upper market. It appears now that space has been put under lease negotiations with a growing startup technology company. Sublet availability has remained flat with growing technology expansion compensating for additional availability. Salesforce Tower is the tallest building in the city and we are now able to take prospective tenants up to the available floors and allow them to visually and physically experience the breath division glass, the calm free floors, the volume of the slab to slab heights and the views. We have 5 floors under lease negotiations, which are what our expectations was for the year and hope to have all of these leases signed by year-end. Only 1 full floor future prospect is actually located at Embarcadero Center, so it's all incremental in the demand. The structure of the building is up about 56 floors and we expect to have our first tenants in occupancy in late 2017. 
I've said this last quarter but I want to repeat it again. We anticipate delivering the first block of space to Salesforce.com in the second quarter of '17 and then we have 4 future delivery dates that extend into the fourth quarter of '18. We do not recognize revenue until the tenants have completed their build out on a floor by floor basis, even though we're going to be receiving cash rent. Our 2017 earning estimates continue to assume we're not going to record GAAP revenue from Salesforce.com's lease in 2017. Rent commencement on the other 4 tenant floors is likely to start in the fourth quarter with accompanying of capitalized interest but is offset by the startup of operating expenses and taxes for the whole building. When the building is fully leased with tenants and occupancy, which we expect to occur in '19, we anticipate an initial stabilized net operating income of between $80 million and $85 million. 
Our Mountain Dew activity continue to be very strong still. We're renewing our single story product at over $55 triple net, but occupancy gains are slower at 611 Gateway. We will start the year there with 186,000 square feet of availability and we're unlikely to see much incremental revenue from that space in '17. Going down the coast to our new market in West L.A. Activity there is robust and we anticipate signing leases for more than 200,000 square feet of our 380,000 -- 385,000 square feet of availability in the coming days and extending another 190,000 square feet. The West L.A. market has had a string of strong quarters of rental rate growth as it benefits from both the creativity and entrepreneurship of local content, creators and providers, the explosion of new content from new economy entertainment companies and the growing labor market for a number of San Francisco-based technology companies that are trying to broaden their workforce reach. Since July, the submarket has seen more than 400,000 square feet of signed leases and there's another 790,000 square feet of activities in the market including our transactions in process. Rent to move more than 10% for these large blocks of space since our purchase in July. 
I want to start my discussion in the New York region with our retail tenancy. At 250 West 55th, we have signed a lease for 55,000 square feet including the second floor with the operator of an experiential thematic visitor destination that expects to be opened by the end of 2017. Since the space needs to be improved, we have not included any revenue in our 2017 estimates while this space is lease. You will recall that our 2016 results included termination income equivalent to 4.5 years of rent. We expect to replace this income from this space after 23 months. At 757 Fifth, we have more clarity on the timing on the retail revenue from the various spaces. We expect to deliver this space to Under Armour in the second half of 2018. So going back, in 2014, prior to the termination of the FAO lease, when all of the retail was leased, we had about $64 million of revenue from the retail spaces at the General Motors Building. All the space is now committed, but in 2017, as we work through the transition, we will have about $51 million of revenue. In the second half of 2018, when the transition is complete, we anticipate an annual run rate of over $85 million of revenue with a pretty conservative protection for percentage rent from the tenants. We own 60% of this joint venture. We're not anticipating any office rent growth and probably slightly higher concessions around our midtown office portfolio in '17. The conditions we have been describing for the last 2 years remain in control. New supply continue to come into the market. The large financial players continue to shrink their cost structures and in certain instances, they've chosen to move to new owned facilities on the far West side, creating additional inventory. Landlords that are putting capital into older assets are attracting tenants. Major League Baseball at 1271 6th Avenue just took 400,000 square feet and Level at 390 Madison Avenue just took 250,000 square feet being the most recent example. The market is active for larger tenants in the mid-80s across midtown. While the market for space over $100 a square Foot obviously has less velocity. I think the most significant change in our Manhattan leasing is that we have seen a significant pickup in demand for our 2 floors, the available floors at 767 5th Avenue, which total about 80,000 square feet. We have a lease for 24,000 square feet out for execution. We actual expect it to get signed today and we have 3 other tenants looking at between 40,000 square feet and 20,000 Square feet. Again, we won't recognize revenue in '17 but the expected contribution is over $7.5 million from this 80,000 square feet. If you look at it statistically, there's actually been a significant amount of space leased at over $100,000 a square foot and that even excludes the lease at 425. More than in fact in 2015 but the typical relocation deal is still under 10,000 square feet. So you have to do a lot of deals to lease space. Our total New York regional activity in the third quarter was about 113,000 square feet. We're negotiating leases for 60,000 of our 87,000 square feet of 2017 rollover at $5.99. It's all price in the 80s and we expect to receive income from some of those spaces in '17. We completed the relocation of all of the tenants from the low rise at 159 East -- 1590 53rd Street. This was our 1 opportunity to dramatically rebuild the space in conjunction with our plan to reintroduce the public spaces. In order to complete the work, we took back 70,000 square feet in 2016, which resulted in termination payments and a rent roll down, which is why you see negative statistics in our supplemental in the New York region this quarter. When we made this decision to proceed with this investment in the late 2015, we recognize that we were going to be reducing the pro rata share of the revenue from the office space by about $5.5 million. That's we're experiencing in 2017. We're now marketing 195,000 market block of space that we hope to deliver to tenants in '18 with revenue commencing in '19. 
At 399 Park Avenue, we've commenced an extensive renovation and had lease about 204,000 square feet of the coming up rollover and we have another 500,000 square feet that is uncommitted including about 100,000 square feet of space that is currently rented at about $45 a square foot. The existing lease explorations from city and the law firm expiring August and September of '17 and while we expect to lease significant portions of the space during the year, we anticipate having to remove the existing improvement and may not have tenants in place with the revenue recognition until 2018. Our other New York City assets have very modest near-term exploration or vacancies. We've signed leases on negotiations ongoing that will create significant amounts of incremental income but the opportunities to drive '17 revenue are limited. 
Going down to D.C.. The D.C. CBD office market fundamentals have not experience much in the way of new demand generators and we haven't really seen any demonstrable positive change in the leasing markets. Landlords are competing on any available space, concessions in D.C. on leases of 10 years or more, typically include the year of free rent and more than $110 of tenant improvement allowance. D.C. is truly a forward leasing market for any sizable space. But there continues to be speculative buildings under construction, believe it or not, aging beauties that are being repositioned and 11 operational buildings with between 100,000 and 400,000 square feet of available space. That's the market we're dealing with. The GSA continue to have a very measured approach to its renewals and we're not aware of any requirements that are net generators of demand. We're negotiating some short-term renewals with the GSA for 196,000 square feet of our 2017 lease explorations. In spite of the challenging environment, we are chipping away at all of our availability with about half of 47,000 square feet of available space under negotiation at 601 Mac, that's the building that opened late last September, and we have another half a dozen leases under 15,000 square feet either signed or in active negotiations at other D.C. CBD assets. 
In Reston, we completed another 6 leases totaling 69,000 square feet, where the average starting rents spills in the mid-50s and we made 2 proposals to large users for our proposed new 270,000 square-foot signature development. Our Reston portfolio continues to be 97% leased, leaving us with a very small smattering of availability. There's actually been a pickup of activity at our VA 95 product, the product that Owen was describing and we're actually in negotiations with 2 tenants for between 53,000 square feet and 69,000 square feet of our availability there. We actually picked up another 31,000 square-foot tenant at our AJ6 building in Maryland. 
As Owen reported, we are close to executing a lease from approximately 476,000 square-foot office building on the site of our existing 97,000 square-foot office building, 145 Broadway. We are moving through the formal review process with the city of Cambridge. We anticipate vacating 145 Broadway during the second quarter of '17 and commencing construction soon after. We are eliminating, taking off the board, $2.3 million of income on an annualized basis until the building comes into service in December of 2019. This is captured in our 2017 projections. So you're starting to get the theme. The demand growth in our Boston suburban portfolio continue to outpace the other submarkets. This quarter, we completed 173,000 square feet of leases and we have more than 475,000 square feet of renewals and relocations with growing tenants in progress. High-quality spaces at a premium and we anticipate additional rent growth in '17. One of our negotiations is for our building at 173, which we took out of service in 2016 in order to complete a major refurbishment. We spent an incremental $16 million and expect to increase income by more than $1.2 million when the tenant takes initial occupancy during the third quarter of 2017. This is yet another example of us purposely forgoing current income in order to create higher long-term value. 
The Boston CBD market continue to be a lease exploration driven market with a steady flow of new technology companies. One of them are interesting phenomenon is that all the large users that have been entering the "Innovation District" or the seaport area, for the most part, traditional, tenants seeking new large blocks of space and most of the smaller and growing technology companies are located in the financial district, Uptown, which is what we call the North Station area or the Back Bay. During the quarter, we leased about 50,000 square feet in our CBD portfolio, but this month, we expect to complete 64,000 square feet of leasing at 888 Waltham Street. Again, I think the lease will get done in the next day or so, bringing us to 89% leased. We've signed 108,000 square feet at the Prudential Center, including 76,000 square feet of new tenants, bringing the occupancy in the Prudential Center to 98% and we've signed 54,000 square feet at 120 St. James, the low-rise portion of 200 Clarendon. As we discussed on our last call, 888 is not going to hit its stabilized run rate until November of 2017 when the occupied floors 4 through 10 or 154,000 square feet. And while we leased more than 1.2 million square feet at 200 Clarendon since we took possession in 2011 and it's a 1.6 million square foot building, we still have 120,000 square feet of low-rise space and 125,000 square feet of high rise. While the low-rise space is very attractive to nonfinancial tenants, the high-rise floors continue to be driven by traditional lease exploration driven users and the activity in this area has been less robust. We expect to lease a large portion of the space over the next 12 month but we're not projecting revenue in '17. 
In summary, we have executed on a significant portion of our plan and we have a significant amount of contractual revenues in both our operated properties and our development assets that will increase our earnings over the coming year. We've now executed on about $72 million of our $80 million bridge but we still have a few significant lease explorations that were part of that bridge that we still need to cover. And with that, I will turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I'm just going to start with a couple of quick comments on our balance sheet and then, I'll jump to our earnings results and our guidance. We completed a significant transaction in the debt up markets this past quarter.
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning. I'm just going to start with a couple of quick comments on our balance sheet and then, I'll jump to our earnings results and our guidance. We completed a significant transaction in the debt up markets this past quarter. We raised $1 billion 10 year bond issuance at 2.75% coupon. If you include the settlement of a portion of our hedges, the all in GAAP interest rate on that financing is 3.5%. We use the proceeds to repay 2 mortgages that had a weighted average GAAP interest rate of about 5.9%, so you will see the impact of the 240 basis points reduction show up as lower interest expense in our run rate going forward. Our cash balances have dropped to just over $400 million after the acquisition of Colorado Center, funding of our developments and the repayment of debt. We project our development spend to approach $1 billion through the end of 2017 and we anticipate either using our currently untapped line of credit or raising additional debt capital as a personal funding source. 
Our guidance currently assumes the use of our line so it's certainly possible that we may complete a new debt issuance and hold the cash short term which will be dilutive to our earnings guidance. With the run-up in treasury rates over the last couple of months, our borrowing cost for 10 years in the bond market is currently about 3.2%. If you assume a $500 million debt issuance at the beginning of 2017, it will reduce our 2017 earnings guidance by about $0.05 a share. The other major debt transaction that we have our eye on is the pending refinancing of our $1.6 billion mortgage on 767 Fifth Avenue that expires next October. This is a consolidated joint venture with our share being 60% and we expect to refinance it in the mortgage market. We currently account for this loan under fair value accounting, so the GAAP interest rate is only about 3%. With the mortgage market currently pricing comparable large loans in the mid-3% range, the refinancing will likely increase our GAAP interest expense. We've also entered into hedges for $450 million of this at a 10 year treasury rate of 2.60% that will impact the transaction. The current cash interest rate on the loan is 6%. So on a cash basis, we anticipate a significant reduction in the interest rate that should in inert to our cash flow. Our earnings for the quarter reported at $1.42 per share, which was $0.01 above the midpoint of our guidance range. Our portfolio performed ahead of our expectations, generating NOI approximately $3 million above our projection due to a combination of rental revenue outperformance and operational expense savings. The majority of the revenue came from San Francisco where we completed a number of leases earlier than we projected, including some renewals with a strong roll up that we started a straight line upon signing. As you can see on our mark-to-market stats, we continue to experience dramatic rent roll ups in our activity in San Francisco. The outperformance of the portfolio was offset by a $1.8 million impairment we booked this quarter on a land parcel in suburban Maryland. This is the last parcel we own and a land assemblage we considered exiting over the past several years, having sold 2 other parcels and booking gains totaling $5.5 million. Our FFO guidance for the rest of 2016, up $5.97 to $5.99 represents an increase of $0.03 per share at the midpoint from last quarter's guidance. All of the increase M&A from the performance of the portfolio due primarily to leasing success in the Boston and San Francisco market. Our guidance now assumes our share of 2016 combined same property cash NOI growth of between 3.5% and 4% growth over 2015, which is at the high-end of our prior range. As you look at 2017, the most important factor to remember is the impact of the amount of termination income that we recorded in 2016. We project 2016 termination income of approximately $58 million. The lion share of this came from 1 large termination at 250 West 55th street and several at 601 Lexington Avenue where we needed to relocate tenants from the low-rise to the high-rise in order to allow our redevelopment to move ahead. Our 2017 guidance assumes only modest termination income. So this represents a loss of $0.31 per share of projected FFO from 2016 to 2017. 
In the portfolio, Doug described our activity New York City and Boston where we're successfully signing leases and letters of intent but much of the impact will be in '18. Although some of our leasing efforts will not result in immediate revenue recognition, we do assume solid growth in same property portfolio in 2017. In Boston, we've signed leases on virtually all of the vacant space at the Prudential Tower and we expect Italy and the rest of the Prudential shops releasing effort to be open and revenue generated by the first quarter. We also start to deliver floors to Putnam at 100 Federal Street and we expect moderate additional lease up at 200 Clarendon Street. In aggregate, our guidance assumes this activity at $17 million to $25 million of incremental NOI to 2017. In San Francisco, we've had a tremendous success both leasing up our vacancy and rolling up rents on renewals at Embarcadero Center this year. This was reflected in 2016 but will be even stronger in 2017 where we project an incremental $18 million to $25 million of NOI, equating to growth of more than 10% for the region. On a cash basis, the growth is even greater at the cash mark-to-market takes hold of our early renewal activity. The impact of the growth we're experiencing in Boston and San Francisco for both increased occupancy and a roll up to higher rental rate is projected to be partially offset by a decline in the contribution from the New York portfolio. The contribution from the Washington portfolio is projected to be relatively flat. As Doug described, in New York City, we will not see any real impact from the significant leasing we're doing at 767 Fifth Avenue and at 250 West 55th Street until 2018. We expect a temporary loss of income from 500,000 square feet of roll over at 399 Park Avenue at the second half of the year. Overall, our guidance assumes NOI from the New York City portfolio to be down $5 million to $10 million into 2017 from 2016. So in aggregate, our guidance assumes our share of combined same property NOI to grow between 2% and 3.5% in 2017 over 2016 and on a cash basis, we assume between 2% and 4% growth of our share of combined same property NOI over the same period. Our non-same property portfolio includes our [indiscernible] and the impact of taking buildings out of service for redevelopment. Our redevelopment projects include combined 159 East 53rd Street in New York, 145 Broadway in Cambridge and one of our suburban Boston assets, 191 Spring Street. We expect this redevelopments to generate an accretive development return on investment but in 2017 will result in a loss of approximately $8 million of NY compared to 2016. This includes both rental income as well as the expensing of demolition costs that we projected $4 million in 2016 and $7 million in 2017. 
On the positive side, we expect to generate NOI growth from a full year of the acquisition of Colorado Center and from our development deliveries. Though as Doug described, our development deliveries will be much more impactful to 2018 based upon the anticipated occupancy dates for our major pre-leases. In aggregate, our guidance assumes our non-same property portfolio will add an incremental $18 million to $30 million of NOI in 2017. The other area where we expect significant change on our earnings in 2017 is through lower interest expense from the combination of debt refinancing, completed in 2016 as well as higher capitalized interest associated with our development pipeline. Our guidance for 2017 assumes net interest expense of between $378 million and $391 million, which is a reduction of $21 million at the midpoint of 2016. We assume capitalized interest to be between $50 million and $60 million in 2017. 
So in summary, based on these assumptions, we project our 2017 funds from operation to be between $6.05 and $6.23. This is an increase of $0.16 per share from the midpoint of our 2016 projected FFO. At the midpoint, the increase in FFO over 2016 is the result of $0.23 per share of growth from our share of our combined same property portfolio, $0.14 per share of incremental NOI from development deliveries and acquisitions, $0.12 per share from lower interest expense, $0.01 per share from higher development and management services income that we project to be offset by a reduction and $0.03 per share from higher G&A expense and $0.31 per share of lower projected termination income. Again, the biggest item to consider when looking at our 2017 FFO growth is the impact of all the termination income that we recorded in 2016 that has not projected at anywhere near the same level in 2017. If you exclude the impact of termination income, our FFO per share at the midpoint of our guidance range is projected to be up 8.5% over 2016. 
I also want to make a quick comment on our dividends. Our estimate for 2016 tax before income before gains on sale is roughly in line with our current dividend rate of $2.60 per share. As we forecast the income generated from our development pipeline delivering over the next few years, combined with the anticipated organic growth in the portfolio and assuming moderating asset sales, our taxable income is projected to grow meaningfully. We've been working with our board on evaluating our dividend strategy and anticipate that our annual dividend will likely increase in both the short term and the longer-term to continue to match our flexible income to our dividend. That completes our formal remarks. Operator, can you open the line up for questions?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Owen, just the first question, with the JV of Blackstone in Metropolitan Square in D.C., can you just give a little bit more perspective on sort of how we should think about this relationship with Blackstone? Is it going to where, as they have buildings t
componenttext: Owen, just the first question, with the JV of Blackstone in Metropolitan Square in D.C., can you just give a little bit more perspective on sort of how we should think about this relationship with Blackstone? Is it going to where, as they have buildings that they're putting on the market, we may see guys partner and buy into those buildings or is it more selling parts of your portfolio or is it the 2 companies both going out and pursuing new acquisitions together?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I -- look, I think that we've done actually 2 important transactions at Blackstone this year. We purchased the half interest in Colorado Center from them and we are doing this recapitalization at Metropolitan Square. I don't think I would read anythi
componenttext: Yes, I -- look, I think that we've done actually 2 important transactions at Blackstone this year. We purchased the half interest in Colorado Center from them and we are doing this recapitalization at Metropolitan Square. I don't think I would read anything more into it than just that. Clearly, we have a good relationship and tremendous amount of respect for Blackstone and we're very open and welcome to doing new business together but I think it will be very situational.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is on L.A, for future investment, your comment sounded a little bit as though we should be patient. But maybe you could just frame some perspective, when you look at the companies out there, whether it's or Hudson, they'
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is on L.A, for future investment, your comment sounded a little bit as though we should be patient. But maybe you could just frame some perspective, when you look at the companies out there, whether it's or Hudson, they're buying like individual deals or maybe a portfolio like Westwood, but the number of the properties that need sort of a Boston criteria don't seem as widespread at least to those of us. So maybe if you can just provide a little bit more perspective on what you guys see as the opportunities set both in aggregate and then, maybe as far as timing, if it's something that's within -- we should wait another 6 months or maybe another 12 plus before we see more investment?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the strategy as you know and as we've been articulating is that the investment in Colorado Center isn't one-off. I mean, we clearly feel that we're going to make a profitable investment in Colorado Center, which is great and was certainly one of the ob
componenttext: So the strategy as you know and as we've been articulating is that the investment in Colorado Center isn't one-off. I mean, we clearly feel that we're going to make a profitable investment in Colorado Center, which is great and was certainly one of the objectives and the other objectives is to get us into the LA market, which we think will be attractive and an important market for the company over the long term. But we don't intend to go out and make new investments just to grow in L.A. Each investment that Colorado Center did, has to stand on its own and in our opinion, create attractive return for shareholders. And so when I think -- also if you look at the overall company, we entered the San Francisco market in the late '90s and it still is the smallest region of the 4 primary markets of the company and here we are, nearly 20 years later. So our intent is to grow, we view the investment in LA as strategic but we're going to wait for opportunities we, again think makes sense and pencil from a return perspective. So where we are in the market today, I don't think you should expect us to go out and purchase stabilize assets in more kind of cap rate environment. Those are not the kinds of things that we're going to be doing. We're going to be looking at new developments. We're going to be looking at assets that needs some repositioning or least up. Our focus will be on a handful of markets in West L.A. and I don't think you should put a confined timeframe on it like 6 months or 12 months. We're going to be careful and patient and wait for the right opportunity.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Mike, a question for you. How much taking the properties out to put them into the redevelopment pool instead of the same store pool impact same store growth. So if you haven't re-classed and you said these are properties we own. We're doing work with them coming out of the pool, what would same-store growth be then?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's that significant to '16 to '17[ph]. We talked about $8 million of reduction. I think that -- we didn't pull them out in the '15 to '16 at this point. I mean, they'll probably come out in the fourth quarter, so 1 quarter at 601 being out
componenttext: I don't think it's that significant to '16 to '17[ph]. We talked about $8 million of reduction. I think that -- we didn't pull them out in the '15 to '16 at this point. I mean, they'll probably come out in the fourth quarter, so 1 quarter at 601 being out for the low-rise which will be a little bit impact -- which will have a little bit of impact. But I would say that 25 basis points, maybe to 50 basis points about that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. On Colorado Center, you said you have deals that are closed? How much capital is it going to take those deals in place or is going to be sort of just the normal expense?
componenttext: Okay. On Colorado Center, you said you have deals that are closed? How much capital is it going to take those deals in place or is going to be sort of just the normal expense?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the deals that we have in place are not legally conditioned on us doing any work to the exterior areas of the building. There's a tenant improvement contribution for each of the deal and I think the general market is $70 to $80 for a 10 year deal and i
componenttext: So the deals that we have in place are not legally conditioned on us doing any work to the exterior areas of the building. There's a tenant improvement contribution for each of the deal and I think the general market is $70 to $80 for a 10 year deal and it's closer to $100 for a 15 year deal. What we intend to do a major repositioning of the property and we have plan that we've come up with that we discussed with, the other party in the transaction and we don't have a firm budget on that yet but it's somewhere, more than $10 million and probably less than $25 million and we have to come to an agreement internally with them on what the right amount to spend is and how long it will take. But that will be more of a global repositioning as opposed to what's required for these deals. These deals don't have any requirement from a legal perspective.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Manny, the number's above[ph]about 50 basis points. It's about $8 million and roundabout $1.350 billion of our share same-store.
componenttext: Manny, the number's above[ph]about 50 basis points. It's about $8 million and roundabout $1.350 billion of our share same-store.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Is there any agreement with Salesforce in space or any option in place if they want more space at Salesforce Tower, they get it or is it a new negotiation for new space?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: So our lease with Salesforce.com includes just the space that they have on "their existing lease." So we have the unfettered right to lease other space to other tenants. You would think that the major 800,000 square foot tenant will be an important customer and so to the extent, we are doing things on other parts, we are letting them know what's going on to the extent that if they have an interest in that space, they can give us their view on how we might work with them on it.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes the line of Tom Lesnick of Capital One Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes the line of Tom Lesnick of Capital One Securities.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, going back to the discussion about financing for 2017, and specifically, mortgage debt. Could you comment at all on what the appetite for balance sheet debt looks like relative to the CMBS market right now?
componenttext: I guess, first, going back to the discussion about financing for 2017, and specifically, mortgage debt. Could you comment at all on what the appetite for balance sheet debt looks like relative to the CMBS market right now?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think both have strong appetites. I think the CMBS market has come back there very strong in the summertime after kind of a week volatile first quarter and beginning of second quarter. And light companies were actually holding back a little bit because
componenttext: I think both have strong appetites. I think the CMBS market has come back there very strong in the summertime after kind of a week volatile first quarter and beginning of second quarter. And light companies were actually holding back a little bit because they wanted to have a more even outflow. So they kind of held back in the first half and now CMBS is more competitive than they are. So you got swap rates that are below treasury rates and then, you got -- for leverage rates that are 50% to 60%, the spreads are very, very tight on CMBS, so they're competitive. So I think now the light companies are trying to become more competitive and put out capital. They have more to put out by the end of the year, so I think it's pretty competitive. And I think that when we look at 767 5th Avenue, that's a big loan. That is going to be more in line with the CMBS market, I would imagine because you would have to put together many other life companies to put that together given its size and the fact that most life companies are maxing out at a couple of hundred to maybe $400 million at most. Or we could do kind of large kind of bank loan transaction which is actually what we have today when we originally did the deal.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my other question. On the redevelopment of the low rise at 601 Lex, how are you guys thinking about positioning rents for that space relative to the kind of wide range of rents in Midtown?
componenttext: And then my other question. On the redevelopment of the low rise at 601 Lex, how are you guys thinking about positioning rents for that space relative to the kind of wide range of rents in Midtown?

componenttext: Todd, you want to take that one?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a very unique product and we're very, very, very excited about it. It's got light in there but no views. It's got a very good location. So that will be position to be in the high 80s. And as 10% of the entire space is at those space terraces.
componenttext: That's a very unique product and we're very, very, very excited about it. It's got light in there but no views. It's got a very good location. So that will be position to be in the high 80s. And as 10% of the entire space is at those space terraces.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Blaine Heck with Wells Fargo.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Owen -- Owen or Doug, it sounds like you have a lot of situations where the lag between signed leases and occupancy or renovation are delaying the recognition of income. But on the flip side, can you talk about anywhere you think their vacant space that c
componenttext: Owen -- Owen or Doug, it sounds like you have a lot of situations where the lag between signed leases and occupancy or renovation are delaying the recognition of income. But on the flip side, can you talk about anywhere you think their vacant space that could be leased quick enough to become income-producing before the end of the year and maybe provide some upside to guidance?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I am hesitant to answer that question too aggressively because the circumstances under which we deliver the space are so critical to when we recognize -- have the ability to recognize revenue. So we can signed leases and be in a position where the spac
componenttext: So I am hesitant to answer that question too aggressively because the circumstances under which we deliver the space are so critical to when we recognize -- have the ability to recognize revenue. So we can signed leases and be in a position where the spaces committed and if we deliver the space in 1 condition, where it recognize the revenue they want and delivering it after having move the existing improvements, it can be 10 months or 12 months or 6 months delayed, so Mike's numbers have some of that baked into them in terms of his projections for our same-store growth for the year but it's pretty muted because of the issues associated with the delivery conditions. So I think we will do more leasing, I don't know whether or not we'll be able to get impact from it on our 2017 numbers.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then, it looks as though CapEx was higher than normal again this quarter and I know it can be a little bit lagging indicator since leases commenced during the second quarter but can you guys just talk a little bit more. You touched
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then, it looks as though CapEx was higher than normal again this quarter and I know it can be a little bit lagging indicator since leases commenced during the second quarter but can you guys just talk a little bit more. You touched on it in New York but what are you seeing in each of your markets with respect to concessions and are you getting any pushback in any of the markets to increase rent or TI?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would tell you that overall, in our markets, if you have to take a direction, concessions are moderately up as opposed to moderately down. I think in New York City, many landlords have taken the recipe that we've been working with for a number of yea
componenttext: So I would tell you that overall, in our markets, if you have to take a direction, concessions are moderately up as opposed to moderately down. I think in New York City, many landlords have taken the recipe that we've been working with for a number of years and prebuilding space and if you prebuild a suite, you're giving a lot more money in the space than you are when you're giving out allowance. But in theory, you're reducing the free rent concession significantly and/or improving your velocity. I described this transaction environment in Washington, D.C. It's pretty close to where it was last year. Maybe it's slightly higher. I think the greater San Francisco market is actually -- concessions have gone down a little bit in the sense that many tenants are sort of deciding that renewing in place on average is a more economical experience for them because of the cost associated with having to relocate. So if you have a tenant place, you can get away with a smaller concession than with a new tenant coming into that space. And then, in the Boston market, CBD probably had slight increase in its tenant improvement numbers, not significant, rent really hasn't become a factor in this market at all and our suburban market actually has seen a decrease overall in concessions because honestly, because of the stronger market and the availability of high-quality spaces is becoming limited.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nick Yulico with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nick Yulico with UBS.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, you mentioned that you're going to do a little over 8% FFO growth this year -- and next year if you exclude the termination income. And so I'm wondering whether FFO or AFFO growth could get even better than that in 2018 and beyond since -- and you s
componenttext: Mike, you mentioned that you're going to do a little over 8% FFO growth this year -- and next year if you exclude the termination income. And so I'm wondering whether FFO or AFFO growth could get even better than that in 2018 and beyond since -- and you still have a fair amount of releasing of vacancy development NOI hit which I think is a greater amount of benefit after 2017?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we don't want to talk too much about 2018 but I think that if you take a look at what we have, we've got a significant amount of space at 200 Clarendon and 120 St. James that is today, roughly 350,000 square feet of availability. That's 0 tod
componenttext: I think that we don't want to talk too much about 2018 but I think that if you take a look at what we have, we've got a significant amount of space at 200 Clarendon and 120 St. James that is today, roughly 350,000 square feet of availability. That's 0 today which is meaningful space. So I think -- and we've got some other roll ups in Boston, both Boston and Cambridge, so I think the Boston market will do very well. In San Francisco, will continue to do well. We have dealt with a lot of rollover, we still got a little bit more to go that has rollouts and we still have a few floors of vacant space. In New York City, Doug talked about 767 and 250 West 55th Street. Now we do have to release the 399 Park space. So depending on how quickly that comes in, that could be a negative for that year. And then obviously our development pipeline, we will have a full run rate of 888 Boylston Street and then, Salesforce will start to have a real impact for us. So I think there's some very positive things in 2018.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. I guess, just one other 1 on Salesforce Tower. Can you go back and explain a little bit more about you guys are talking about the operating expenses, I guess, hitting for the full building at some point I think at the end of 2017, al
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. I guess, just one other 1 on Salesforce Tower. Can you go back and explain a little bit more about you guys are talking about the operating expenses, I guess, hitting for the full building at some point I think at the end of 2017, along with the removal of capitalized interest and is that an issue that affects 2017 much or is that more of a 2018 issue?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The way that we capitalized taxes are we continue to capitalize them on the percentage of the space that is not leased. Up to 12 months, basically after we deliver the building. But most of the other operating expenses, you do have to start to ramp up for
componenttext: The way that we capitalized taxes are we continue to capitalize them on the percentage of the space that is not leased. Up to 12 months, basically after we deliver the building. But most of the other operating expenses, you do have to start to ramp up for utilities and other things and you can't capitalize those kinds of things. So in the very beginning of your occupancy, you have a tough time getting positive NOI but obviously, as you lease up, you start to get that leverage.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, just quickly, can we just get the capitalized interest assumption for 2017?
componenttext: And then, just quickly, can we just get the capitalized interest assumption for 2017?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we said $50 million to $60 million of capitalized interest for 2017.
componenttext: I think we said $50 million to $60 million of capitalized interest for 2017.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Feldman with Bank of America.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: I guess just to start. Doug, did I hear say that you're $72 million is down of $80 million lease target for the repositioning NOI?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: So we've been keeping this running total and so we have done $72 million of $80 million on the revenue side but remember that there was a net -- there was a net reduction from some leases that were expiring that sort of goes against that so I'm giving a gross number, not a net number. So there's another, call it, $15 million to $17 million that's sort of part of that $80 million that we still have to get done. But from an apples-to-apples basis, from what we've been reporting from the beginning of the year, we've started at 0 and now we've gotten $72 million of $80 million and then we have some negatives to come on that we still have to cover.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Mike, you talked about a potential $0.05 drag from a debt deal earlier in the year. Is that in your guidance or are you seeing if you do it, it would be a drag?
componenttext: Okay. And then, Mike, you talked about a potential $0.05 drag from a debt deal earlier in the year. Is that in your guidance or are you seeing if you do it, it would be a drag?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we do, it would be a drag. So we assume in our guidance that we are using our line of credit when we need it, so we got some interest expense in our guidance is associated with our line of credit which we've drawn as we need the money. So it's going to
componenttext: If we do, it would be a drag. So we assume in our guidance that we are using our line of credit when we need it, so we got some interest expense in our guidance is associated with our line of credit which we've drawn as we need the money. So it's going to be drawn throughout the year. But it's certainly possible again that we could do something much sooner than that and then we would sit on the cash and the cash doesn't earn much. So I'd give an example of $500 million because that's the approximate amount of capital we would need to fund most of our pipeline.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then do you have a view for AFFO in 2017 based on your guidance and your dividend?
componenttext: Okay. And then do you have a view for AFFO in 2017 based on your guidance and your dividend?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I can give you is some of the pieces to kind of help you. If you look at our projections for what we need to lease to meet our plans, we need to lease something like 3.5 million square feet of space. So depending on how much cost you throw it at, tha
componenttext: What I can give you is some of the pieces to kind of help you. If you look at our projections for what we need to lease to meet our plans, we need to lease something like 3.5 million square feet of space. So depending on how much cost you throw it at, that's probably somewhere in the $200 million plus or minus range for costs that would get hit there. Noncash rents, we gave guidance for that of $50 million to $70 million and I think that we would say maintenance CapEx is probably somewhere in the $60 million to $80 million range. If you look at other noncash expenses that we have, that would offset that probably between $35 million to $45 million. So you're talking about total adjustments to our FFO of $280 million to $320 million, something like that. That would bring you down probably to, I don't know, 4.25 to 4.50 or something like that on a per share basis? Just dropping that out on the guidance.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, just going back to the same-store question for '18. Just kind of back of the envelope, you guys have a sense as you're going through the numbers of where you are shaping up for '18 same-store and what kind of pop you'll get over '17 based on
componenttext: And I guess, just going back to the same-store question for '18. Just kind of back of the envelope, you guys have a sense as you're going through the numbers of where you are shaping up for '18 same-store and what kind of pop you'll get over '17 based on what's in motion?

componenttext: We've got protections obviously but a lot can change and a lot can happen. We don't want to get into '18 guidance at this point.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. And my last, I guess, fundamental question on New York City. You gave some interesting color on market leasing and demand you're getting in your building. And then you also said that $80 -- 80-ish rent market is pretty good. How are you
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And my last, I guess, fundamental question on New York City. You gave some interesting color on market leasing and demand you're getting in your building. And then you also said that $80 -- 80-ish rent market is pretty good. How are you guys thinking several years out on New York City? Is everyone kind of thinks about the moving pieces in the market, how do you guys think about what you're expecting?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you want to try that one, first?
componenttext: John, you want to try that one, first?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm very consistent. I'm very bullish on New York City. I think New York, the population is going up. All the indicators are positive. There's not much job growth as last year but there's job growth this year. I think the hotels are doing well. It's
componenttext: Well, I'm very consistent. I'm very bullish on New York City. I think New York, the population is going up. All the indicators are positive. There's not much job growth as last year but there's job growth this year. I think the hotels are doing well. It's a very good market, so we think it will continue to draw our people into the market, the tech sector, the TAMI sector is growing. So the long-term is bullish. We do have some supply as we've talked about coming on with the Trade Center primarily in the rail yards and that will be absorbed over the next couple of years.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, in terms of the prospect to push rents. Could flatten out, is that going to continue?
componenttext: And I guess, in terms of the prospect to push rents. Could flatten out, is that going to continue?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not bullish on rents moving up. I think there are some areas in the city and some particular buildings were rents will move and there are some places where it will be a little bit softer but I'm pretty flat overall for the next couple of years on rent
componenttext: I'm not bullish on rents moving up. I think there are some areas in the city and some particular buildings were rents will move and there are some places where it will be a little bit softer but I'm pretty flat overall for the next couple of years on rents.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Anyone else want to chime in?
componenttext: Okay. Anyone else want to chime in?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Jamie, we've been saying for I think several years now that as John articulated, New York is a healthy market. It's a desirable city, there's job creation, I think the mix of industries is getting more diverse in a very positive way, so all that'
componenttext: I think, Jamie, we've been saying for I think several years now that as John articulated, New York is a healthy market. It's a desirable city, there's job creation, I think the mix of industries is getting more diverse in a very positive way, so all that's very positive but there's a fair amount of supply. It's significant on a square-foot basis, it's less significant on a percent of total stock basis but it matters. So when we run our numbers, we see availability in New York. It's hard to push it below 10% and when you're in an environment like that, it's hard to push rents. Certainly above inflation and we've been saying that and we've been, in many cases, leasing our portfolio with that type of philosophy.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's all true, but also on the other side of that, we don't see availability going to 12%. It takes a lot of movement to move it from 11% to 12%. So it's pushing somewhere around 11% aggregate in the city and we have some pipeline coming on over th
componenttext: Yes, that's all true, but also on the other side of that, we don't see availability going to 12%. It takes a lot of movement to move it from 11% to 12%. So it's pushing somewhere around 11% aggregate in the city and we have some pipeline coming on over the next couple of years, small, as Owen said, a small percentage relative to the $400 million square foot market here but nonetheless space that will impact the market. So we're going to be somewhere around 11%, that's the availability rate, overall Manhattan is going to be at the end of the year. Fourth quarter, we're probably leasing velocity, we'll probably move up. It should hit close to the 25 million, that's the average over the last 12 years.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Rob standing in for Steve. Just kind of stepping back at a high-level. You guys are going to do, call it, $1.3 billion of NOI, roughly this year and I guess, my question is once all the developments are place in service, the biggest portion obviously
componenttext: It's Rob standing in for Steve. Just kind of stepping back at a high-level. You guys are going to do, call it, $1.3 billion of NOI, roughly this year and I guess, my question is once all the developments are place in service, the biggest portion obviously being Salesforce and once you guys are through majority or all of your planned leasing, what's kind of like the run rate cash NOI or GAAP NOI that we should be thinking about looking 3 years out when all of this activity which will come quarter-to-quarter, introduce a lot of noise to the result is finish, what's that bogey you guys are targeting?

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to answer that question in a terribly unhelpful way which is I don't think we're in a position were we feel comfortable giving you a projection 3 years out. We've given you a lot of pieces and we've described the average return on costs of our d
componenttext: I'm going to answer that question in a terribly unhelpful way which is I don't think we're in a position were we feel comfortable giving you a projection 3 years out. We've given you a lot of pieces and we've described the average return on costs of our development pipeline and the delivery of those dollars, and so if you're assuming 7% as a number that we're using as sort of surrogate, the number is actually going to be higher than that on a GAAP basis because we're describing cash yield and obviously, cash yield don't include the increases in rents that you straight line and they don't include, as Owen for example said, what our market land value is that the noncash items or non-GAAP items. So the numbers are going to be higher. And if you take that and then, Mike gives a pretty good same-store revenue number. I wish I could tell you that we could give you more than that but I think that's what you're going to have to work with to come up with our 3 year projection if you want to call it that.

headline: Boston Properties Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I know obviously it's a long way out. It's just a lot of activity that's kind of happening concurrent to each other and it's also not going to be a straight line up, obviously. So, yes, that's helpful, I get it.
componenttext: That's helpful. I know obviously it's a long way out. It's just a lot of activity that's kind of happening concurrent to each other and it's also not going to be a straight line up, obviously. So, yes, that's helpful, I get it.
